QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: Does today's government decision on Kakadu National Park totally preclude new mining activity taking place within stage 2 as well as stage 1 of the national park and, with the exception of Coronation Hill, allow exploration only in stage 3? Is this decision therefore not at total variance with the Prime Minister's letter of 1 September to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment in which he said that he would have serious reservations about any proposal that would result in the imposition of a more restrictive framework? I ask whether it is also not at total variance with comments made by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Evans, yesterday when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I would like so far as the existing Park is concerned to see some assessment of the resources there to proceed . . .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. The assumption underlying his question is wrong. Let me make clear the effect of the Government's decision. It will mean that there will be no mining or exploration in the existing Kakadu National Park, stages 1 and 2. That is not at variance with what I have said.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to what is referred to as stage 3, which is the Goodparla and Gimbat pastoral leases, we will extend the national park beyond its existing boundaries. But we have made clear, firstly, that there will be no mining of uranium. Stage 3 is the area which is the more highly prospective regarding non-uranium resources, particularly it seems for gold and platinum.

In the processes of government, in discussions in the relevant committees and in Cabinet we will be undertaking the steps which will enable the assessment of the non-uranium resources in stage 3. We believe that this represents an appropriate compromise between the two essential interests that a large number of honourable members-not only on the Government side of the House-have, that is, that we should have a proper concern for our great natural heritage.

Stage 2 of the national park will be submitted for World Heritage listing. I believe that that decision will meet with the approval of the great majority of the Australian people. I was concerned to ensure in regard to the most prospective area for non-uranium resources, which is stage 3, that we should not preclude our capacity to ascertain what is there and, according to national interest considerations, have the possibility of developing that. The decision by the Government will ensure that those two sets of considerations will be met properly.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: QUEENSLAND: LOAN TO NATIONAL PARTY MEMBER

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of the allegations made in the Queensland Parliament last week concerning a decision by the State Minister for Primary Industries to direct the Agricultural Bank of that State to lend $145,000 to a prominent member of the National Party of Australia? Can the Minister tell the House whether any Federal funds are involved? Will he comment on whether such activities are a normal part of primary industry ministerial activity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we know, Queensland is the State of corruption. The only thing that really strikes me in my visits to Queensland is the deeply-held love between the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia at this time. It is really wonderful to see the great love between those two parties there. In answer to the honourable member's question let me say that I am aware of the allegations. They concern me deeply. I would imagine that in times such as these, Mr Turner, the State National Party Minister involved, would receive numerous requests for favours for his National Party mates. After all, that is the way the system works up there.

ANSWER.PARA: I find it very sad, however, to consider the possibility that in the twilight of a distinguished career in the service of Queensland agriculture Mr Turner appears to have given in to the temptation to be of service only to the Queensland National Party. It is especially sad because the recipient of this $145,000 State jackpot is a failed National Party candidate for the Senate.

I have to view these allegations most seriously because it appears that a large part of the money loaned by the Queensland Government to the individual concerned was not its to lend at all-it was the Commonwealth's. Of the $145,000 loaned, $85,000 was granted at 4 per cent under the natural disaster relief arrangements. As honourable members are aware, this scheme is funded by $3 from the Commonwealth for every $1 from the State in years of heavy demand, and after Cyclone Winifred this is one such year. We have a situation in which the Commonwealth and the States have agreed on a scheme under which the Commonwealth, the taxpayers of the nation, funds the bulk of natural disaster relief in adverse years. However, we find that in Queensland it is handed out to National Party candidates at 4 per cent interest, at the whim of National Party leaders.

This $85,000 was loaned by the Agricultural Bank at the express direction of the State Minister and against the express advice of the client's trading bank, the Rural Reconstruction Board, an agency of the Queensland Government, and Elders. The Board considered the poor man's finances to be past the point of no return in terms of viability. His business equity was being eroded at a rate in excess of $2,000 a week. All the advice to him was that he should sell-a view shared by the pastoral house's finance manager, his trading bank manager and the Rural Reconstruction Board. These views were known to Minister Turner. But Father Joh Bjelke-Christmas intervened and loaned the man $85,000 at 4 per cent-three-quarters of which appears to have been the Commonwealth's-and $60,000 more at 13.5 per cent, which was properly the Queensland taxpayers'.

The Queensland Premier has shown his disregard for these allegations, calling it a loan of a lousy $145,000. I would like to suggest to the Queensland Premier that it is not a lousy amount but it was a lousy decision.

My colleague the Minister for Finance is attempting to establish with certainty whether the State is liable to repay to the Commonwealth any of the moneys loaned. To obtain a natural disaster relief loan we need to be sure that the recipient had experienced some real natural disaster apart from being a member of the National Party. In the meantime let it serve as a reminder to the taxpayers and voters of Queensland: It is time they stopped Sir Joh and his Party cronies playing Father Christmas at their expense.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to his Press conference in Brisbane last week, when in answer to a question on Soviet influence in the Australian anti-uranium and peace movements he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Of course they are involved in it . . . I'm just stating the obvious.

In the light of his admission that elements of the Australian peace movement are under the influence of the Soviet Union, will the Prime Minister specify more precisely the nature of that influence and the levels to which it reaches? Will he also give the House an assurance that such groups have not received any government funding through the International Year of Peace grants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —For obvious and understandable reasons on the other side of the House, what I said at Brisbane has been blown up somewhat. Let me make clear what I was saying and the extent to which I wanted to extend it into the Australian situation. I was stating the obvious when I said that there were interests in the world, not only in Australia, which when addressing themselves to this issue had motives other than concern about the mining, transport and export of uranium. I went out of my way then and subsequently to make it clear that I was not attempting to cast aspersions on the great bulk of the people in Australia, who have a deeply held conviction on this issue.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members opposite will do their purposes no good at all if they attempt to take from what I say some suggestion that the great majority of people in Australia who have expressed their concern at the mining and export of uranium have ulterior motives. I have never believed that and I do not believe it now, and I certainly did not want to convey the impression that that was in any general sense the case. People within the Labor movement, the trade union movement, the churches and a whole range of groups which have no conceivable connection with or influence from the Soviet Union hold particular beliefs on this issue. It is a well known non-state secret that I do not share their view, but I do accept, as I have consistently, the integrity of their position. I say to the honourable member for Kooyong that I have no information as to the degree of influence, financial or otherwise, where that influence exists, but it would be passing strange to believe that it does not happen in this country as I believe it does in others. As to the final point of the honourable member's question, I have no evidence before me that any such group which may be in that category has received any funding under the International Year of Peace.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Has his attention been drawn to the statement by the right honourable member for New England that stolen ammunition and weapons were shipped from Australia to Sri Lanka by Tamils to be used by terrorists? Has the right honourable member submitted any evidence in support of his allegations to the Minister or to the police? Is the Minister aware that baseless accusations against a peaceful community such as the Tamils, many of whom came to Australia to escape from racial violence in Ceylon, are harmful to our multicultural development? Finally, will the Minister request the right honourable member for New England to submit evidence, if he has any, against individuals instead of accusing a peaceful community of good Australian citizens?
—Order! The honourable member is debating his question. I call the Minister for Defence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share the honourable member's concerns about the position of the Tamil community in this regard. I share his appreciation of the Tamils as a peace loving community within our multicultural society. When I saw the Press release by the right honourable member for New England in the terms in which it was put out I was more than a little mystified. Unlike the general argy-bargy of politics in this place where we quite freely dispense allegations with regard to the activities of other people and each other, these allegations were couched in quite precise terms and in some considerable detail right through the right honourable member's Press release. It was concluded by a statement that he regarded the advice that had been given to him to be advice on excellent authority and that there was a serious matter of security concern for the Government to be obliged to consider. When members of Parliament raise those sorts of security issues with me I always take them seriously. Generally they do so privately. When they believe that a serious matter of security concern has arisen they will come to me privately from both sides of the House and raise it with me. I cannot say that that has occurred in this case. In answer to one part of the honourable gentleman's question, I am not aware of any of the evidence that has been presented in this regard. Nevertheless, having not had that evidence presented to me, I made the best efforts I could to inquire through my Department and through other departments affected by those entirely specific and detailed allegations as to what their foundation might well be and whether we could discover any truth in the matter that required our attention. Having gone through those detailed allegations I cannot find any accuracy in any of them.

ANSWER.PARA: In the first place it was suggested that a million rounds of ammunition had been stolen from an Australian ammunition factory and shipped to overseas terrorists. Ammunition Factory, Footscray is not missing, honourable members will be pleased to know, one million rounds of ammunition. Furthermore, one million rounds weighs 44 tonnes and represents two heavily laden semitrailers. Clearly, employee pilfering could not account for this bulk even over the period of a year. It would require an employee to pilfer 5,000 rounds per working day. This represents 25 ammunition containers of 200 rounds each per day. As each container is heavy this volume is not credible. Of course the employees could have spread the load around a bit. People would have witnessed a whole lot of workers coming out of Ammunition Factory, Footscray with their trousers round their knees and bits and pieces of ammunition dangling out of their pockets. I am pleased to inform the honourable gentleman that that event has not occurred either. These suggestions are entirely bogus.

The right honourable member then came to the conclusion that ammunition was shipped via Darwin, Brisbane and Melbourne in waste paper containers. That has roused the irate indignation of one waste paper exporter to Sri Lanka, who has pointed out the absolute impossibility of doing that without whoever's machine was doing the compressing blowing up in the faces of the people who were doing that compressing. I will not go any further into that, because he has said that he intends to take legal action in regard to that suggestion. I do not know whether he has done so, but if he has it is clearly not a matter appropriate for comment here.

The right honourable member went on to say that, because of all this, the Army was recently forced to buy one million rounds of ammunition on the open market as the Government factory was unable to meet the order. The statement implies that we could not meet the order because it was stolen. Indeed, an order for six million rounds of 5.56 millimetre ammunition was recently put to tender overseas, and Australian production of this calibre will commence in June 1987. It was put to tender for the simple reason, not that rounds had been stolen, but that we do not produce it. We will produce it under the self-reliant defence policies of this Government, but we do not do it yet. Over the last six years, there have been 18 overseas orders of 5.56 millimetre ammunition and orders of other calibres. During the right honourable member's time as Minister for Defence, an order for one and a half million blanks was placed in the United States.

The right honourable member also claimed that a terrorist had stolen the ammunition while working at the Ammunition Factory, Footscray. He claimed that the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation had been notified but had allowed him to escape overseas. Subsequently, on the Willesee program, reporter Martin King claimed that he had spoken to this same terrorist some months earlier, who had convinced him that he was indeed a terrorist. The Willesee program did not run the story, despite the reporter's conviction of the terrorist's bona fides, nor did it raise the matter with me and my Department or my office, although it was subsequently raised in discussions last week.

Theft is a matter for the Australian Federal Police, not ASIO, to investigate and there was no theft to investigate. The so-called terrorist was identified by the Willesee show reporter on Friday evening. His name is Ram Damieen and he was employed as a national employment scheme trainee from the Aborigines at the Ammunition Factory, Footscray, from June 1984 to March 1985. He claimed that he was an Aborigine and had lost all his papers in Cyclone Tracy. Mr Damieen worked as a supply clerk. He had nothing to do with ammunition or paper work related to ammunition. As a temporary employee, contrary to the assertions of the Leader of the National Party, he did not have an ASIO security check.

The Willesee reporter stated last Friday that, off camera, Mr Damieen claimed again to be a Tamil terrorist. The Federal police have since interviewed the gentleman and he told them that he was an Aborigine, that he had been grossly misrepresented and was going to take legal action. Police investigations are continuing, but the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young), who has responsibility for such matters, informs me that Mr Damieen may be the first Tamil who knows how to play the didgeridoo.

I believe that the right honourable member must give us more information on his claims and his sources. It has been reported in the Sun-Herald newspaper that, immediately after his media conference, the representative of a Canberra lobbying group, Carney Hocking and Associates, was telephoning journalists advising them to ring the Sri Lankan High Commission for confirmation. That group is headed by Mr Carney, formerly on Mr Sinclair's staff, and, as I understand it, the group has a public relations account for Air Lanka. My office has also been told-it is not obviously as reliable a report as that-that a freelance journalist was complaining in the Press gallery on Friday that Mr Carney had given the story to that journalist and it was going to get a big run on Sunday, but that he had given it instead to Mr Sinclair. This all sounds very curious, and obviously there will be opportunities during the days ahead for the right honourable member to clear that up.

To get back to the point, not one single item in that Press report was factually based-not one. They were detailed accusations, not the general argy-bargy that we throw around the place at each other from time to time. They were obviously introduced in the context of his embarrassment at dealing with the problems raised by the absurd claims by the Leader of the National Party in Queensland about this Government's attitude to terrorism. It is this Government that has taken its responsibilities seriously in that regard and it is this Government that has ensured that it is a primary requirement of ASIO to pay attention to the operations of potential terrorist organisations, if any, in this country. I might say that that preoccupation has sometimes come in for criticism from conservative circles, who believe that the principal function of ASIO should be counterespionage and that it should not concentrate on these types of issues.

So obviously he was doing his best, as a loyal National Party member, to cover for his colleague back in Queensland. But his best was not good enough, particularly when it came forth in such detail, such spurious detail, as subsequent investigations have found.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Defence a question and draw his attention to the Auditor-General's report, which is to be tabled later today, in which, referring to Footscray and other ammunition factories, it is stated:

QUESTION.PARA: These factories have a lamentable history of inadequate accounting. The sustained lack of interest displayed in the financial reports by management represents a serious breach of public accountability obligations and shows little evidence of the commercial orientation necessary for efficient operations.

In light of his claim in his Press statement that, with the exception of 25,000 rounds, all ammunition produced at the ammunition factory in Footscray is accounted for, how did he reach that conclusion? Where is that ammunition? What does he believe that ammunition is being used for? I also draw the honourable gentleman's attention to that part of his Press statement which stated that in another incident a small amount of explosives and ammunition was stolen, and refer him to the answer by the Special Minister of State to a question on notice in the Senate Hansard of 8 April 1986 which referred to four break and enter incidents between 29 December 1985 and 18 January 1986. I ask him: On what basis does he believe there was only one such incident? What guarantees can he give this House that the figure he stated, that is, only 25,000 rounds are missing, is accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the right honourable gentleman for his question and appreciate the fact that he is now running a thousand miles an hour away from his previous accusations. Let me now start with the 25,000 rounds. Indeed I felt that the occasion of his particular Press release required of me that I state in answer to him the maximum possible extent of the problem which was present at the time and to which I was obliged to respond. The point I make concerning the 25,000 rounds is that we have subsequently gone through an accounting procedure on that matter and we can now fail to account for only a few hundred. So in fact the bulk of that 25,000 since then has been accounted for. The right honourable member will no doubt be pleased to know that.

ANSWER.PARA: I come to the basic suggestion about the problems with accounting not only in that factory but across the board in defence factories. We have had some real problems over the last three years catching up with the mismanagement of the government factories which has occurred and which was permitted to occur by the honourable member's Government when it was in office for that very substantial period. The fact that we are prepared to confront those problems is evident in the rationalisation in which we have engaged in all the defence factories. We have been obliged in that process to lay off workers. We have been obliged in some circumstances to shut factories as we start to introduce commercial practice into them, that is, commercial practice related not only to their accounting procedures but also to their operations overall. I think that the Auditor-General correctly identified a long historical problem in regard to accounting procedures in the defence factories. He would also be in a position to be able to identify correctly the fact that this is the Government that is actually doing something about it after 30-odd years, the only Government that has done anything about it, compared with the pusillanimous performance in that regard when the Opposition happened to be in government. As I have said, in a number of those factories we have introduced direct and more effective accounting methods. Honourable members would also note that the Auditor-General has referred to the fact that this Government has begun to address those problems.

In regard to the theft of ammunition-the one million rounds that the right honourable member is looking for-that is supposed to be a matter of ASIO investigation, there have been police investigations with regard to small amounts of missing ammunition from factories, not the amounts that are going to be used to fight a great terrorist war in Sri Lanka, the Middle East or anywhere else, but a few rounds here and there. The result of those police investigations is that a person is going to have to go to trial and an employee has also been dismissed. So these matters are being picked up by the police and are being dealt with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite go: `Oh, oh!' This is a bit different, is it not, from a million rounds for the heinous terrorists that we are supposed to be supporting-a bit of pilfering here and there which is supposed to cover that particular exercise?

ANSWER.PARA: The right honourable member seeks assurances on guarding arrangements at factories. As with the accounting problems at factories, so too we addressed the guarding arrangements at factories left depleted by the right honourable member's tenure as Minister for Defence and his predecessors in that regard. There has been at those factories a tightening of security procedures to deal with the sorts of problems that have arisen from time to time with regard to pilfering and break-ins. Nobody is ever able to produce-not this Government, not the previous Government-absolutely foolproof security procedures anywhere. I would say that the procedures we have been introducing in the defence factories are markedly superior to anything that was attempted while he was in office.

Investigations have proceeded and been brought through to some degree of success, at least to the extent that charges can be laid. With regard to the particular 25,000 rounds, as against the one million, that the right honourable member has got particularly uptight about, I am able to assure him that we are down to being unable to account for only a few hundred of those, and a bit more effort on behalf of the people shifting paper on the issue will probably eliminate most of those as well.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the Rt Hon. Sir Peter Kenilorea, Prime Minister of the Solomon Islands. On behalf of the House I extend to him a very warm welcome.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister will be aware of the recent earthquakes which have devastated the Kalamata region of Greece. What information can he provide to the House in relation to this tragedy and what action has the Government carried out?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The honourable member for Calwell refers to a subject which of course has brought considerable grief directly to many in Greece and also to many of our Australian citizens and would be a matter of concern to the Australian community generally. I have nothing to add to the general details that have been available in the Press as to the extent of the tragedy that has occurred there. I can say to the honourable member, however-and I believe I would be speaking on this matter not merely for the Government but for the whole House-I have sent a message to the Prime Minister of Greece in these terms:

ANSWER.PARA: I was very sorry to learn of the earthquake which occurred in Southern Greece and of the death, injuries and destruction at Kalamata.

This is a human tragedy which will draw worldwide sympathy, but it is felt particularly acutely in Australia where so many of our citizens have strong personal and family ties with your country. Indeed Australians have notable connections with the Messinia region ranging from the landing of Australian troops at Kalamata during the Second World War to the many thousands of Greek Australians whose origins are in this part of Greece.

On behalf of the Government and of all Australians I would like, through you, to convey to the relatives of those killed and to those injured and suffering the effects of the destruction our deepest sympathies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Treasurer. On what basis does he maintain that Sydney is his principal place of residence for the purpose of claiming ministerial and parliamentary travel allowance?

—I can see, on the basis of organised questions, how the Leader of the Opposition is again wishing to play the man and not the ball, but so be it. I am quite happy to be in that particular game any time he likes. There is nothing irregular about my travel allowances. I own one residence in this country and it is in Sydney. That is the basis of my claim, as were the claims of a plethora of coalition Ministers during their period of office.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Much misleading information has been published relating to the log book record-keeping requirements for motor vehicles subject to the fringe benefits tax. What action can the Government take to clarify the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The changes to the fringe benefits legislation, in terms of the claims for motor vehicle costs and deductions, reflect the possibility of users of vehicles for business purposes being able to substantiate a high proportion of their deductions. At the moment two bases of substantiation are available in respect of motor vehicles. One is the statutory rule. I am not certain that many taxpayers understand that they do not need to fill in log books. Log books do not have to be filled in if owners of vehicles wish to use the statutory rule which has been provided by the Government. I do not have a copy of the precise rule with me, but it means that the write-off is around 40 per cent for 5,000 kilometres of vehicle usage, and for usage up to 25,000 kilometres it is about 75 per cent to 80 per cent. In other words, if a motorist wishes not to bother about the log book, he does not have to. He can fall back on the statutory rule if he so chooses.

ANSWER.PARA: If, however, the owner of a business or a self-employed person wishes to claim 80 or 90 per cent, or something of that order, and substantiate to the kilometre the differentiation between private and business use, then the log books, quite properly and sensibly, are available for that purpose. All they need to do is enter the private mileage in the log book each day and the balance is automatically designated as business mileage. It is not an onerous obligation. The notion that has been put about by the coalition, that a person must fill in details of every trip is, of course, nonsense. All people have to do is make clear what is their private mileage and the balance is business mileage.

The whole purpose of this, of course, is to remove from the tax system the blemish whereby people who have the use of vehicles make claims at the taxpayer's expense which are really claims for private use. I remind the House that many investment advisers and accountants are still advising their clients that because of the concessionality of the statutory rule it is still worth their while to own and operate a motor vehicle. The log books are available for any owner of a vehicle who wishes to substantiate the fact that he or she can claim a higher level of business use than would be available under the statutory rule on the basis of block kilometres.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Primary Industry to the decision introduced by stealth last week to increase the base price of diesel fuel by 5.8c per litre, which will further affect farm returns by $76.2m. Why did the Government increase the cost of fuel when there was an urgent need to ease domestic costs and slash the tax burden on fuel?
—I am not responsible for this area of government policy. I will check the honourable member's question with the relevant Minister, who I assume is either Senator Button or Senator Gareth Evans.

—Is the Minister for Communications aware of concerns raised by the Post Office Agents Association regarding possible closures of post office agencies? Can the Minister indicate whether there is any substance to these rumours?

—The matter raised by the honourable member in relation to concerns expressed about the closure of post offices is well known to me. The honourable member has also raised this issue with me by way of correspondence. The fact is that the publicity that has been given to this matter by the Association is very misleading, particularly in two areas. There is an indication that due consideration is not given by Australia Post to the closure of post offices, which is not true. As the honourable member is aware, there is a difficulty in relation to finance, because of Australia Post having to carry out its financial obligations under the Act. There has been considerable consultation before any post office has been changed. The recent publicity by the Association in relation to the proposals for the closure of post offices has been greatly exaggerated. I have indicated recently to the honourable member that, in relation to a couple of specific cases, the concerns are without foundation.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment and refers to the funding by the Community Arts Board of the Australia Council of the official bureau of the Palestine Liberation Organisation in Australia, the Palestine Information Office in Melbourne. Is it the normal practice of the Community Arts Board of the Australia Council or of any other board to provide funds to political groups which advocate or defend the use of terrorism? If so, what steps is the Minister taking to ensure that this practice is discontinued?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member knows, I have long had sympathy for the Palestinian cause! I think I should briefly outline the history of the Australia Council and how it operates, although I would have thought that the honourable member knew that. The Australia Council is appointed by the Government, as are the boards. We have a principle of arm's length funding and peer group assessment; that is, the boards, which are made up of artists with specialist expertise, assess applications for grants and recommend them to the Council. The Government does not interfere with the decision-making process. Neither this Government, nor its predecessor, nor the Whitlam Government, which set up the Council, has ever interfered. We have always adhered to the principle of arm's length funding.

ANSWER.PARA: In July 1985 the Community Arts Board gave a grant of $5,000 to an organisation called the Palestine Information Office. The grant was towards the costs of mounting a visual exhibition of the cultural traditions of Palestine in association with a large number of art works-paintings, et cetera-provided by or especially pre- pared for the exhibition. The exhibition was to bring together contributing artists of Australian-Arab background, in addition to artists from the Aboriginal, Italian, Greek and Peruvian communities, similar to exhibitions on the same theme held previously in Japan, Italy, France, Eastern Europe, the Middle East and the United States of America.

TALK.START.PARA: —To promote the PLO.

—There is no PLO office in this country. The Palestine Information Office is headed by a man by the name of Ali Kazak, an Australian who is obviously sympathetic to the PLO. There are people of Palestinian origin in this country. They form one of numerous ethnic communities, of which there are dozens in this country.
—Why fund them?

—For the same reason we fund other ethnic organisations in their artistic pursuits. We adhere to the principle of arm's length funding and the decisions must be made by the Australia Council and its constituent boards.

—I ask the Deputy Prime Minister whether he is aware of the plight of Mr White who, while engaged in a regular passenger service between Cyprus and Sidon, in an act of piracy by the Israelis had his boat boarded and confiscated on the high seas and directed to Haifa. Mr White spent a month in an Israeli gaol and was released without charges being laid. Will the Attorney-General tell me what action this Government feels it ought to take in view of the very strong support we are giving to the Israeli Government in recovering from this country people who it claims have committed offences in Israel?
—I am not aware of the matter. I will have inquiries made and inform the honourable member.

—I ask the Prime Minister to confirm or deny the fact that out of some 430,000 questionnaires sent to business proprietors throughout Australia in relation to the fringe benefits tax or the FBT-now known as the farewell Bob tax-less than 50 per cent have been returned, indicating massive public opposition to this tax. I remind the Prime Minister that 1 October-the first payment date-is now only 14 days away. I therefore ask the Prime Minister: What action does his Government intend to take against the thousands of businessmen in this country who refuse to pay this tax and against those, including me, who are advising hardworking Australians not to pay this vicious, iniquitous socialist tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question should properly have been directed to the Treasurer, who is responsible for administration in this area, but I am more than relaxed about answering the question from the honourable gentleman. One never ceases to be amazed by the double standards on the other side of the House, not least those of the honourable member for Denison who is at the forefront of trumpeting the responsibility upon the trade unions to obey the law of this country. The Leader of the Opposition said: `Let there be 1,000 Mudginberris'.
—Hear, hear!

—`Hear, hear!', he says. What was the point of his proposition? He is saying that where the law exists it should be obeyed. I happen to agree that where the law exists it should be obeyed, and I have said so on both sides of the industrial fence. What I find totally difficult, indeed impossible, to comprehend is how people can come into this House and on the one hand say to the organised work force of this country that it should obey the law of this land properly passed through this Parliament but on the other hand not only tell others, whom they regard as being of their ilk, not to obey the law but also actively encourage them to disobey it. They will be judged by the great bulk of the people in this country who will benefit from the fact that this Government at last has taken steps to bring equity into the tax system in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: The fringe benefits tax is part of a total package of tax reform. It is estimated that in the next full financial year it will bring in approximately $600m as part of a tax package which will bring in $1.5 billion. Not one cent of that will be kept by the Australian Government. In fact, $4.5 billion will be paid out in the next full financial year to the taxpayers of this country, the overwhelming majority of whom have had an undue burden placed upon them in past years because of the way in which our predecessors in government protected the few privileged in this community and imposed a greater burden upon the many. We will overcome the legacy which was left by the Leader of the Opposition who, when he walked out of the door of the Treasurer's office, bequeathed to the people of this country a maximum tax rate of 60c in the dollar. As a result of the combined measures undertaken by this Government, by 1 July next year we will have reduced the Howard 60c in the dollar to 49c in the dollar. One of the central features by which we will be able to do that is the bringing to an end of the iniquitous system whereby a privileged few in this country were able to avoid their burden and so pass on a greater burden to the mass of the people in this country.

If the honourable member for Denison, the Leader of the Opposition or any honourable member on the other side of the House believes that the Opposition will derive some political advantage from encouraging a few people to break the law they should start to understand political arithmetic. While the mass of people silently approve and the people who are having their perks taken away from them are making a massive noise against the loss of their privilege, if the Opposition reads that as a potential political advantage I hope that it will continue to do so because at the next election it will find, to its great disadvantage, that it has been massively wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Is he surprised that there has not today been a question from the Opposition dealing with economic issues? What does this say about the general acceptance of the Budget by the Australian community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised. The Opposition is always delving and rolling in trivia. Such matters as the Ordnance Factory, the Palestine Liberation Organisation and my travelling allowance tends to rate ahead of major economic issues. I can only assume that the Opposition thinks the Budget is entirely appropriate for Australia and has no queries about the cast of economic policy and that, despite the protestations of the Leader of the Opposition about how the Government should not be diverted from the principal task of managing the economy, he thinks it is going fine. Otherwise there may have been a question about it.

ANSWER.PARA: However, to the more general point, going past the irrelevancies opposite us to the relevance of the Australian public, in the last couple of weeks in the opportunity I, the Prime Minister and other Ministers have had in touring the country we have found a very high degree of acceptance by the Australian public that the Budget is a correct strategy for Australia, that it recognises the difficulties of our external trading conditions, that Australia is living through the worst terms of trade that it has experienced since the Second World War, that restraint with equity was the order of the day for the Budget and that the Budget achieves that objective. In achieving that objective it has done what it set out to do, that is, to reduce consumption and demand and to lift the emphasis upon savings and investment. I think that is well understood and it is a commentary on the good sense of the Australian public that it can see the attempts by the Government to deal with this externally induced economic problem. Yet the comments of the Opposition remain where they have always been in respect of economic policy-entirely and completely irrelevant.
