DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The total failure of the Government's economic management resulting in the loss of Australia's AAA international credit rating.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Wednesday, 10 September, in New York, Moody's Investor Services Inc., one of the major credit rating organisations in the world, announced that Australia's AAA credit rating, which it had held ever since it entered foreign markets, had been reduced to AA1. This was a very sad day for Australia because the rating given by Moody's and the rating given by the Standard and Poor's Corporation, which will also be reviewed later this year, determine the interest to be paid by Australian governments and government instrumentalities when they are borrowing overseas. So whenever the Australian Government needs to borrow money abroad to make up for deficits in the Budget or for any other purposes, or Qantas Airways Ltd or the Commonwealth Bank of Australia wishes to borrow abroad, it will pay, as a result of the economic failures of this Government, a higher rate of interest than it otherwise would have paid. Ultimately, that will cost every taxpayer in Australia more money.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a flow-on effect from that. Not only does the downgrading of the Government's credit rating reflect adversely on the Government and push up the borrowing rate of the Government and government instrumentalities, but also it is a grave reflection on Australia as a whole. It is a national disgrace. It is shameful that this Government should be the first Government to suffer the humiliation of having Australia's AAA credit rating reduced in international financial markets.

Moody's, in giving its explanations for this action, which had been very seriously considered long before the Budget and, indeed, delayed until after Moody's had seen the Budget, mentioned a variety of economic and structural weaknesses which `cloud the nation's flexibility for servicing long-term external debt over a five to 10-year horizon'. In other words, for the first time in Australia's history, an international credit rating agency has said that there is doubt about Australia's capacity to be creditworthy and to repay its debts. The Australian Financial Review reports:
Moody's said that Australia's overseas debt had risen rapidly over the past several years-from a total of $US18 billion in 1981 to $US59 billion currently.
The agency believes that continued shortfalls in foreign currency receipts will result in further build-up in external borrowings.
In a devastating reference to the Budget of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) Moody's is reported as saying:
Recent measures by the Government to reduce public spending are steps in the right direction, but they are likely to be insufficient to put a brake on the build-up in debt requirements.
One of the major items on the Treasurer's agenda for this Budget was to meet the requirements of international markets in reducing public spending and taxes. The article continues:
Moody's said that its rating decision also reflects several internal factors,--
that is, factors over which the Government has control-
including inflation rates running at twice the OECD average and unemployment pressures.
Industrial and labour market rigidities are further expected to hamper the country's efforts to shift economic resources into areas with high foreign exchange earning capacity.

In other words, this highly respected international credit rating agency turned its thumb down at the fourth Keating Budget. It said that there were some positive aspects within the Australian community and talked about the liberalisation of controls on direct investment and capital inflows, something that the Government acted upon too late, and months after the Opposition had suggested it. Moody's mentioned the floating of the Australian dollar and, in what we would regard as a double-edged statement, referred to tax reform. But it said that the effects of these measures are still too uncertain to provide a level of investor protection compatible with Moody's AAA rating category.

What a disgrace it is to be the first Treasurer of Australia to preside over the downgrading of Australia's international badge of probity and creditworthiness. I do not think it will be any news to honourable members on this side of the House that the Treasurer has long expressed a great admiration for J. T. Lang, who was the Premier of New South Wales in the 1930s and wanted to repudiate overseas debt. He was sacked by the Governor of New South Wales for so doing. Here we have the person who admires J. T. Lang being the first Treasurer who has presided over a downgrading of Australia's international credit rating. What were the reasons for this downgrading? Summarised, they were that debt was rising to a point where Moody's doubted whether Australia had the capacity to pay it back over the longer term with certainty. It said that the recent changes in economic policy and the recent measures-it was referring, of course, mainly to the Budget-were insufficient to change this situation. It talked about internal factors within Australia-the high rate of inflation, rising unemployment and an industrial relations and labour market system which was so rigid that Australia could not adapt to changing external requirements.

What does the Opposition say about this? The Opposition says that the Government brought this on by its own recklessness, its own deceit and its own gutlessness. What do we mean by recklessness? This Government was reckless from the very beginning. When the Government came into office in March 1983 it had the ball at its feet. The economy was coming out of recession, the drought was breaking, the Fraser wages pause was in place and it had the confidence of the business community and of the international financial community. It had everything in front of it to bring Australia out of the recession and to make Australia secure against any forthcoming international shocks. But what did the Government do? It embarked on a campaign of reckless spending and borrowing. It doubled the rate of expenditure that we had over the seven years of the Fraser Government. From 2.1 per cent in real terms on average over the seven years of the Fraser Government it has risen now, at this point of budgetary forecasting, to 3.9 per cent on average, which is almost double, and it will blow out during this financial year.

What about debt? When this Government came into office the external debt overall-private and public-stood at about $36 billion. At the last count by the Reserve Bank at the end of the financial year it had risen over the period of this Government from $36 billion to $88 billion, and the forecast is that it will rise to over $100 billion before this financial year is out. The public debt for all three levels of government, which stood at $14 billion when the Government came into office, as at last December, the latest period for which we can get figures, had gone from $14 billion to $31 billion. It is rising and it is probably over $40 billion by now. There is the question of servicing that debt. Do honourable members realise that it now takes about 40c in every dollar we earn abroad in export income to service our external debt? This is the recklessness of the economic program of this Treasurer. This economic program, make no mistake about it, has failed. It has clearly failed in the eyes of the world and it has clearly failed in the eyes of the Australian voter.

Of course, that is not all. While all that was going on, things started to go wrong. They started to go wrong in February 1985, when the dollar dropped very substantially. But the Government ignored the signal. There was further evidence of failure and, indeed, the Government noted in its Budget Papers of last year that there would be difficulties with the terms of trade. By October and November, when we had dreadful balance of payment figures, dreadful inflation figures, and inflationary wage settlement and the dollar marked down again, it was obvious to everybody that the economy was in trouble. Yet this Treasurer and his Prime Minister embarked on a deliberate campaign of deceit of the Australian community. They continued this right through into May this year. Indeed, on 9 May the Treasurer said this to the Economic Planning Advisory Council, his own advisory group:

Overall, 1986 is emerging as a year of slower, but still satisfactory growth, a year in which we will see consolidation of the very strong gains of the past three years and in which the economy can deal with the imbalance on our external account.
It is notorious that only five days later the Treasurer, having said that to EPAC and having deceived it, went on the John Laws program--

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.
—He said: `That's right'.

—The Treasurer says that he did deceive EPAC. We have his first admission that he deceived EPAC. He went on the John Laws program and said that we were moving to the point of being a banana republic. This is the level of public debate that was engendered by this Government and this is the depth of deceit to which the Treasurer and the Prime Minister were prepared to go. Throughout the whole of this period the Government was utterly gutless in taking any notice of the signals and taking the necessary steps to bring the economy round.

SPEECH.PARA: On 3 January the Opposition put up a four-point plan. It said that the Government must cut spending, that it must delay the wage case and that it must relax foreign investment controls. These points were put up in a program published by us on 3 January this year. What was done? Absolutely nothing was done. We suggested that there be a mini-Budget and that spending cuts should come into place before the beginning of the financial year, but nothing was done. The Government was gutless because it was concerned about the Labor Party National Conference in July. We suggested that the wage case be delayed and the productivity deal with the unions be called off. We also suggested that the anti-investment taxes introduced in September of last year be removed in order to encourage business investment. None of these things was done. The Government was not prepared to face up to the trade union movement and speak common sense to it. Indeed, the Government put a fraudulent case to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in March and it did not even mention the deterioration of the terms of trade in its submission to the Commission. So the Commission, although it did not accept the actual case on productivity, allowed the powerful unions to go ahead and pursue the 3 per cent superannuation claim by industrial action.

This is the history of recklessness, deceit and gutlessness of this Government. It did nothing from October right through until the Budget in August, which was said to be the great panacea. The Government said: `Wait for the Budget and everybody will see that this will be the answer to all our economic problems'. Moody's Investor Services, which had decided to look at the rating of the Australian economy, waited for the Budget. Representatives came out here and spoke to the Treasurer and Treasury officials. They spoke to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who argued in favour of retention of the AAA rating for Australia because it is a matter of national honour that we retain our international creditworthiness. However, having examined the figures of the Budget against the claims made for it by the Treasurer and having given the Treasurer an opportunity to explain what he had done and why, they went back to New York and objectively downgraded Australia's AAA rating to AA1. It was quite clear that anything that might have been said about confidence in the Treasurer by international markets is absolutely nonsense.

I understand that the Treasurer gave a pep talk to members of Caucus this morning. He told them that all they had to do was to be positive and to wait for the turnaround in the economy. I wonder whether Caucus members remember the J-curve. They were told to wait for the J-curve to turn around the balance of payments. Senator Button did not believe it. In May the Treasurer told the Australian people:
Let me make the point that the Australian economy has been entirely robust.
The Treasurer presumably also deceived his own party room. It is a national disgrace that we have lost our AAA credit rating.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member's time has expired, that is for sure. I have heard some dishonest presentations here in my time but that just about takes the cake. The matter of public importance is related to the Government's so-called economic mismanagement in the loss of Australia's AAA rating; yet everything that is said by Moody's Investor Services Inc. gives the lie to that statement. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) in his last utterance said that Moody's came to Australia, asked about the Budget, and, having examined the Budget figures, went back to New York and downgraded Australia's AAA rating. But Roger Knye, one of the people who came to Australia and who chairs the Australian desk at Moody's, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Moody's thinks the Budget was a brave one. In a rating review we take into account the wisdom or lack thereof of a country's economic managers. One of the positive features of the Australian scene is the intelligent guiding of the ship of state.

So what about that? The honourable member tried to make the cheap point that Moody's made a judgment about the Budget then decided to bring Australia's AAA rating down when, in fact, Moody's explicitly says that the Budget was brave. Mr Knye said on the AM program on the day of the release of the rating:

There are many factors that went into our decision. Chief among them was our view that external conditions such as commodity prices, restrictive access to agricultural markets and supply-demand imbalances for Australia's raw material exports, were combining in such a way that Australia would be, would find it somewhat more difficult to earn the requisite foreign exchange needed to service its debt.
He went on:
Our downgrade should not be interpreted as a black mark against the current Government or any future government.

The honourable member for Mackellar knows that those things were said. He knows that Moody's made a judgment about Australia's terms of trade over the five to 10 years of the survey period that it was examining. Yet the honourable member tries to make a cheap point. On the day of the release of the rating statements from the Opposition became more extreme as the day went on, more strident and ridiculous one after the other. Nobody listened because Australia has had enough of the strident immaturity of these political opportunists. Australians want to look hard at our national condition and pursue sensible policies towards a more secure economic future. They are not interested in the headless-chook antics of the honourable member for Mackellar.

The other thing that the honourable member said in closing was that the Government was gutless. He said this about a government which has brought the coalition massive Budget imbalance-the massive fiscal deficits of Treasurer Howard-from 5 per cent of gross domestic product to 1.4 per cent in prospect. Supposedly we are gutless. We pull these outlays down for this year to 1.4 per cent as a Budget deficit and outlays to zero; yet the honourable member for Mackellar, when speaking to the National Press Club, said:
It is not therefore in the public interest that an Opposition geld itself by announcing in intricate detail which interests it might challenge with its expenditure cuts.
This would invite the maximum degree of opposition from the interest groups directly affected.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right, too.

—That is right, is it? The honourable member talks about gutlessness. His Party is not even prepared as an opposition to say where it would change outlays, much less as a government. We can see the nakedness of the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not therefore in the public interest that the Opposition geld itself by announcing in intricate detail which interests it might challenge . . .
In other words, the Opposition says: `We made a mess of it in government but even in opposition we will not come clean on where our fiscal policy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the next paragraph.
—I know what the honourable member says, that he would bring spending growth to zero. Why would anyone believe the honourable member when he is not prepared to say--
—That wasn't the next paragraph.

—Yes, it is. I have the honourable member's speech. It says that growth will go to zero. Why would anyone believe the honourable member when he not only does not have the guts but also does not have the decency to say where his public outlays cuts would fall? Does the honourable member think that it is fair enough for this Government to labour over outlays changes for five months and bring down a Budget which offends certain groups in the community to get the requisite changes in the macro- economy when for him no such discipline exists?
—It will in due course.

—No, this is not in due course. The honourable member makes it quite clear that he will not outline any outlays changes. He talks about gutlessness. My God, the honourable member is unbelievable-talk about double- speak. If the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) decides to put the cue in the rack, I know that one of the first casualties of that change will be that the honourable member for Mackellar will be replaced forthwith as shadow Treasurer. Let us consider what Moody's said. Moody's made it quite clear in everything it said-I go back to its Press statement. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: Moody's emphasised that Australia's international credit quality remains strong.
It went on:

In this regard, several recent structural changes are viewed positively by Moody's including liberalisation of controls on direct investment and other capital inflows, the floating of the Australian dollar, and tax reform.
Who did all those things? It certainly was not the coalition. Moody's went on:
These should eventually lead to a more balanced economy.
It went on:
On the positive side, Moody's said that many fundamental factors bode well for Australia's long term credit quality.
It said further:
The agency cited the nation's political stability, its strong natural resource base, sound economic management . . .

Everything the honourable member said has been put down by Moody's utterances about its review. I make the other point that the major United States rating agency, Standard and Poor's Corporation, has reaffirmed Australia's AAA rating by making it clear that it is not about to undertake a review as Moody's has. Other commentators in New York City interested in Australian sovereign debt say that they are not in a position to commit themselves to a view about the terms of trade over a five to 10-year period. One can have a subjective view about the terms of trade over a five to 10-year period. Moody's was prepared to put that subjective view into place in this assessment. Many other groups, Salomon Brothers Inc. for instance and Morgan Stanley International Inc., indicated that they were not prepared to make a judgment about the terms of trade over a five to 10-year period. I suggest that it would be a very brave person or institution that would try to forecast the price of oil, wheat or non-ferrous metals over a five to 10-year period. It is basically on those factors that the review has changed the rating. Even so, it is a movement from AAA to AA1 which, of course, is the next category. Moody's emphasises that Australia's international credit quality remains strong.

I notice that the honourable member for Mackellar brings out the notion about the J-curve-how there is not one. He keeps making the point that Moody's made it clear that it believes that Australian enterprises will take up the opportunities provided by the devaluation of the Australian dollar and that it was confident:
. . . in the private sector's eventual ability to respond to competitive challenges from overseas.

Apparently the champion of the free market, the coalition, is not at all confident about the capacity of private business to take up the opportunity because it says that there will be no J-curve, there will be no change in net exports despite the fact that the national accounts indicated clearly that there was a 1.3 percentage point contribution to growth from net exports in the last year compared with the 1.25 per cent forecast in the Budget, which of course was scoffed at by the honourable member for Mackellar who said that there would not be a J-curve. The Government said the figure would be 1.25 percentage points. The outcome of the national accounts was 1.3. In this Budget we are saying that the figure will be 1.75 percentage points from net exports and we have the huge driving force of a 40 per cent depreciation behind it. Apparently the free marketeer opposite, the honourable member for Mackellar, does not believe that a 40 per cent price change on the exchange rate will make any difference to the pattern of imports and exports, that the free market economy of Australia will not respond, that the price signals do not matter.

The honourable member talked about the J-curve being an L-curve. The lack of economic literacy of the honourable member for Mackellar and the Opposition in general is startling. The fact that this country will secure a real and effective depreciation of that order of magnitude and the changes that already have been secured in our national accounts in net exports and will be secured this year give the lie to the claim that there is no J-curve. It is obviously there. Of course, it was swamped by the terms of trade decline. It is with the swamping of the terms of trade decline that the Opposition chooses to muddy the waters and suggest that there is no effect operating in the economy. Indeed, without that 30-odd per cent depreciation, the Australian dollar returns of the Australian primary export sector would have been decimated. As it is, they have suffered markedly under the decline in the terms of trade. As I have said, our export earnings in Australian dollar terms would have been decimated.

The Opposition does not believe in the J-curve, market economics or the entrepreneurial capacity of Australian business. Is it any wonder that Australian business does not believe in the Opposition? I heard in an interjection talk about labour market rigidity. Let us examine that. The fact is that the data put down that claim. I shall quote the OECD's figures on the changes in annual real wages between 1983 and 1985: In Australia the change was minus 5.3; in the US it was minus 0.6; in Japan plus 5.8; in Germany plus 3.8; in France plus 3.1, and in the United Kingdom plus 10.9. In other words, the greatest change in annual real wages was in this country. The claim that there are labour market rigidities and inflexibilities is put down by these figures. What is not put down is the central fact that Australia has a centralised wage system. It has the British craft union structure and is not organised on an enterprise or industry basis. Which party has the policies to draw the best economic circumstances from that condition? It is clear that the Australian Labor Party alone has that capacity. The coalition Government gave us a 16 per cent wage increase in 1980-81 and 1981-82 because it was not in any position to manage the economy.

What is the Opposition's wages policy? What a joke! It has decided to allow opting out for enterprises with fewer than 50 employees, but the enterprises would opt out into a centrally determined wage. It is upward flexibility, not downward flexibility. That is what the Opposition calls wage flexibility. When the honourable member for Mackellar was quizzed about how he would handle a depreciation, he said at the National Press Club:
We would go to the Arbitration Commission.

So the Opposition wants to have its cake and eat it too. It wants the centralised system for depreciation-it will trot off to the Arbitration Commission to get change there-but it will not have the Commission dealing with organisations which have fewer than 50 employees. There will be opting out for them, but they will only opt out to a minimum wage that is determined by the same commission. That is the Opposition's policy. Intellectually, it is a disgraceful joke, yet Opposition members advance it in this place and elsewhere.

The Opposition has no wages policy, no incomes policy and no fiscal policy. If it does not have a wages policy and a fiscal policy, it will have no credentials for economic management. It is saying that it has a $5.9 billion set of receipts commitments, and the Leader of the Opposition has implicitly stood by that by saying that he has junked his outlays commitments but not his receipts commitments. The shadow Treasurer will not say where the outlays changes will be. The Opposition wages policy is a joke and would be washed to one side in the real economy, if it were ever put into place. Yet Opposition members talk about the Opposition's credentials and how it advises the Government. The Opposition crowd could not raffle a duck in a pub. We all know that and we have always known it. Does the Opposition think that Australian business will ever trust it again? Does the Opposition think that Moody's Investor Services or Standard and Poor's Corporation or the great institutions of the United States, Britain, Germany or Japan have any confidence in it? The answer is that they have none whatsoever.

The final put-down of the nonsense and tripe spoken by the honourable member for Mackellar was the reaction of the foreign exchange markets to the Moody's decision. I received a telex from Morgan Stanley in New York telling me that the decision was taken with a grain of salt. That was the reaction of the markets around the world. I advise the Opposition to do its best at political opportunism and urge the honourable gentleman to make the most of his shadow portfolio. I do not mind entertaining him while dealing with these matters of public importance because he will not be here in this job. He will be a long time in opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Treasurer's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has not faced the realities of the situation to which I attempted to direct his attention a couple of months ago. Largely, he devoted his speech to making debating points vis a vis my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), and not to very good effect. This is the fact before the House: Moody's Investor Services has taken away Australia's AAA credit rating-but the Treasurer does not address that. That rating has been taken away from us because of the dimensions of our present economic predicament, together with assessments of our ability over the next few years, under this Government's policies, to meet our obligations in respect of the debt it has accumulated and will accumulate.

SPEECH.PARA: Someone has to set forth the dimensions of our predicament, which the Treasurer has glossed over. Over the past three quarters we have had nil or slightly negative growth in non-farm gross domestic product. We have the yawning deficit in the balance of payments of upwards of $1,000m a month, or about $30m extra into hock every day. The August deficit figure was $1.24 billion, and the Treasurer said: `We welcome the improvement'. Improvement on what? It is an improvement on the April figure of $1.5 billion, which generated the banana republic comments, and on the figure for October 1985, which was of about the same order. However, the August figure was above the average of recent months, and we are on course for a total deficit this year of about $15 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Micawber would have been a better Treasurer.

—Many people could have been a better Treasurer. We have a yawning deficit, and that has to be financed by borrowing overseas. So our debt is on course for reaching $100 billion during the financial year. Thus, growth is at a standstill and we have a yawning balance of payments deficit. Our debt is expanding. The sinking Australian dollar has stabilised temporarily at about 60c, but with a significant quantum of Reserve Bank intervention. Inflation is 8 to 9 per cent, which is highly dangerous; indeed we may trace the course that is already in motion-a devaluation-inflation spiral. That is highly dangerous. In comparison, inflation in Germany is virtually zero and it is a couple of percentage points only in the United States America and in the other countries which are our trading partners.

SPEECH.PARA: We still have in place an accord, the centrepiece of which, in principle, is an adjustment of wages to the inflation rate where there is foreshadowed an application for a two points discount, but what is two points in relation to adjustment to 8 per cent inflation? There are vast problems in that area. Another dimension is that unemployment is rising to 10 per cent, on the Government's own figuring in the Budget Papers. Further, investment is flat. According to Mr Crean of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, it is abysmal, and it is set to fall further on the Government's own projection. Yet if advantage is to be taken of the devaluation, about which the Treasurer has had a good deal to say, there must be new investment in import competing industries and export industries.

But that investment is not forthcoming because no one believes that the competitive position, which has been significantly improved, will be retained. Why should they-businessmen-when they look at inflation figures of the order I referred to? Associated with all this we have interest rates at crippling levels, going through the roof with the prime rate touching 19 per cent the other week. It has come back a little but interest rates are at crippling levels and that also is very adversely affecting the necessary investment. These are the dimensions of the problem we are looking at.

I stress to the people who are listening that this Opposition is not knocking Australia. We are not putting down the long term prospects of Australia-under the right policies. But we do not have the right policies. That is and has been the problem. It is important that the Australian people recognise who brought this situation about. It has certainly been exacerbated by the adverse movement in the terms of trade, by low world commodity prices, but the principal factor, particularly in the early stages, was the policies of this Government and in particular its profligate spending. I cannot spend time elaborating on the Budget deficit of $8 billion in 1983-84, but it was not a Howard Budget deficit. There was a forward projections figure of about $9.8 billion. But the Hawke Government brought in a $8 billion deficit embracing, in its own terms, $2.5 billion for its own new programs. So we are talking about a deficit of $5.5 billion-in the hands of those opposite-and we would have had it down further.

Need I talk about the 1984 deficit and the profligate spending of that year when we had a whole range of headings of very large increases in spending-sport and recreation expenditure was up about 60 per cent; the community employment program was up 80 per cent; the bicentennial program was up 350 per cent. It was the greatest spend-up of all time. Now this year we have a projected deficit of $3.5 billion. Everyone knows that that is a phoney. In the first place it has been substantially affected by significant increases in indirect taxes, particularly the excise on petrol which will add to inflation and make even more difficult the rectification of our fundamental problems. When the Govern-ment should have been cutting spending we had precious little of that, as indeed the Moody's statement said.

Secondly, as we know, the deficit figure of $3.5 billion relies heavily on a number of once-off changes-a Reserve Bank profit of the order of $600m; a deferral of the granting of the tax cuts, saving the Government $650m; and there is a difference in the impact of such expenditure cuts as were made, in the next year compared with this year, of the order of $500m. The real underlying deficit is thus in excess of $5 billion. The Government, in an act of bravado, will shortly bring in a Bill to introduce new tax rates as from 1 July next year that will cost another $3 billion. So the Government will go into next year, in effect, with an underlying deficit of $8 billion at least-that is, if it does go ahead with the tax reductions. Does the Government imagine that the markets have not been able to do those sums and to look forward to the incompetence and understand the sheer deceit, as the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) said, of shifting the problems into that period? No wonder further support has been necessary to uphold the dollar at the 60c level.

The Opposition does not suggest that there is any quick fix, any easy, overnight solutions to these difficulties. There is a long, hard haul ahead, but these matters underline the imperative necessity to implement the major, historic changes, changes in long-standing attitudes and institutions, required to allow this country to realise its tremendous potential, which we do not deny for one moment. These are in particular the requirements that governments in Australia should spend, borrow, tax and interfere much less, and the need for genuine tax reform and major changes in our wages and industrial relations system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual when I enter a debate on a matter of public importance such as this it is good to follow the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards). He makes some very reasonable points, and those points are worthy of canvassing. I am very pleased to hear him admit that the problems facing the Australian economy are many-fold and that there are no easy solutions. I would be the first to endorse the remarks that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has made in that regard. Quite clearly, the Government has no easy fix or easy solutions at its disposal to face the problems that have been foisted upon it.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard today words such as `recklessness', `deceit' and `gutlessness' thrown about the chamber with great abandon, directed at this Government and in particular this Treasurer. I believe that that is nothing but nonsense. If we look at the record of this Government since it came to power and the deceit that was here when we first arrived on this side of the House we find that prior to the election the people of Australia were being told by the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), that the deficit was very low and that we had no cause for concern. We were suddenly in government and found out from the Treasury that we had a deficit of over $9 billion. The Opposition has the gall to say that we are deceitful and that the Treasurer of this Government is deceitful. It tries to tie this in to some spurious notion that the downgrading of our credit rating by Moody's Investor Services will mean doom and gloom in Australia. That also is nothing but nonsense. Let us look at what happened when Moody's decision was announced. We can do no better than to refer to some of the newspapers that reported this at the time. What did they say? The Age, for example, on 12 September stated:
The financial markets yesterday brushed aside the Moody's downgrading of Australia's credit rating to welcome the latest trade figures by lifting the value of the dollar and cutting interest rates.

The honourable member for Berowra has talked about interest rates going through the ceiling again. The result has been that since then interest rates have been going down and the dollar has been going up. We have talked in this place previously about the volatility of the dollar. It is a phrase I have used before and I will not repeat it, but one can describe just how that operates. Quite clearly, when we have a floating dollar we will be subject to movements as they occur. What else was said when Moody's gave us the AA1 rating? What did it mean? The Sydney Morning Herald on 12 September stated:

Intrinsically, Australia's down-grading from AAA to AA1 does not mean a lot. It will raise by fewer than 0.25 percentage points the cost of overseas borrowing by the Commonwealth and its authorities, with some flow-on possible to borrowers in the private sector. The main significance of the move is political. Many may see it as what Moody's said it was not: a black mark against the present Government.

I repeat that many may see it for what it was not-a black mark against the Government. That is exactly right. How did other financial institutions view the position? The Treasurer went to the position of the Standard and Poor's international agency. What did it do? It strongly praised the Australian economy on the eve of its annual review of the nation's credit rating. That New York-based firm still has Australia in the top AAA rating. Mr William Chambers of that organisation was reported as having said that:
its rating was usually reviewed after the announcement of a country's Budget.
However, the article continued:
He said that Australia's balance-of-payments problems and foreign debt was obviously of concern to the agency.
`But that (the balance of payments) is something Australia has very little control of', Mr Chambers said.
`It is a problem that has been imposed on it.'

We have been saying that for some time. The Treasurer, in his brave and courageous statement to the people of Australia in setting out the scene for Australia's problem, alerted the people to that position and this Government has set about doing something about it. We have brought down a very brave Budget. If we go back to pre-Budget times we can recall the doom and gloom merchants on the other side. Those brave economists out there, all working for private banks, were saying that we must have a Budget deficit of $4 billion or we will be in really deep trouble. The night the Budget came out, the Treasurer announced a figure of $3.5 billion. Suddenly, because they had not reached that figure in their estimations, they all scurried away and said: `There must be something wrong with the figures. We didn't think of $3.5 billion'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbery figures.

—The honourable member says that the figures are rubbery. Let us have a look at the figures for the last three years for which this Government has brought down Budgets, in terms of its commitments under the trilogy. Coopers and Lybrand published a most interesting review of the Budget in August 1986. It looked at the outcomes of the Budgets, under the Government's trilogy of commitments, for 1984-85 and 1985-86, and it projected the outcome for the 1986-87 Budget. What did it have to say? The honourable member for Berowra mentioned the point about the deficit. In 1984-85 the deficit was $6.746 billion, in 1985-86 it was $5.742 billion and the projected deficit for 1986-87 is $3.5 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite frankly, the figures that have been projected in Budget after Budget have been verified. Every one of the commitments of this Government under the trilogy has been met, bar one projection for the 1986-87 Budget, which is a 0.5 per cent over-run on an increase in tax revenue as a proportion of gross domestic product. That will be the only over-run that we have had for four years. Yet Opposition members come here and tell us that we are economic mismanagers and that the Treasurer is presenting to the people of Australia deceitful, reckless and gutless policies. That is arrant nonsense.

How did the people of Australia react to the Budget? We have heard of this. In Question Time today, we heard the Prime Minister clearly point out, from his visits around the country-the Treasurer has been going around the country as well-the fact that people have been generally supportive of the Government's endeavours. For example, on Wednesday, 20 August the Australian, which is no great supporter of this Government, said:
The Federal Government has given us a tough Budget, but one that deserves considerable praise.

What do we see in the Australian Financial Review? Again, some on this side of the House say that the Fairfax Press does not give us a good go. I happen to be a strong believer that the Australian Financial Review does that. Under the heading `Mr Keating's remarkable Budget', it said:

The Treasurer, Mr Keating has produced a remarkable Budget. He has met the most optimistic of market expectations, maintained a high level of welfare spending, confounded many of the criticisms which the Opposition had signalled in advance and taken the very real political and economic gamble that his measures might not be fully effective in time to save Labor at the next election.
But it is also economically responsible and politically honest.

The premier economic newspaper in the country said that the Budget was `economically responsible and politically honest'. What did the real estate industry have to say about this? Here we have a report headed `Keating budget is good news'. It states:

The Budget news released this week may be horror to some but to the real estate industry things could be looking up. `Good news for the industry!' said Mr Phil Roberts, Executive Director of the Real Estate Institute of Australia. `The general thrust of the budget will in time take the pressure off the interest rates. I consider the approach taken by the Government is good'.

Time and time again, we can point to those in the community who have seen the successive Budgets of this Government and this Treasurer and who have all sung their praises. The Metal Trades Industry Association said: `Government administers the right medicine'. Mr Bert Evans said that the Government had administered the right dose of medicine through the Budget to get the economy going.

All those people cannot be wrong. The Government has taken a clear, concise and important step in guiding the economy along the road to recovery from overseas forces that have impinged upon it-forces that have come through our balance of payments, our terms of trade and through export and import prices that have been beyond the control of this Government. Indeed, even if the Opposition had been in power, it would have been beyond its control-far more beyond its control, because it would not have known how to handle it in the first instance.
I reject out of hand this matter of public importance, which says that the Government has been a total failure.

PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House or Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many Post Office Agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport.

We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Post Office Agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and reject any moves to change the payments to a flat rate or to tamper with the spouse rebate;
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That taxpayers with dependent children have been gravely disadvantaged by a serious decline in the level of recognition provided in the taxation system for the costs of maintaining a family, in particular:
the failure to index family allowances which has resulted in an erosion of more than 50% in their real value since May 1976;
the abolition of family allowances for dependents who have turned 18, even those still at school;
the abolition of concessional tax rebates for education and other expenses.

That this erosion in horizontal tax equity has placed an intolerable financial burden on many larger families, particularly those on middle incomes who fail to qualify for means-tested benefits such as TEAS but whose living standards are now well below average due to heavy expenses on necessities such as education, housing, food and clothing.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:
family allowances be restored to the 1976 value (in real terms), and indexed according to the CPI;
the dependent spouse rebate be retained;
the Federal Government take urgent measures to restore equitable provisions in the taxation system through the introduction of family income splitting.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Conquest,Mr Drummond,Dr Klugman,Mr McGauran,Mr Rocher and Mr Smith.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's proposal to bring about a reduction in the amount payable under the present Family Allowance Scheme, that the House of Representatives assembled oppose such a move, on the evidence of its impact not only on the family unit but on the families with multiple births.
That any reduction in the spouse rebate would also affect these families drastically and that the House of Representatives assembled oppose any move to reduce the spouse rebate.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek to restore family allowances to their former level if they are reduced and restore the spouse rebate should the Labor Government reduce this rebate.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
1. We are concerned by media statements that the Government intends to restructure the family allowance payment in a form that will reduce its assistance to families.
2. Remind the Government that the family allowance payment is not a Social Security payment as such but a replacement payment for a tax rebate once enjoyed by families for their responsibilities.
3. Whereas the tax rebate would be indexed to the CPI the present family allowance has lost real monetary value since 1976. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
(i) The family allowance payment be indexed to the CPI.
(ii) That there be no adverse adjustments to family allowance payments in the 1986-87 Budget.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned plead that the Parliament implement pro-family policies. In particular we appeal for:
1. the retention of the present graduated assessment system for payment of the Family Allowances;
2. indexation of the Family Allowances in order to keep pace with inflation;

3. an increase of 3.7% in the Family Allowance benefit to return it to 11.5% of the Average Award Wage (making it similar in value to the 11.5% of the Basic Wage when Child Endowment was first introduced by the Chifley Government in 1941).
4. retention of the Dependent Spouse Rebate and the amount of the Dependent Spouse Rebate adjusted so that it is equal in value to the tax-free threshold allowed when calculating taxable income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That families have been gravely disadvantaged by a serious decline in the level of their net disposable income through:
Failure to index family allowances-resulting in a 50% loss in their real value since 1976
Abolition of family allowances for dependants who have turned 18-even those still at school
Failure to increase the spouse rebate since 1982
Discriminatory taxation system-which penalises single income families.
Recognising the cost benefit to taxpayers when the intact family unit itself delivers essential care to the extended family.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take immediate action to:
Restore the lost value of family allowances and to index them to cover future price rises
Introduce optional income-splitting for taxation purposes
Retain the spouse rebate.

PETITION.TITLE: First International Earth Repair Year
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That deterioration of the total global environment is continuing at an increasing rate; that important environmental resources vital to human livelihood such as trees, soil and water are decreasing at an alarming rate; that there is a need for educating all people to assume a greater responsibility for the conservation, sustainable use and maintenance of vital resources; that dynamic and active initiatives are needed to conserve and renew the total environment; and that protecting, conserving and repairing the Earth can unite all people and nations in co-operative action for survival;

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will propose to the United Nations General Assembly at its 41st Session in September 1986 that 1988 be proclaimed the ``First International Earth Repair Year''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Gear,Mr Hodges,Mr Peacock,Mr Spender and Mr West.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will legislate, or act in accordance with the present legislation to replace the current members of the Film Censorship Board who have admitted to Senator Harradine on 12 December, 1984 as reported in the Senate Select Committee on Video Material, (see attached extracts), that they are not applying either the blasphemy or obscenity tests as required under the provisions of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations, and that these persons be replaced by persons who will apply these and the other related test in accordance with the said Regulations.

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blanchard,Mr Kent,Mr Milton,Mr Saunderson and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce divisions in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum.''
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Edwards,Mr Hawker and Mr O'Neil.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

We the undersigned residents of Australia totally reject any move to cut funding to Australia-wide English as a Second Language program in schools.
We request that the Australian government restore funding to the 1985 level in the 1986/87 budget.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Grace,Mr Hollis and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the government to honour its election promises to pensioners.
In particular those promises relate to the following commitments:
1. That within three years of its election to office, a Hawke Labor government would raise the level of the standard pension to 25% of Average Weekly Earnings;
2. That the lag time between the announcement of the Consumer Price Index figures and the subsequent adjustment of pensions would be reduced to one month, and
3. That the disproportionate tax burden borne by low income earners would be lifted.
None of these promises has been honoured to date.

Your petitioners are extremely angry at the failure of the Government to live up to its commitments and as in duty bound will ever pray that these serious omissions will be given the attention they deserve.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin and Mr Allan Morris.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
(2) That the impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug;

Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Wollongong Area Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we the undersigned are totally opposed to the closure of the Wollongong area office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

PETITION.TITLE: Chernobyl Nuclear Disaster
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That following the Chernobyl nuclear disaster of 26 April 1986, the Soviet Union has not yet adequately explained to its citizens or those of the Soviet-occupied Baltic States, Ukraine and other areas affected by the radiation fall-out the potential short-term and long-term health hazards and available modes of prevention or reduction of radiation poisoning. Neither have the appropriate medicines for substitution therapies to minimise bodily accumulation of radioactive elements been adequately provided.

2. That the Soviet Union operates many nuclear power stations without the elementary structural safeguards against radioactive spillage regarded as mandatory in the west. Of particular concern is the safety of the largest Soviet nuclear power station at Ignalina in Soviet occupied Lithuania, of similar design to Chernobyl, which already has a record of operational problems. Radioactive spillage at Ignalina would quickly contaminate the whole of Latvia, Lithuania as well as vast areas of Europe.
We request that the Australian Government will,
1. Through the World Health Organisation, provide medical aid and broadcast medical information to the victims of radiation exposure following the Chernobyl disaster.
2. Through the United Nations Organisation request the Soviet Union,
(a) to close down all nuclear power stations similar to Chernobyl till protective structures are built.
(b) permit international inspection of such safety structures.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Keating and Mr Peacock.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The fringe benefits tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will repeal this Legislation and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

2. The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 contains many anomalies, inconsistencies and mistakes in drafting and its administrative implementation is an unwarranted burden on Australian businesses and the Australian taxpayer.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that this House repeal as a matter of utmost urgency this regressive legislation which imposes a disincentive to economic and employment growth, thereby jeopardising the well-being and living standards of all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Fringe Benefits Tax is an iniquitous and unjust impost which will further damage the Australian economy and further increase costs to employers.
The Tax will:
(1) further increase the level of unemployment;
(2) increase the administrative costs and overheads for business and Government;
(3) particularly disadvantage small businesses and farmers; and
(4) act as a disincentive to those who are the most productive and skilled.
And we the undersigned call upon the Government to immediately repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

it adversely affects business throughout Australia, including farms,
by creating a further tax burden it destroys incentive,
it has caused unemployment,

That the anomalous Fringe Benefits Tax is iniquitous, inequitable and unfair on the grounds that-
it adversely affects business throughout Australia, including farms,
by creating a further tax burden it destroys incentive,
it has caused unemployment,

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:

preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions on a reasonable sliding scale
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
