PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows:
1. In or about August 1985 the Commonwealth Department of Aviation established certain helicopter transit and access lanes for the Sydney Metropolitan area.
2. Certain of these transit and access lanes approximately follow the course of the Parramatta River and extend over Sydney Harbour.
3. The abovementioned lanes have been set by the Department of Aviation at an altitude of 500 feet between Ryde Bridge and Middle Head.

4. Your petitioners are concerned at the noise presently generated from and about the abovementioned lanes by the transit of helicopters and are concerned that over time the present noise levels will significantly worsen due to the inevitable increase in helicopter traffic along the abovementioned lanes.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the abovementioned helicopter transit and access lanes which presently pass by the suburbs of Birchgrove and Balmain be removed or relocated in order to eliminate the creation or the likely creation of any noise nuisance affecting or likely to affect the residents of Birchgrove or Balmain.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth the legislation to tax fringe benefits is iniquitious, inequitable and unfair.
Your petitioners humbly pray that you do not proceed with the legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting and Television Act
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament becomes aware that the Public has no legal right to influence the setting of Standards for Television Programming, that we deplore the new Standards which come into force on 1st February, and that we call on Parliament to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, section 16 (2), so that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, when determining Television Standards, and screening hours, shall consult with the Australian people.
because at present the Tribunal is compelled by law to consult only with television stations on these matters,
because the new standards are a result of such consultation, and have already been implemented without public discussion,
because the new Standards are ambiguous, and without definition,
because the new Standards are composed of modifying terms which circumvent the proscriptions,
because the media is only motivated by aspirations of pecuniary superiority,
because, in contrast, the public is only motivated by their wish to exercise pastoral care over the nurturing home environment of their children,
because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe extreme importance to ``the storyline'' of a film screened,

because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe total unimportance to the effects of viewing, especially violent films, on the young, the impressionable, the immature, the unstable, or the socially disadvantaged,
because we refuse to accept the media-imposed assessment of community standards,
and because we wish to impart our demand to be consulted, our demand to have legal status in decision-making, and the right to counsel those whose decisions so deeply affect our homes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest attention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce divisions in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Stud Stock Tax
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned stud breeders of Australia showeth:
1. Stud breeders are deeply concerned over the Federal Government's decision to create a new tax which will be most harmful to the industry.
2. If passed, the proposed tax law would cause chaos in an industry that caters for the domestic and export markets.
3. Could cause the loss of pedigreed animals in all spheres of the industry for years to come.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will:
(a) Reconsider the stud stock tax and so remove an added burden on stud breeders.
(b) Formulate policies that will de-regulate the industry and achieve an environment which caters for the depressed economy resulting from the devalued dollar.

PETITION.TITLE: Chernobyl Nuclear Disaster
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concern to Australian citizens asks that:
1. The Australian government exert pressure on Moscow to-
(a) Allow the International Atomic Energy Commission full expert investigation of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster and its human consequences;
(b) Allow Australian Ukrainians to send medical aid to family and friends in Soviet Ukraine; and,
(c) Allow free communication between Australian and Soviet Ukrainians.
2. The Australian Government-
(a) Launch a public appeal to help the Chernobyl victims;
(b) Support the removal of Russian nuclear weapons out of Ukraine;
(c) Support the decolonization of the USSR so that captive nations like Ukraine and the Baltic states are not exploited for Soviet Russian nuclear purposes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That an additional tax on gold production would drastically affect the gold mining industry and impoverish the communities and infrastructure dependent on its existence and continuing development.

2. That any additional taxation raised with such a tax would not compensate for the loss to Australia of export earnings, employment opportunities, infrastructure development and the multiplier effect of the gold mining industry in all these areas, on the general community.
And we your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established to work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and health food supply and tree cover for the needs of present and future generations. By working for these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. IImplement Action Programs Leading up to 1989 which will include:
(a) Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

(b) Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygienic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground power from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising impoverished soils;

(c) Developing National Employment Programs giving priority to the planting and growing of healthy forests, food-producing trees and other crops and vegetation including environmentally sound use and reuse of water to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are greatly concerned at:
(a) The ready availability of X-rated videos and other pornographic material; and
(b) The increased tendency to highlight so many forms of sexual activity in the media without regard to the susceptibilities of the general public; and
as a consequence, Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in parliament assembled should take action to
1. Prevent the importation and sale of hard core pornography and grossly obscene publications.

2. Require the censorship authority to more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes in determining classification and suitability of films and videos to be shown to Australian audiences; and
3. Ensure greater propriety in television productions, local and overseas, telecast to Australian audiences.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:
We strongly condemn the Australian Government's reversal of its electoral policy to restore land rights, dignity and economic security to the aboriginal people.

We call on the Australian Government to immediately set about negotiating a treaty with the Aboriginal sovereign nation, and that this treaty with full land rights, be implemented under the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties, before 1988.
We call on Australian Government to adequately fund and support the negotiating process of the Aboriginal nation.

Should the Government fail in this resolve, we call on the Australian people to demonstrate their solidarity with the Aboriginal people by boycotting the bicentennial celebrations and sharing a national year of mourning in 1988.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Australia's volumptious interest rates are casting this nation into permanent perdition by spreading over outwards beyond our shores, through lack of parliamentary controls for the benefit of continental investors.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge all politicians from all parties to unite and unwind this destructive absurdity which is neither logical or morally correct, and stop projecting time absorbing incidental incidents that are not of fundamental importance.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament House. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.

Your petitioners humbly pray that you repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

That we the undersigned are greatly concerned by, and totally opposed to proposed taxation changes and the introduction of new taxes, value added tax, consumption tax or retail turnover tax, capital gains tax, death duties, gift tax or inheritance tax. We wish you to repudiate any or all of these taxes in part or full.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Commonwealth Government of Australia will protect our society from these taxes.
And your petitioners, as is duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are dissatisfied with the present Federal Government's policy on Community Languages.

And request that the Australian Government take urgent steps to formulate and approve a policy for the teaching of Community Languages, on a permanent basis, in the day schools, in order to safeguard the linguistic and cultural heritage of all Australians.

Moreover, with the present petition, we request that Community Language Resources Centres be instituted, to operate within communities, in order to assist schools in the implementation of Community Language programmes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. The present Australian national flag is not distinctively and uniquely Australian and is confused with other national flags.
2. The people of Australia have never had an opportunity to express their views on an appropriate Australian national flag in a referendum.
3. The present Australian national flag does not properly represent Australia as a sovereign, independent nation.
4. The present Australian national flag falsely proclaims Australia as a colony, homeland, protectorate, dominion or government department of Great Britain.
5. The first condition in the flag competition of 1901 required that the design should show Australia's loyalty to the British Empire. The British Empire no longer exists.
6. A public opinion poll held in 1984 using the Gallup Method revealed that 52% of Australians surveyed wanted a competition for a new design for the Australian flag.
7. There is no inherent link between Australia proclaiming a unique and distinctive flag and the political issue of Australia moving to a republican form of government.
8. The adoption of a truly Australian national flag would serve as a focal point for Australia's bicentennial celebrations in 1988.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
(a) Appoint a Committee of the Parliament with representatives from both Houses and all parties to invite and consider proposals for the design of a new Australian national flag, and

(b) Require that Committee to make recommendations on the form of a minimum cost referendum at the time of the next general elections, in which the electors will be given the opportunity to vote for a flag from a selection of at least three designs which will include the present Australian national flag and the winner of the Ausflag-Bulletin-2MMM.FM competition of March 1985.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament of Australia assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That this is not Canberra's money to muck around with, the money was taken off our husbands through their tax to give to us mums.
(2) That our children do not suffer.
(3) That our family's have enough hardships without taking any more away from us.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:
(1) Please not to proceed with the cutting of our endowment.
(2) Ensure our children do not have to suffer because of your Parliament.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Hawke Government should:
pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices on 1 March 1986;
not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned residents of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the Hawke Socialist Government should;
pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices
not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
maintain its tax cut commitments.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Socialist Government should not continue to rob the taxpayers of Australia by failing to pass on the fuel tax cuts due under the Import Parity Pricing System.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Health
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to any taxation change which involves a tax on Health Fund contributions, health charges or benefits;

That we are already required to pay a 1 per cent levy to partly finance the Medicare scheme and that we would regard any further taxation of our health insurance arrangements as unfair and unreasonable;
That therefore we urge the Government to ensure that there is no taxation on illness and no special taxation on those who seek to insure themselves against the cost of private health care.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Closure of Marsfield Post Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that the Post Office at Marsfield be closed. The Post Office serves a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced by having to travel to another centre for our postal and banking requirements, or even to collected registered, certified letters and parcels. Many of us are pensioners and the cost of such travel would be an unnecessary imposition. The nearest Post Offices are about 2kms away with no convenient public transport. Also for those of us who work during the week, this is the only Post Office open on Saturday mornings where we can collect our parcels, do our mailing and other services it provides.

We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer, and that they should not be closed merely to save money or help Australia Post make a profit.
Your petitioners therefore humble pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Marsfield Post Office.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that persistent rumour suggest that the Hawke Government intends to reduce Government expenditure by contracting or eliminating programs for war veterans and war widows.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment and that of previous Governments to ex-servicemen and women by:
Ensure no additional cut-backs will be made to the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs.
Review the previous cut-backs in such areas as the travel allowances, dental scheme and repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.
Proceed with abolishing more stringent conditions.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
Persistent rumour suggests that the Hawke Government intends to reduce Government expenditure by contracting or eliminating programs for war veterans and war widows.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Honour its commitment and that of previous Governments to ex-servicemen and women by:
Ensuring no additional cut-backs will be made to the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs.
Reviewing the previous cut-backs in such areas as the travel allowances, dental scheme and repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.
Proceed with abolishing more stringent conditions applying to the granting of the TPI pension.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Life and Democratic Institutions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the loyal citizens of Australia firmly express our strong opposition to any proposals to remove or undermine the importance of the place of God and/or the Queen in our national life, and democratic institutions.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament assembled reaffirm our nation's total dependence on God the Creator in accordance with our Australian Constitution, which commences with the words ``Humbly relying on the blessing of Almighty God'', and the Standing Orders of both the Senate and the House of Representatives which prescribe that Parliament each day shall open with a special prayer to Almighty God and the Lord's Prayer.
We also call on the Parliament assembled to re-affirm our genuine loyalty to our Head of State, the Queen of Australia, Elizabeth II-``God save the Queen''.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Administration Fees
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(1) We oppose the introduction of a Tertiary Administration fee on the grounds that it will pave the way for an elitist system of education available only to those who can afford to pay; and

(2) We oppose the introduction of a tertiary administration fee on the grounds that it will provide the legislative machinery to increase tertiary fees at any time deemed necessary by government, offering no recourse to tertiary students.
What your petitioners therefore humbly pray; that the House take all possible steps to withdraw the introduction of the Tertiary Administration Fee.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights
that the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education
that the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate
that the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will oppose the Bill of Rights, support Liberal amendments to improve it in case it is passed, and pledge to repeal it should it become law.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labour Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Islander Languages
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas:
(a) Aboriginal and Islander languages, which numbered approximately 260 when Europeans first arrived, are even more seriously endangered-already 145 have become extinct.
(b) English-speaking population expansion and English-speaking mass media expansion threatens the survival of the remaining languages of Australia.

(c) Aboriginal languages reflect an ethos that is truly Australian and unless steps are taken to implement language maintenance, this ethos will be lost not only to Aborigines but to non-Aboriginal Australians, and to the world.
We humbly pray the Government to:

1. Through the Prime Minister's Department, provide $300,000 per annum for a guaranteed period of ten years to enable the Aboriginal community of Australia to establish a co-ordinating body to implement steps to prevent the extinction of the remaining languages, and to introduce programmes which will enable these languages to continue into the future for the sake of all Australians. This body will enable us to maximize existing financial, material, and human resources, and is the least expensive way of implementing urgently needed maintenance programmes.
2. Through the Prime Minister's Department, provide finance for the establishment of Regional Language Centres-ten are urgently needed-cost $200,000 each.
and we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purposes for our Nation.
And your petitioners, in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Flags Amendment Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

1. That the Flags Amendment Bill, 1984, as presented to the Senate and passed, which ensures that the Australian Flag cannot be changed except by referenda, be brought before the House of Representatives.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will ensure that the Flag Amendment Bill, 1984, will be presented to the House of Representatives at the earliest possible time.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Flags Amendment Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the speaker and the honourable members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a Referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Translator: Brisbane SBS UHF
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned believe that the quality of reception of the Brisbane SBS UHF television station is of a very poor quality in many of the Brisbane suburbs.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Government to erect a translator capable of providing a service comparable to that of the major cities in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed Legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed Legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed Legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones: Indian and Pacific Oceans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners wish that all medicines prescribed by a registered Medical Practitioner may be available free of charge by the Government to all pensioners for the following reasons:
1. The enormous cost of some drugs, including pain relieving ones, not at present on the ``free list''.
2. That certain drugs essential for permanently disabled, such as epileptics are at present being charged for and therefore present a great financial burden to the pensioner.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will consider our wishes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Identification Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification (ID) cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the system:
(a) is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud and, to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud;
(b) will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private nature;
(c) will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer; and
(d) cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended and in fact provide the opportunity for blackmail and other forms of misuse.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identifications cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective and less obnoxious methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forest: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows woodchipping and clear-felling will destroy the Otway Forests, water catchments and jobs in tourism.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will protect the Otway Forests for the future and refuse any licence to export woodchips from the Otways.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights in Poland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That basic human rights and freedoms continue to be ignored by the government in Poland.
That there are still some 350 political prisoners in Polish jails, despite an amnesty declared on 22 July 1986.
That the government in Poland continues to deny such persons the status of political prisoner and frequently submits them to physical and mental torture, refusing them even basic medical attention.

That the government-created and government-controlled trade unions have no standing among the workers, who still regard the suppressed and outlawed Trade Union Solidarity as having been their only true representative body.
That there is no freedom of thought at Polish universities and no freedom of expression in Polish media.

Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should do all in its power and authority, through the Government of Australia, to alleviate the suffering of the Polish people and to ensure that the government in Poland recognises human rights and freedoms, admits to the existence of political prisoners and allows them humane treatment, freeing all such prisoners as soon as possible; and that the government in Poland restores former rights and privileges to the Trade Union Solidarity, re-establishes basic university freedoms, re-admits academics who were dismissed for their political beliefs, and introduces true freedom of expression in the Polish media.

3. That all the most important U.S. Bases in Australia have nuclear First Strike functions is clear, with Pine Gap for example having the ability to pick out land targets for the U.S.A. Sea-Launched Tomahawk Cruise Missiles.
4. Action against U.S.A. Bases in Australia is Over- due and Urgent. They endanger World Peace and are an outrageous violation of Australia's National Sovereignty.

DEBATE.TITLE: FUTURE DIRECTIONS FOR COMMERCIAL BROADCASTING SERVICES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 August, on motion by Mr Cohen:
That the House take note of the papers.
Motion (by Mr Barry Jones)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Goldstein speaking for a period not exceeding 17 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today for my 17 minutes to respond to reports tabled by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) on the last day of sitting and will divide my time equally between the reports dealing with commercial radio and those dealing with commercial television. The report regarding commercial radio is comprehensive and might finally give a hint of progress to those entrepreneurs and consumers anxious to see established additional radio services in regional areas of Australia after years of frustrating delay and inaction. But, as the report itself suggests, the equalisation of regional television services is to receive priority, so it will be still some time before additional radio services become available. The lack of departmental resources, combined with the problems associated with band II clearance, will mean even further delays to the long-awaited expansion of radio service in the rural areas of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the radio report alludes to the need for an indicative plan that would provide a program for change and assist in the decision-making process. Such a plan is long overdue and when completed should take away some of the ad hockery, uncertainty and false expectations which have plagued this Government's approach to broadcasting since it was elected in 1983. A coherent, detailed and well thought out framework, which presumably such a plan could provide, would go a long way towards putting the development of radio broadcasting in Australia on a more rational and predictable path.

The study outlines various options for expanding regional commercial radio services. Reading between the lines, it would appear that option C, the so-called market groups approach, is the one favoured by the authors of the report. Approach C would involve the Minister and the Department of Communications categorising the regional radio markets into four groups: Firstly, markets where there is a prima facie case that a new competitor would be viable; secondly, markets where there is a doubt about the viability of a new competitor; thirdly, markets where it is believed that a new competitor would not be viable; and, fourthly, markets that are so small that special measures may be needed. The report then suggests several ways in which the new or extra services could be brought to those markets. The options range from using the existing supplementary scheme, combined with the use of ministerial planning powers, to a fast-track option which would abolish the supplementary scheme and allow the rapid introduction of additional services. Of course, the advantage of that method, apart from a more speedy introduction of services, is that it would reduce the time and effort currently expended by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in what are sometimes unnecessary and costly licence hearings. The coalition would favour a more streamlined and less bureaucratic process in respect of the whole licensing system. We do, of course, favour the supplementary licence scheme.

In the section on structural matters, the report raises the issue of ownership and control provisions with respect to radio. The Opposition parties are also in favour of a review of the current ownership provisions, particularly if changes are undertaken in the context of the public interest. At present, the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 restricts any one owner to owning no more than eight radio stations, of which only four can be in any one State. Moreover, there is a limit of four metropolitan stations throughout the country and a limit of only one metropolitan station in any one State. The Tribunal observed:
Compared with television, there is no significant concentration of ownership in commercial radio.
I believe that the Government should seriously consider a loosening of the current ownership provisions as they apply to commercial radio.

In the area of programming, the coalition is particularly concerned that new independent radio licensees may not provide a decent choice and range of programs; rather, they may concentrate on trying to compete with the existing licensee for the same market niche. The report refers to this type of programming as `me-tooism'. In such cases a supplementary or additional permit-which is the Opposition's policy-granted to the existing operator has a distinct advantage. The additional programs can then be geared to the audience not currently catered for by the first commercial signal. That means that there is a genuine attempt at alternative programming. Given that the concentration of ownership does not appear to be a major issue in the radio field, the Government should give due consideration to the problem caused if there is `me-tooism' in programming when new independent licences are issued. Additional quantities of programming may not necessarily lead to better quality in terms of what is available to listeners. In other words, if the existing station tries to cater for all the needs of the community and the new licence holder concentrates, for example, on rock music because the majority of people seem to prefer that sort of music, before we know it the existing licence holder will also turn to rock music and no other tastes will be catered for. A supplementary licence inevitably leads to a catering for other tastes because the one licence holder will not set up a station in direct competition with its own programs.

Another crucial issue raised is that of commercial viability. We believe the notion of commercial viability needs a thorough overhaul. A Liberal-National Party government would look at loosening the viability criteria, as currently applied by the Broadcasting Tribunal, and allowing market forces a more prominent role in determining the viability or otherwise of a particular market. For too long, detailed and truncated arguments about viability have been allowed to delay proceedings before the Broadcasting Tribunal unnecessarily.

With respect to the Forward Development Unit's earlier study on AM-FM conversion, I must observe that the three options presented to the Minister were totally unenlightening. With specific reference to the question of converting existing commercial AM services to the FM band, the report suggested three options: Firstly, allowing all commercial stations to convert; secondly, allowing regional commercial stations in competition with an FM station to convert; and, thirdly, allowing no conversion. The Minister made a brief reference to these alternatives when he commented on the latest radio report, but nothing new was presented. I would have thought that these three options were obvious, without there needing to be a detailed study, and I believe it is an issue which the Government should seriously consider. It should seriously consider allowing AM stations to convert to FM if spectrum space permits, and of course, in regional Australia it should. It rests on the available resources of the Department to allow the necessary planning and implementation of such a move. Many people in the private sector with consortiums ready to invest and provide services to rural Australia are now debarred from doing so by the policies of the Government and the obstructions that are placed in their way. We can see no obvious reason why those AM stations which wish to convert to an FM frequency should not be able to do so if technical circumstances permit. Of course, it is not only commercial radio operators that desire access to FM frequencies. We must remember that the needs of the national and public broadcasters must also be considered when planning is undertaken with respect to the use of spectrum space.

In summary, it can be said that these three long overdue reports have raised a series of significant issues relating to broadcasting in Australia. The decisions made in the next few months and years that will arise as a result of these three reports and associated community discussions will have a momentous impact on the broadcasting industry for decades. It is crucial that the Government get it right and it is imperative that all interested parties and the public take the opportunity to comment on these reports to ensure that decisions are taken on behalf of all Australians. I must say that decisions taken to date in respect of regional commercial television do not fill one with hope in that regard.

In the balance of my contribution I will refer to regional commercial television and I will amplify these remarks when I speak during the Budget debate tomorrow. The Minister, in the statement to which I am now replying, said: `Equalisation is well within our reach'. I wonder what he meant by that. What is equalisation? Is it the same number of services in each region? The Government's early propaganda led us to expect that that would be so, but it is now clear from the Minister's statement that will not be so. Tasmania, we are told, will be a special case, and so will South Australia. There are to be two services in Tasmania, but in regional South Australia there will be one service. The result of these policies is that Mildura, a small centre, will have three services. Hobart, a State capital city, will have two services. Regional South Australia, such as Mount Gambier, Port Pirie and Loxton, will have one service. That is a very strange way of achieving equalisation. Nevertheless, the Minister assures us that it is well within our reach. What is within our reach? The answer must surely be the aggregation of viewing areas, regardless of the effect that has on the production of local programs, the lack of genuine community of interest between the areas to be aggregated together, local advertising revenue and local employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has not considered those aspects.

—Not only has the Minister not considered any of those aspects; he has not consulted anyone who has. He has not consulted local communities, nor has he seriously consulted licence holders. At no time were the licence holders consulted by the Government about the most fatal flaw in the entire proposition, which is the so-called one-in, all-in aggregation.
—Did he not talk about that?

—He did not discuss it with them and the Department did not discuss it with them. The important point is that the policy adopted by the Government now will bring about an aggregation of viewing areas, regardless of the adverse effect that will have on all aspects of local production, employment and advertising. At the moment a delegation of staff-not management, staff-is visiting Parliament House from Channel 8, which covers Bendigo and Traralgon in Victoria. It is here to register its opposition to the Government's policy. Members of the delegation know that their jobs are at stake. Because they are here I might as well give an illustration of the way in which the policy of the Government will work, to show what a nonsense it really is. In regional Victoria services provided by Channel 8 operating from Bendigo cover Gippsland through a Traralgon station which formerly had a licence on its own but proved to be too small. The service operating from Ballarat covers a good deal of western Victoria and there is a very small station at Mildura confined just to its own area. The Bendigo and Ballarat stations are both financially able and extremely willing to provide a supplementary licence, to provide the genuine alternative program to which I have just referred in respect of radio so that people can see a second commercial service alongside that of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service. Both organisations are willing to do that. All the Minister has to do is say that he will grant them a supplementary licence. Each of them, by that supplementary licence, would provide a greater viewer choice than is now possible under the Government's policy or, of course, is possible under the Government's refusal to provide a supplementary licence.
—And more jobs.

—It does mean more jobs. More people will be employed locally and there will be more advertising because there will be alternative programs. Let us look at this matter. Under the proposition now adopted by the Government there will be competition for the major audiences if there are two or three licence holders in the area. There will be a duplication of programming which means that no alternative programs will be provided. Equalisation should be seen in terms of diversity of programming; it should not be seen just in the number of services. The Government wants to aggregate the areas now covered by Bendigo, Ballarat and Mildura. The result of that will be that those three stations will need to set up facilities in the areas now covered by the other two and to set up expensive equipment for the insertion of local advertisements, local news, and the coverage of sporting and other activities. Obviously the cost of producing those will be greater than if only one area is being covered, and the cost of installing the equipment is estimated to be about $20m a year. What will the stations get for that? They will lose their existing market and have a great problem in trying to split three ways the other two markets. In effect, there will be a loss of local production.

SPEECH.PARA: The day after the Minister made his announcement about localism, Mildura announced that it would seek to trigger off an immediate aggregation of those areas. Mildura could easily be sold by its existing licence holder to someone else who would immediately take the network programs from Sydney or Melbourne with national advertising only and no local programs. The service would cover Bendigo and Ballarat, meaning a greatly expanded market for Mildura. In that way localism could immediately be wiped out because the other two stations, quite simply, could not afford to provide it. Why run local programs and local advertisements at substantial cost when one's competitor is making a profit by networking from Sydney or Melbourne? That is the logical consequence of this measure. One regional television executive recently said: `What responsible business manager could be expected to leap at the chance to invest $20m in order to lose up to 50 per cent of the audience and slash profits?'. To prove the point in respect of Bendigo, I remind the House that the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), a Labor Party member, a member of the Government, said the following on 26 August:

At a time when the Government is taking the necessary tough decisions in relation to our Balance of Payments position, it would be irresponsible to encourage the importation of an additional $400m or more of overseas capital equipment.

That is what is involved in this policy. Even if one does not agree that the Government is taking the necessary tough decisions, it is guaranteeing that we will import another $400m worth of overseas equipment while we are on a buy Australian campaign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Loans Bill 1986 is a machinery of government type of Bill. Basically it occurs because we are not allowed to overdraw the Consolidated Revenue Fund of the Government and therefore defence and certain other expenditures that would be met from the Consolidated Revenue Fund have to be charged to the Loan Fund, which is another fund of the Government, or there has to be an arrangement to reimburse the Consolidated Revenue Fund from the Loan Fund. The purpose of this Bill is to allow the Government to meet certain defence and other expenditures from the Loan Fund rather than the Consolidated Revenue Fund. That is all perfectly unexceptionable. The Opposition has no quarrel with that or with the particular sums to be taken out of the Loan Fund. However, in passing I point out that the extent of the moneys that have to be borrowed is governed by the Budget deficit of $3.5 billion. We could draw attention to the excessive borrowing program of this Government. However, I will leave that matter to a later hour this day when I will speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1).

SPEECH.PARA: There is a trick to this Bill which was raised by the Government last year. The Senate in its wisdom decided to amend it and on that occasion the Government accepted the amendment. Let me explain to the House exactly what that means. The Loans Bill comes into the House on an annual basis. Last year, for the first time, the Government tried to amend the Bill to provide for a standing Act. In other words it would no longer be necessary to introduce a new Loan Bill each year to provide for the borrowing requirements of the Government from the Loan Fund. I have to confess that the Opposition in this House let the matter slip. We did not object to the Bill in this House. However, the House of review, very sensibly, had a closer look at it because it was not acting under the very fast time program that we have to act under here. The Senate decided, certainly with the support of the Opposition as a whole, that the Bill should be amended to retain the form of an annual loan Bill, not a standing Act of the Parliament. We had the support of the Australian Democrats and independent senators in that matter and those amendments were accepted by the Senate. When they came back to the House of Representatives the Government was not exactly gracious in accepting the amendments but at least it did accept them and that was that.

I want to make it quite clear in giving the Opposition's view on this Bill that we have no intention whatsoever of delaying it. Some people get nervous about this matter because the same Bill was delayed in 1975. I want to make it quite clear that we have no intention whatsoever of proceeding along the lines that certain people did in 1975, so let there be no spectres of that kind. All we are concerned about is that this Bill should be an annual Bill so that if there are any controversial matters relating to it or any matters we want to raise in the Parliament we will have every opportunity of doing so and it will not merely be a question of the Government relying on standing legislation. This means that we will ask that a committee of the whole House examine the Bill and we will move amendments to bring it back to being an annual Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to the comments by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) and note his comments about the Loans Bill being an annual Bill as distinct from a standing Bill. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) in his second reading speech discussed that matter. I take up a point raised by the honourable member for Mackellar at the outset of his discussion; that is, the role of the Loans Bill in funding the Budget deficit. This debate provides a good opportunity in this place to strike a contrast. Earlier today we had some debate about economic strategy. This debate provides a good opportunity to strike a contrast in terms of economic strategy because essentially it comes down to the deficit. The honourable member for Mackellar mentioned the $3.5 billion deficit. It is a source of some satisfaction to us on this side of the House that we have been able to achieve a $3.5 billion deficit. This deficit contrasts with the $9.6 billion projected deficit that was the legacy of the then outgoing Treasurer, the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). I emphasise that contrast in terms of the funding restraints and pressures on government.

SPEECH.PARA: The community at large recognises that this Government had to address a very serious issue. In the face of declining commodity prices it was very important that we brought in a deficit that would minimise impact on financial markets. It is in that light that we ought to address the broad economic issues. It is important in this place to try to provide that focus. In going around my electorate I have found that the emphasis now in the community is that we are in difficult times and there is a need for some very serious economic decisions to be made. There is a recognition that those decisions are being made by this Government. This debate provides the opportunity, as do other debates- we had the matter of public importance debate earlier today and the Budget debate will be resumed later today-to show the community that all the decisions we are making head in a particular direction and fit within a framework. That framework is to recognise, on the one hand, that there has been a massive decline in commodity prices and, on the other hand, that the decline in commodity prices is being reflected in the balance of trade, the value of the dollar and interest rates. So there is a relationship between all those factors. Domestically, there is also a recognition that we need to take account of those factors in terms of the Government's fund raising efforts. I note that there will be no bond raisings as a result of this Budget. Further, there is the need to address wages policy. So when we are talking about something like the Loans Bill as it applies to the funding of a prospective Budget deficit, it is important that we take a moment in this House to show that a clear strategy is being developed by this Government and that that strategy takes account of the present difficult times.

Let me sketch briefly the very difficult issue we have to address-a decline in world commodity prices. It is well understood in the community that that decline would have occurred irrespective of which party was in government. Had the Opposition been in government, the same issue would have had to be faced-that is, a massive decline in commodity prices. It is important to recognise that in framing debates in this place. Between 1981-82 and 1985-86 there was a 28 per cent decline in coal prices. Another major commodity that has attracted a lot of attention in recent times is wheat. There was a 27 per cent decline in wheat prices between 1980-81 and 1985-86-a very large decline. There was a 22 per cent decline in wool prices in the same time-frame. Iron ore prices, which are very relevant to my State of Western Australia, suffered a 26 per cent decline. There was a decline in aluminium prices-Western Australia being a producer of bauxite-of 28 per cent from 1983-84 to 1985-86. So we are talking about a very short time-frame and a very substantial decline in commodity prices. There was a 24 per cent decline in beef prices. In respect of sugar, which is a very important industry, particularly in respect of your State of Queensland, Madam Deputy Speaker, there was a 68 per cent decline in prices. That has had a major impact on the economy. Might I add that this Government has moved to address that problem with respect to Queensland. The only difficulty we have had has been in getting the Queensland Government to recognise its responsibilities in that respect.

Barley is very important to my State of Western Australia. There has been a 48 per cent decline in the price of bulk feed barley. I interpose here that there has been some good news recently with respect to malting barley. The European barley crop has not quite come in as expected and it is likely that Australian malting barley will be able to be sold in the European market at reasonably good prices. So in all of these areas there are windows of opportunity for us as a government. There was a major downturn in oil prices, of which everyone is conscious, between 1981 and 1986.

I will now talk about London Metals Exchange prices because they are quite significant. There was a downturn of 62 per cent in the price of silver between February 1983 and August 1986. There was a 39.3 per cent decrease in the London Metals Exchange price of lead between December 1981 and August 1986. There was a 15 per cent decline in the price of zinc between January 1984 and August 1986. So there has been a considerable decline in a very short period. Between January 1984 and August 1986 the London Metals Exchange nickel price-again, Western Australia is a miner of nickel-fell by 20.1 per cent. All those commodity prices are significant in terms of Australia's trade. We have seen a decline in most commodity prices and we have had to react to it.

I mentioned just a moment ago windows of opportunity. This Budget strategy has been to set out a platform for the economy to operate on. That platform has been designed to reduce Budget outlays, to reduce the deficit and to reduce the impact on the money market, thereby setting the scene so that, if there is an upturn in commodity prices and a downturn in interest rates, we will be in a position to move ahead in terms of economic recovery. It is crucial that we have set in place an important strategy. To draw a contrast-clearly that is the function of this sort of debate-what we are talking about is setting in place policies ranging from fiscal policy, which is mainly focused upon the Budget, to monetary policy. Monetary policy has been a matter of concern to us, because we were adjusting monetary policy earlier this year to do something about the value of the dollar and interest rates adjusting capital inflow.

What we are seeking in our trade policy is an expansion of the volume of exports and import replacement production. We are doing that because the floating of the Australian dollar has given us the capacity to pursue those lines. In regard to exchange rate policy, the floating of the Australian dollar has meant some important structural changes, but these changes were very necessary for the Australian economy because we were living in an artificial world for far too long. The floating of the Australian dollar has meant that we have now begun to recognise where Australia is placed internationally.

Finally, no policy on this side of the chamber contrasts more strongly with that of the Opposition side than does our wages policy. We have a wages policy which fits within the framework of the prices and incomes accord and which, in sum, represents, if you like, a social wage approach to wages policy. We have a policy, but the Opposition does not have a clearly defined policy. The Opposition has a series of propositions and options which it might pursue, but it does not have a cohesive wages policy.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member is getting a little wide of the debate.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I was trying to set the framework in which to focus on the Budget deficit. When we put our policies in place, aiming for a deficit of $3.5 billion, we were able to demonstrate to the Australian community that we had policies. The context of this Bill, which seeks to fund a deficit of $3.5 billion, is that this Government has been outstandingly successful in the most difficult of times, recognising what basically is a $6 billion loss in income. To be able to turn around and place a Bill in this context, I believe, is quite an achievement.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an achievement in another sense, which I think is an important function of this chamber, in that we are able to communicate to the community precisely what we are trying to do. There is a recognition in the Australian community that the strategy that is being pursued is a cohesive strategy; that is, it is a strategy designed to make some tough decisions. They are decisions that I think many would prefer not to have to make, but they are tough decisions and they are decisions that are understood by the community as being responsible decisions as part of that strategy. In the context of this debate on the Loans Bill, the crucial thing we are aiming at is to say that we have an economic strategy and that that economic strategy is being well thought through and is designed to deal with the conditions which we face.

I will make just a couple of remarks in closing. There has been some considerable discussion in the financial Press and in the political arena recently about the assessment of Australia in terms of our deficit strategy and the AA1 assessment by Moody's Investor Services. What I think has to be emphasised in the context of this Government's economic management is that those overseas who are making assessments of how we are performing are saying that, yes, this Government is taking account of the difficult economic circumstances that face it and that it is not retreating from those objectives or from the very difficult evidence confronting it of those declining commodity prices that I referred to. This Government is addressing those issues and it is doing so responsibly. What comes out of the Moody's assessment and what comes out of the comments by other financiers on the international stage is that the Australian Government is providing the necessary ingredients for an economic recovery-an economic recovery based on making tough decisions and putting in place a policy framework. The centrepiece of that policy framework, in terms of the Budget, has been the $3.5 billion deficit.

I think we can contrast this role and approach to economic management by the Government with what is being provided opposite. There has not been up to this stage the degree of rigour and analysis that is required in the context of these difficult economic times. I say that because I think we are subject now to more scrutiny in the Australian community and in the international community than we ever have been. That is not a bad thing if as a government we are up to doing the job, but it is a difficult thing if one is not up to doing the job. I am very confident that we as a government can put the necessary mechanisms in place and I think the Budget strategy shows that we are doing that.

In closing, in the context of this Loans Bill I say that this Government has said to the Australian community: We are about making difficult decisions, we are making those difficult decisions, which range through the policies I referred to earlier, and overall they provide a recognition that we can, if we are serious enough about it, set the framework for economic recovery, particularly into 1987. There is already evidence that the international community has recognised that the Australian dollar has been undervalued, that it is now improving in value, that interest rates are starting to come down and that the international financial community has a renewed confidence in the Australian community. And why not, because what we have in Australia is a community that is capable of great vigour, great achievement and great performance. We have shown it in the past and I am quite confident that we can do it in the future. What is required and what is being offered in this place is economic leadership.

I ask the Australian community to pause for one moment and to think in terms of the quality of leadership that is being provided in economic management here. If the community looks at that quality of economic leadership, it sees that it is there. One can identify the components of a necessary economic policy. I do not think it does the Opposition a great deal of credit in terms of contrasting its policies with those of the Government. We are quite confident on this side. I think the economic leadership is there, I think the platform for economic recovery is there and I believe that there are many reasons why we in the Australian community should be confident of the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At about this time last year the Government sought to stray from what had been the practice of successive governments. In its Loans Bill 1985 this Government wanted for itself the power to borrow money, under that particular instrument, not for purposes arising out of its taxing and spending for and confined to the year 1985-86, but for evermore. It seems that every day in this place we see the Government moving to take more and more out of the realm of the Parliament and vest it in the Executive, and I suppose we should not be surprised. The fact that the Senate wisely rejected the ploy last year certainly has not deterred the Government from trying on the same thing again this year. It is bad enough that successive governments have adopted a similar device each year for the sole purpose of avoiding the need to refer their proposed borrowings to the Loan Council for approval. At least the enabling legislation in the past had the virtue that it had to come before this Parliament each and every year.

SPEECH.PARA: The present Government does not want to be under any such constraint. First, as its predecessors wanted and achieved, it wants to avoid the constitutional limitations on borrowings. Secondly, and more importantly than that, it wants to be able to do this very thing for evermore and a day. As to the first element, the Government avoids constitutional constraints by pretending, in the Minister's second reading speech and in the explanatory memorandum, that these borrowings will be raised for spending for defence purposes only. That is plainly a ploy. That might seem like a good enough trick because the government of the day can get around the Constitution in that way and because it has become accepted practice and, therefore, precedents can be claimed.

The second element is far more important for a number of reasons. What is being sought in this Bill is, in effect, an open-ended cheque. While it is nominally a Loans Bill, in reality it is a loans and appropriation Bill. An esteemed colleague of mine who has retired to the Ministry in the Tasmanian Parliament, former Senator Peter Rae, said in the other place last year that it is more like a Khemlani affair avoidance Bill. But more than that, it is contrary to the spirit of the Constitution and it is contrary to the spirit of parliamentary representation in that it effectively prevents us from debating the merits of a particular measure brought down each year and entitled the Loans Bill for that particular financial year.

The honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) introduced into the debate a few factors which I must say are relevant because they all have an effect and influence on the Government's need to borrow this money. He alluded to interest rates. It is interesting to note that the estimates of interest rates for various Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries as at 30 June read something like this: In Australia the rate was 8.4 per cent; in Japan it was 0.5 per cent; in the United States of America it was 1.7 per cent; in West Germany it was a creditable -0.2 per cent; in France it was 2.3 per cent; Italy was pushing us hard at 6.3 per cent; in the United Kingdom it was 2.5 per cent; and in Canada it was 3.7 per cent. The average inflation rate last year for OECD countries was 2.6 per cent. Looking at it another way, the average for major OECD trading partners was 2 per cent. Australia's inflation rate, as can be readily seen from those figures, is more than triple the OECD average, more than four times that of our major trading partners, almost five times that of the United States of America and a disastrous more than 16 times that of Japan, our major trading partner.

They are factors which will influence the consequences which arise from this legislation, which merely gives the Government the means by which it will borrow to offset its budgeted deficit. Those inflation rates will come into play, just as they affect the value of our dollar and affect our ability to roll over existing loans and to take out new ones.

The honourable member for Stirling also introduced the matter of our trade policy. He omitted to mention that our balance of payments is a disaster area, it having deteriorated significantly in the past two years. In 1985-86 the current account deficit blew out to a record dollar level of $13.7 billion, or more than 5.9 per cent of gross domestic product. That blow out of almost $14 billion in 1985-86 compares with the Budget forecast for that year of only $10.7 billion. When we talk about the Loans Bill and how much we must borrow to make up the deficit naturally we are suspicious because last year the Government was out by $3 billion or $4 billion. That does not give us any confidence in the Government's projections this year. Madam Deputy Speaker, I am sure you will understand why I say that. The current account deficit exceeded $1 billion in nine of the 12 months of last financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—It is shameful. Prior to the Hawke Government the monthly current account deficit in this country had never exceeded $1 billion, yet it exceeded that figure nine times-in nine months out of 12-last financial year. The current account deficit had almost doubled from $7.3 billion in 1983-84, the first full year of the Hawke Government. The OECD has forecast that in 1986 our current account deficit as a percentage of GDP will be the largest in the OECD area. On top of that, Australia's foreign debt is at alarming levels. It totalled around $35 billion when the Hawke Government took office in 1983. The latest official figure-for December 1985-puts that figure at $75 billion. In this year's Budget Papers, the Treasury estimated that our foreign debt had reached $86 billion by June 1986. The Reserve Bank of Australia in its latest annual report put that figure at $88 billion, but who will quibble about a couple of billion dollars under this profligate Government?

SPEECH.PARA: These latest figures also support the confidential Treasury forecasts, which were reported in the Australian newspaper a month or so ago, of our foreign debt reaching about $85 billion by June 1986 and a staggering $100 billion by June 1987-less than 12 months away. On this basis our foreign debt will have increased by $65 billion during the four years of the Hawke Government. A $100 billion foreign debt represents something like 35 to 40 per cent of GDP and will generate an annual interest bill of, I guess, at least $9 billion or 3.5 per cent of GDP. I see some young people in the gallery. This is the sort of legacy, girls and boys, that you will be left under this Government because by the time you are taxpayers you will have to pay it back. I have to apologise to you for that. This is considerably more than the Government spends on health, education or defence each year.

—I appreciate that. My reason for straying into that area was that the honourable member for Stirling also transgressed. Of course I shall get back to the Bill.
—It is a correct point of order that the honourable member address his comments through the Chair.

—I would not like to leave the accusations and allegations by the honourable member for Stirling unanswered, he having made them before you drew the matter to his attention, Madam Deputy Speaker.
