—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am not sure whether I am offended or not and I seek your guidance as to what exactly the honourable member means by `that member comes from Queensland'. Perhaps the honourable member might like to explain it.
—The Chair is not in a position to offer members guidance. There is no point of order.

—I apologise to the honourable member. I called him a National. I meant no insult by that. He is easily confused for a National. I withdraw those words unreservedly. The real difference is that in a period when real labour unit costs have been reduced, when there is an unprecedented period of industrial peace, we are not about blaming the ordinary men and women of Australia for our current crisis. We are not going to say to them: `You're going to be the victims of any economic action'. We are going to say: `Everyone has to bear the burden equally'. I am very concerned to hear Opposition speakers talking about this inflexibility that is required in the trade union movement, and bringing up work practices.

SPEECH.PARA: For the record, there has been a process by which parties can sit down and negotiate work practices that need improving. We have had some excellent examples in the steel plan, as the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) would know, in the car plan, and more recently in the heavy manufacturing industry plan. All parties to that plan are satisfied with the real progress being made, but once again the trade union movement is being painted into a corner as being somehow the guilty party that forced these conditions on unwilling employers who would never have agreed to them and in fact did not. Of course, these things were obtained by a process of negotiation and the proper mechanism is for them to be unravelled by that same process. As I have outlined, there are some good examples of how it can be done on an industry basis. We have the opportunity to do it also at enterprise level.

My constituents know full well what the implication of a Liberal government is. Hope is taken away, dole queues are created and the social fabric of the community that I am proud to represent is torn asunder. Therefore, when this Budget has been described as economically sound and politically honest, they can understand that and they can understand that they are being called upon to make some sacrifices.

I conclude on a matter that is of some interest to me and which concerns the university. I am rather disappointed that the Education Minister, Senator Susan Ryan, continues to boycott the western suburbs of Sydney by refusing to go there and have a look at the position herself. I am pleased to say that other Ministers have visited my electorate, including the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and, on Friday, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). They are certainly not boycotting the area. It is also a matter of disappointment to me that the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission and its head, Hugh Hudson, and the head of the Higher Education Board in New South Wales, Ron Parry, are still refusing to consult and underpin the activities of the new advisory council. I am looking forward to that blockage being unblocked.

Real progress has been made towards achieving a senior high school. You may recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, that Mr Hudson suggested that the area of greatest need was in lifting participation rates. We have had two public meetings in the electorate organised by my friend and colleague the State member for Riverstone. There was a tremendous turnout of parents and students, but, I am afraid, only a handful of Teachers Federation officials. Judging by the will of that meeting, most of the teachers and all of the parents and students were in favour of a senior high school, and if there had been a little bit of rope there and some white sheets, we might have had about three fewer Teachers Federation officials in New South Wales.

However, I was rather disturbed that, at the second meeting, it became quite clear that the Teachers Federation has given up on the parents and is trying to manipulate the students against a senior high school. I remain confident that we will get a senior high school, which will have a dramatic impact on participation rates and the quality of passes and will provide extraordinary numbers of students not only from my electorate but from others for the new university, which I am sure is inevitable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this Budget debate to support the amendment in regard to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) which has been moved by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). This Budget is like a hall of mirrors. It is full of illusions. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) proclaims that the Budget reins in government expenditure, when in fact outlays are increased by 6.9 per cent in money terms and by a small amount in real terms. That is his present forecast, but already there are indications that there will be a significant real terms blowout. He proclaims, like a wizard, that he is reducing the Budget deficit to $3.5 billion, when there was a stretching rather than a cutting. The lower deficit was achieved by lifting taxes, by accounting methods such as the Reserve Bank's currency trading profit, and by the Government's heroic assumptions about economic growth. I might add that this assumption about the Reserve Bank's currency trading profits implies as significant a change in the value of the Australian dollar in the current year as occurred in the last, disastrous financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: Far from reducing the size of government, the Budget does not provide for the abolition of one single ongoing function of the Commonwealth Government. Most of the Budget savings are matters of tinkering with the machinery of government, with the timing of reforms and of indexed payments, rather than real savings and giving the machine the overhaul it needs. The Treasurer appears to give us a long-heralded tax cut, but this is an illusion now as it was an illusion when those tax cuts were first announced. Whereas before the Labor Government came into office the standard rate of tax was just over 30c in the dollar for the great majority of taxpayers, under the Hawke-Keating tax plan the standard rate of tax would have been 46c in the dollar. The average weekly earner and those on incomes below the average are supposed to be thankful that the standard tax rate, instead of being increased to 46c in the dollar, is being increased to 40c in the dollar. Now there is the further illusion of the postponement of the expectation of a tax cut that was to help Australian families, which means that the real benefits of that gain, certainly in this financial year, are lost by the delay, by increases in the Medicare levy and by fiscal drag as well as by the increases in indirect taxes that impact particularly heavily on families with children.

For the second year in a row the Hawke Government has broken its trilogy commitment not to increase taxation as a percentage of gross domestic product. Had the Government not broken the trilogy commitment, tax receipts would have been $400m lower in 1985-86 and $1,400 million lower in 1986-87. As the Leader of the Opposition said, this is a taxing, not an axing, Budget. Coupled with that, the Budget tells us that the foreign debt is likely to continue, for nothing in the Budget demonstrates that steps have been taken to reduce the rapid escalation of Australia's foreign debt. This increase in the foreign debt will not only impose a heavy burden on this generation year by year, by allocating an increasing proportion of its overseas earned revenue to the servicing of overseas debt, it will also impose a massive burden on the children of today.

Something needs to be done about that. There needs to be a major change in policy. Although I do not wish to spend a great deal of time on that topic this evening, I simply want to say this: I believe in a free market economy in Australia. I believe in the ideal of a free market economy for the world. But we do not have a free market economy in the world. Major trading blocs are taking advantage of Australia's too-rapid desire to move into a world free market economy. The time may come when we in Australia need to recognise that many of those who are our closest trading partners are taking advantage of us. They are taking us for a ride. They are benefiting from our naivete. We may one day find that we have to use some of the strategies that became necessary in times of previous governments if we are to protect the Australian economy, Australian families, the Australian worker and Australian investments.

Whilst I would like to develop the topic further, all I want to place on record tonight is my concern that all of us who have ideals and goals may have to take a step back or maybe a step sideways before we can take that big leap forward that we have attempted to take all too soon at such great price, not so much to us-if it were to us, we should bear the price-but to our children. The price we are expecting people to pay is a price we are expecting our children to pay. I do not believe that we in this Parliament today should be allowing the implementation of economic policies that are putting such a huge potential burden on the future prosperity of Australia's children.

The principal topic I wish to talk about in relation to the Budget tonight is its impact upon Australian families. It is an anti-family Budget. The effect of the Hawke Budgets-this one and its predecessors-has been to bring about a major shift in the burden of taxation from single people and married couples without children to families with children. Let me run through some of the figures produced by the Institute of Family Studies. It compared two households where both adults were working, and because both were working they were achieving a household income of $40,000 a year. One household had no dependants and the other had two student children aged 16 and 18 years. As a result of the last two Budgets introduced by the Australian Labor Party Government the disposable income of the married couple without children has been increased by $10 a week, whereas the disposable income of the family with children has, by contrast, been reduced by $6 a week. Is that a sensible way to achieve what is the illusion of tax reform? Tax reform is not merely tax reduction; tax reform is making the levying of the burden fairer and more equitable, taking more note of capacity to pay, recognising the responsibility borne by parents in maintaining children and by spouses who are at work in maintaining spouses who are not at work. If we go on taxing families in the way we have been, in the way this Government has been, more and more of those spouses who are being supported by taxpayers in a personal sense and more and more of those children who are being supported by taxpayers out of their disposable income after tax will, because of the pressures put upon Australian families, cease to be happy intact families and will move into the sole parent, supporting parent category where the supporting, caring parent along with the cared for children become the responsibility of government and the public sector and in that position are forced into poverty.

The largest group of Australians in poverty are children. A vast number of children are living below the poverty line. In many instances this is because the custodial parent is not getting any support from the non-custodial parent. A second reason for their being moved into poverty is that our taxation and social security system is failing Australian families. It is not a family taxation and social security system; it is a system for individuals who have a greater capacity to pay tax while they are single, while they have no children. Yet they are not paying the tax that they should pay in order that when they do have children they can get fair treatment under the taxation system. If we had a social conscience and genuine feelings of compassion as well as proper concern for the future of the nation we as members of parliament would be deeply concerned not only that poverty is increasing but also that the number of poor children is rising alarmingly.

In spite of the rhetoric about the family which has been the stock-in-trade of many in this House, debate on the specifics of family policy has been weak and policies implemented to assist families have been far outweighed by those which have burdened them and weakened their economic viability. Not only the unintended but sadly sometimes the intended consequences of tax and social security changes introduced in the name of reform have penalised families in general and two-parent single-income families in particular. One of the most fundamental and significant causes of poverty is the substantial error we have made, and continue to make, in the structure of our tax and social security system as it impacts upon families. Measures in past years and in this year's Budget have increased the disposable income of families without children by more than $10 a week, and in stark contrast, impact upon and have reduced the disposable income of families with dependent children.

I believe that the time has come when we should develop family policies, when we should have taxation and social security policies that are based upon a life cycle concept, policies which recognise the fact that the great majority of Australian taxpayers pay the taxes that they ultimately receive as social security benefits. Today's social security beneficiaries are tomorrow's taxpayers; today's taxpayers are tomorrow's social security beneficiaries. The great majority of Australian people are at some stage either taxpayers or social security beneficiaries, and sometimes for periods they are both. I was fascinated to read an article the other day which indicated that 25 per cent of pensioners and social security beneficiaries pay tax through the income tax system. They represent 10 per cent of Australian income taxpayers and they pay $800m in tax on their pension as well as their other incomes.

But the system is failing in its recognition of the responsibility taken by parents for maintaining children, and by spouses for maintaining dependent spouses. For those who are outside that concept, for those who in many instances are not married, the system is fine. They are individuals, they are treated as such and they receive benefits as individuals. But children in intact families, dependent spouses in intact families, are assumed to be dependent upon the breadwinning member of the family or their parents. I am very concerned that some very strange ideas are circulating in some academic circles. In an article, the Centre of Policy Studies in Victoria noted:

While it is certainly true that the presence of dependants does indeed reduce ability to pay, it is debatable whether this should be regarded as a reason for reducing tax liability any more than should the buying of a boat which likewise reduces the ability to pay . . . Since the decision to have children, however, is usually one of choice, it is arguable whether the tax system should recognise such costs.
Economic analysis of this kind shows children being thought of as durable goods. As has been pointed out by another writer, this idea can be translated as follows:

A child is costly to acquire initially, lasts for a long time, gives flows of pleasure during that time, is expensive to maintain and repair, has an imperfect second-hand market . . . Likewise, a durable good, such as a refrigerator . . . or a boat!

If that sort of mentality is influencing policy makers in the way in which the tax and social security systems deal with children, we have a very serious situation on our hands. I believe children must be treated as people, as the future of the nation, and that the support of children by taxpayers should be recognised by way of tax relief which is at least equal to the extent of the minimum cost of providing those children with their basic needs. I believe the same should be true in the case of dependent spouses. It is absurd that we should be paying to separated families five times as much as we allow the taxpayer who is supporting a spouse in an intact, happy home. That differential does affect social behaviour as well as the economic viability of the single income household with a dependent spouse and dependent children.

Assistance by way of allowances for children also needs to be sensitive to the ages of the children. Recent studies have shown that $1,000 is the minimum cost to provide for a child aged two, whereas $2,500 is the anticipated cost to a family to provide for a child in his or her teens. I think we need life cycle financing for families. We need a family policy. We need tax policies that are sensitive to the needs of Australian families. A taxation system which does not favour those with the responsibility for bringing up dependent children is a taxation system without social vision. We need a tax policy, a social security policy, with a social vision. This Budget fails Australian families, as it has no such vision.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was simply amazed to listen to the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), a member of the Liberal Party, when he had the audacity to move his amendment to the motion for the second reading a few moments ago. In his amendment he talked about high levels of government spending. He talked about the inflation rate and a wages policy. He also talked about the effect of this Budget on business. He certainly has a political cheek to move such an amendment because he was part of the Liberal-National Party Government that left the Hawke Labor Government and the people of Australia with a Budget deficit of $9.6 billion. He was part of the former Liberal-National Party Government that actually created negative growth in its last year in power. He was part of the same Government that overshot its expenditure targets and blew its estimated deficit targets for five Budgets in a row. Yet he has had the audacity to talk about overspending.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mackellar talked about the present inflation rate. What was it under the Liberal-National Party Government? In 1979-80 it was 10.1 per cent; in 1980-81 it was 9.4 per cent; in 1981-82 it was 10.4 per cent; in 1982-83, its last infamous year, it was 11.5 per cent. Those figures should be compared to the low of 4.3 per cent and the high of 8.4 per cent under Labor. As for his comments about wages, I doubt whether few Australians have forgotten that it was under the Howard-Fraser Government that the work place became a battleground. If we look at the record and the statistics, we find that between 1976 and 1982 more than three million days were lost on average each year in industrial disputation. As for jobs lost and the unemployment situation, under the Carlton Government-if we want to talk about it in that way; it was the Liberal Government, the Howard Government, the Fraser Government-the level of unemployment rose to 718,000. In comparison, the Hawke Government has created 634,000 new jobs.

The honourable member talked about the nation's trading situation internationally. It was under the Liberal-National Party Government in 1981-82 that the Australian people suffered a recession. It was under the Liberal-National Party Government in 1981-82 that the current account deficit rose to 6 per cent as a percentage of gross domestic product. It is also a matter of statistical record that the former coalition Government, in which the present member for Mackellar was a prominent front bencher-he was a Minister at the time, and the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), was the all-powerful Treasurer-presided over the destruction of our nation's manufacturing and service industries. It was under Howard that Australian manufacturers were stifled by an overvalued exchange rate. The little assistance that was given was focused on negative protection measures, with few positive measures to encourage competitiveness and export growth.

I have taken the trouble to look up the actual facts and figures of that time, when whole sectors of the industry collapsed and disappeared. Regardless of what members of the Opposition now promise, the people of Australia will look at the facts of their past performance. In 1980-81 assistance given to heavy industry by the Liberal-National Party Government amounted to $47.9m. Under the Hawke Government last year, this figure rose to $109.1m. In the light industry area-we remember that the Liberals are supposed to be industry conscious-the assistance received by that industry in 1980-81 amounted to $18.4m. Under the Hawke Government last year it jumped to $123.3m. In 1981-82 the Howard-Fraser Government spent a miserable $25.5m on technology development. If one contrasts that with what the Hawke Government has spent in the last year, one will find that it has almost trebled to $67.8m. The total assistance given to manufacturing industry in 1980-81 by the Howard-Fraser Government was only $138.5m, yet in 1985-86 the Hawke Government spent $466.4m. The honourable member has had the audacity to move an amendment referring to effects on business!

The Liberal and National parties want people to think they have changed, but there is no better test than the test of past performance. The Liberal-National Party Opposition has always been great on promises, but it has certainly been light on performance. It has never been concerned about our international competitiveness. As Treasurer, the Leader of the Opposition knew what had to be done in regard to the dollar, but he kept it overvalued, making manufacturers unable to compete with the imports which flooded in, and wrecked Australian jobs and industries. It was during his reign that so many companies went off-shore. It was when we sent our publishing firms to Hong Kong and Singapore. As in the past-it has not changed now-the Liberal-National Party coalition still sees Australia as an agrarian economy, selling mainly food products and unprocessed minerals. The Hawke Labor Government, on the other hand, has had to pick up the shreds and make the tough decisions to get Australia back on the economic tracks. The Opposition will go to any lengths to try to deny what it has done but, slowly, and surely, the truth is being revealed.

A month ago the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia-the MTIA-known as the national voice of engineering employers, published a booklet entitled `Australia's Foreign Debt-Budget Implications', written by Dr Clive Edwards, MTIA's chief economist. On page 23 it states:

MTIA's task force on industry competitiveness recently pointed out that Australia's manufacturing sector is still conditioned by the traumatic developments of the early 1980s; (by) the large wage and on cost increases, the over valued exchange rate, the severe recession of 1981-82 and 1982-83, all of which led to a reduction in the size and capabilities of the sector, i.e., the manufacturing sector.

Who was in government from 1980 to 1983 when this happened? It was the Liberal and National Country parties. Business leaders must laugh when they now hear the honourable member for Mackellar, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), the honourable member for Bennelong and others making all these pro-business promises, because business leaders know their record-a record of large wage and cost increases, a record of a pittance in assistance to business, a record of over-valued exchange rates and a record of uncompetitiveness in industry. It is also interesting to see what the MTIA publication said in conclusion. It made a number of points and the main one was that to reduce growth in Australia's net foreign debt there had to be a slowing down of growth in government spending and a reduction in public sector or government borrowings. This is exactly what the Hawke Labor Government has done. In real terms, after allowing for inflation the rate of increase in government spending has been held to zero.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a cut.

—It has been held to zero for the first time in something like 30 years, yet the honourable member says that. Government borrowing has been reduced so that more money is available for private sector investment in productive activities that will increase exports and replace imported products with Australian made goods. It would appear that, despite all the pessimism and the prayers almost of the Opposition that things will continue to go bad, many Australian businesses are looking to the future with optimism. (Quorum formed) As I was saying, according to a survey by the Australian Chamber of Manufactures carried out in Victoria-this survey covered 205 companies which account for one in three jobs in manufacturing in that State-a new optimism is appearing and that optimism is being generated by this Hawke Budget. The survey found that there is mounting evidence that improved international competitiveness in manufacturing is beginning to make itself felt. It found many companies were increasing exports and were finding it easier to compete against imports. This is not just because of the devaluation of the dollar but because there is a new attitude, a new approach, better corporate planning, new products and innovative marketing strategies. There is a new confidence that will expand as industry begins to see and grasp the opportunities that now exist under this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this Budget is generating further confidence because, unlike our opponents in the Liberal and National parties, people in every walk of life now realise that the Hawke Labor Government is prepared to put aside short term political popularity for long term national economic advantage and development. This approach sharply contrasts with the Howard-Sinclair attitude. At a time when this country should be stopping the lurks and rorts, at a time when the welfare cake should be shared amongst those who are the needy, not the greedy, at a time when investment should be directed at productivity rather than quick quid schemes, we find this Opposition will do anything and say anything to try to attract votes. It has come forward with a massive program. It wants to abolish the fringe benefits tax and reintroduce entertainment rorts, at a cost of $700m to the ordinary people. The Opposition wants to get rid of the capital gains tax, but at what cost? It would be at a cost of another $5m. The flow-on of the world oil price will cost Australian taxpayers another $400m. The Opposition wants to reinstitute negative gearing, which would add another cost of $50m. It wants to repeal the assets test.

The honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) said earlier how he cared for pensioners. The Opposition wants those on $500,000 to still receive the pension. The Opposition wants to put another burden of $600m on the people of Australia. The honourable member talked about families on two incomes. Income splitting will cost the Australian taxpayer $2.7 billion. Those measures amount to almost $4.5 billion, and they are only part of the Opposition's promises. We must ask: Where will the money come from? If we total all the Opposition's promises to date we find that they amount to something like $11 billion.

The promises are made not only by the Liberal Party. Of all the stupid things to do, a few weeks ago the National Party sent a letter to a man called Dr Doug Everingham of 50 Corberry Street, Rockhampton, asking for money. The National Party did that to a former Labor member of this House. What does the National Party say that it will do? It says that it will do the same sorts of things: It will repeal the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, the assets test-the list goes on and on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I got one too.

—The honourable member got one too. Labor members are receiving letters from the National Party. It is just as much a joke as its promises, because what it is promising simply cannot be delivered. Yet the honourable member for Mackellar says nothing at all about how he would find this money. He spoke here as the shadow Treasurer and what did he say about where he would find this money if he ever got into government? He said not one word. Maybe he had nothing to say because it has already been said for him by the new extremist right movement. Let the people of Australia remember that the Leader of the Opposition says that he stands by these promises. This is the group which says that it will abolish the first home owners scheme. It is the group that the Liberal Party supports and obviously, from the letter of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), the National Party supports-the group that will cut local government grants in half. This year we gave local government $585m; the Opposition would slash that figure in half. This is the group that would abolish family allowances for the first child. This is the group that would totally reintroduce university fees of $8,000 to $9,000 per student. Imagine the number of young people who would not be able to go to university. This is the group that would introduce a tax on the family allowance at the marginal tax rate of the bread winner. It is also the group that says it would remove the half-yearly indexing of age pensions and benefits. However, the honourable member for Sturt has the audacity to say that he and the Liberals are concerned about the family and the aged. What a joke.

SPEECH.PARA: Ladies and gentlemen, members of the Government who have gathered here tonight, let me say that if one had to sum up the Budget in only 100 words one could best take the words out of the introduction of the booklet `A guide to the 1986-87 Commonwealth Budget'; that is to say, the 1986-87 Commonwealth Budget makes a major shift down in government spending and borrowing that will permit Australia to vastly improve its trading performance. The Budget includes a big cut in the Federal deficit, no increases in government spending in real terms, and some increases in tax receipts, offset by income tax cuts as promised in the tax reform package. It also asks Australians to accept smaller pay rises for a while so that we can stay competitive with the rest of the world, lift our export performance, and win back a bigger share of the markets for Australia. The Budget will provide Australia with the opportunity to surmount its economic problems and maintain control over its economic destiny. No wonder the people of Australia are supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to the fevered speech of the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) and in particular to the bit about Dr Everingham being asked for a donation by the National Party of Australia.
—Don't tell me you got a letter too!

—I advise the honourable member to check with Dr Everingham to make sure that he has not made that donation. From my visits to his part of the world-central Queensland and Mount Isa-it seems to me that more people are leaving his Party in disenchantment than are joining it. The honourable member talks about our promises to abolish the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax. If honourable members opposite had an ounce of sense and wanted to stay on that side of the House the first thing they would do would to be to abolish the fringe benefits tax. It is that tax above all which will see honourable members opposite transposed very rapidly, within 18 months, to this side of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget of three weeks ago seems to have caused many more problems for the Government than it has sought to solve. For three weeks we have seen turmoil in the Australian Labor Party as it has torn itself apart, particularly over the issue of uranium mining. Little factions have been meeting here tonight, as they have done for the last three weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they are under control in the north.

—The honourable member was on the news today saying what he was going to do to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). What happened this morning? Nothing. The honour- able member and all the other fellows who were so brave on AM went to water, the same as they went to water last week and the week before that. The other point that must be made about this Budget is that, apart from all the problems it has created for the Labor Party and the Government, it has failed to address the real problems. Within three weeks of the Budget being introduced, the Government has announced that it will introduce a mini-Budget in May. Within three weeks of the annual Budget being brought down, it has been discredited. It is out of date and a new Budget is announced. The Budget has failed to address the problems that are besetting this country. There are no cuts in programs. There are no cuts in government spending. An inflexible labour market still dominates. Our overseas debt continues to rise, inflation is rising, and there is no real encouragement for our exports. On top of all that, the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax that are already in place, as if they were not enough, taxes are to be increased. As a final accolade from the world market, our AAA rating has been reduced to AA1.

SPEECH.PARA: Today the annual report of the Reserve Bank of Australia arrived in my office. If one flicks through it one sees that almost every economic indicator put out and analysed by the Reserve Bank is on a downturn. That is an indication of how the Reserve Bank, the market-place and the rest of the world see this Budget. Let me turn to taxation. The Budget is a high taxing Budget. Few programs have been reduced but taxes have been increased. In regard to personal tax in particular, which has been sapping this country's energy for years and destroying initiative, the great promised tax cuts, which were to have been introduced on 1 September, have been delayed for three months. One begins to wonder whether those tax cuts will ever come. When one looks at the new tax rates whose introduction has been postponed from 1 September to December, one finds that those who earn $12,500 a year, who are currently paying 25c in the dollar, will pay 24c in the dollar under the new scheme. Those people are basically Labor Party supporters. They will be very grateful at the next election because the Government has given them the magnificent benefit of a one cent reduction in their tax! The Government will give those who are earning up to $28,000 a year, who are currently paying 46c in the dollar, a 3c reduction. If the Government thinks it is going to buy their votes with a lousy 3c reduction after all the hoo-ha it has been through in the last three months, it is very much mistaken.

One of the other problems which beset this country is the domination of this Government by the unions. We have heard a lot in the last few weeks about the New Right. I understand the real fears of people who see the New Right as some emergent nazi-type group that is going to become dominant in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support them?

—Let me say to the honourable member that I do not know who the New Right are. I suspect that honourable members opposite do not know who the New Right are, either. They are taking the opportunity to try to create a New Right to divert attention from some of their problems. They are blaming the New Right for all their ills. If members of the New Right are people such as Copeman, if he is one of the people who the Government believes are forming the secret society of the New Right, and if people such as Copeman are taking a stand against restrictive labour practices such as the 284 practices which I understand the management at Robe River objects to, I am very much in support of the New Right. Let me tell honourable members some of the work practices the management there is trying to get rid of. Unions have placed a black ban on supervisors, who cannot give orders to their men. General foremen cannot pass direct instructions to an employee. For trivial reasons the Australian Workers Union has regularly placed bans on the transport of meals. Dust suppression on roads is undertaken by watering and the trucks must be manned even when it is raining.
—Even when it is raining-that is a good one.

—Even when it is raining. There are two men to a truck. Presumably, the trucks go up and down watering wet roads. Dust suppression agents such as oil are not allowed to be used on the roads. When holes had to be drilled nine metres apart instead of seven there was a jack-up by the union. To replace a discharged fire extinguisher after normal hours, someone was called out for four hours on double time. Five employees must be on site for the operation of a rail servicing machine designed to be operated by two people, and so it goes on and on. If the Government is blaming the New Right for trying to get rid of some of those restrictive trade practices, which are holding back this country and making us uncompetitive, let me declare here and now that I fully support them.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism. I would like to make some opening remarks about the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown). What has happened in recent weeks makes interesting reading. During the last autumn session we had the saga of Mr Rodney Groux who was employed by the Minister. God knows where he is now, because the Minister did not know where he was when he was employing him. I presume that he is still under police investigation, but we have heard nothing about that.

The Minister went overseas and got stuck into all the States. He would not say anything to the States while he was in Australia, but while he was overseas he gave the States a good bucketing for carrying out their own promotion of the tourist industry. He speculated on the Budget deficit. Do not tell me that he won that one. He was hauled over the coals by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Minister said `No, I am not really interested in politics' and that he wanted to get out, but then he said that he might stay for a while. So, we do not know what he is going to do. In any event, as far as the industry is concerned, he has become a lame duck. He has been banned in Western Australia. The Western Australians will not give him a bed or a feed over there because they believe that he has done nothing for them. There is a report that his phone is bugged by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. I do not know whether the Minister says that; but, if he has said that and believes that, has he reported that to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen)? He keeps setting up expensive boards and commissions all over the place so that he can put his mates on them. He set up the Australian Institute of Sport, increased the board--

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! I am giving plenty of leeway. I know that this is traditional in an appropriation debate. But this tale is going on for a rather long time. I ask the honourable member to finish it and to relate his comments back to the Bill before the House.

—We are talking about the Budget, we are talking about the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism, and we are talking about the man who is administering that Department. I think that how that particular portfolio is administered, within the context of the Budget, is very important.
—I accept your explanation and I request you to accept my direction.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I will come back to something that I hope you will regard as a bit more pertinent, and that is the expenditure within the portfolio and the setting up of boards and commissions and in particular the expansion within the Department. In March 1983 the Department had five officers of class 2 and above in sport and recreation. In August 1986, three years later, it has 23 officers of class 2 and above. That is an enormous expansion by any standard.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, let me also say that the tourist figures indicate that the tourist industry is in a very strong state in Australia, and for that the Minister deserves a lot of credit. But it does not mean that many of the things that could make that industry better have been addressed. They have not been addressed. I refer in particular to penalty rates. Penalty rates were something that the Minister was going to fix when his Party won government. The Government has given every excuse as to why penalty rates have not been fixed. Penalty rates are still a bugbear of the industry. As honourable members opposite well know, throughout Australia we have first class hotels that literally do not operate on weekends and public holidays because they simply cannot afford the penalty rates associated with the staff when the penalty rates are one and a half, two or two and a half times the normal rates.

The other problem that I very much hope will be addressed is the increasing congestion at our airports. For the life of me I cannot understand why, with the congestion in Darwin and particularly Brisbane, the Government will not accept the offers of the private sector to come in and rebuild or build new international terminals at those airports. The honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) should not shake his head, as it is a fact that a consortium in Brisbane offered to build a new terminal; yet when the proposal was put up it was thrown out of court. The same thing happened in Darwin. If honourable members opposite want to see this industry expand, I would have thought the sensible approach would be to accept the opportunity afforded by the inclusion of the private sector.

On sport let me say just this: All of the promises that the Minister made quite rashly before the Budget came down have been doomed. He promised everyone that programs would go ahead. Unfortunately, they have not gone ahead, because the Budget was cut. For example, the national sports facilities program is now $8m short. We have problems such as the current development in Victoria where money was promised, the proposal went ahead on the basis that the money would be forthcoming, but suddenly it was not to be provided. The same thing has happened in the sports development program.

The market has made its judgment on this Budget. This is the only Government and the only Treasurer to take our credit rating from AAA to AA1. The way the Treasurer prances in here, he looks as though he is proud of it; but the market is not proud of it. The market has made its judgment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Boom times.

—If the honourable member opposite thinks it is just the market that has made that judgment, he ought to go out and talk to some of the people who used to be his supporters and see what they think of the Budget, the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax. There is one thing I will say for the Treasurer: He has done this country a favour because with his intemperate remarks about a banana republic he has brought home to the people of Australia just what a mess this economy is in. The sooner the lot opposite are tossed out and we have some competent economic managers on that side, the sooner we will get out of that mess.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The previous speaker has obviously quoted from the report of the H. R. Nicholls Society which has been distributed amongst members of the National Party, and I ask him to table that report.
—There is no point of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight there are just a few minutes left for me to comment on the Budget and to pay tribute to the great work of our Treasurer, the Hon. Paul Keating, who has made an extraordinary, dedicated contribution to reducing the deficit that was inherited by this Government from the previous discredited Liberal-National Party Government which is now in opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I deal in some depth with the Budget and the debate that is now in progress, I make a few observations on the remarks made by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White). He said that this Government was dominated by the unions. If that is so, how can the Budget clearly set out the fact that since 1982-83 there has been a cumulative fall in real unit labour costs in the non-farm sector of over 7 per cent? That means that, comparing profits and wages, there has been a fall in real unit labour costs. That is something about which very few countries with which we compare ourselves can boast. There is a further one per cent fall forecast in 1986-87.

Yet the honourable member for McPherson and other members of the Opposition make these wild statements that the Government is dominated by the unions. If it is, real unit labour costs should be increasing. We have had talk of restrictive work practices at Robe River. That is all rubbish because if we get rid of the industrial relations system in this country, as the H. R. Nicholls Society and others seek to do, we are getting rid of a system that has given us a 5 per cent cut in earnings. The employees in this nation have accepted a 5 per cent cut in earnings over the last few years to try to get this country out of the economic malaise and economic mess which we inherited. I pay tribute to the employees in this nation.

I also refute some of the nonsense we got from the Opposition about the Budget attacking families. In the contribution by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in this House he said that bulk billing will be abolished except for people such as pensioners who really need it. What about the families with four or five children or a chronically ill child? They will not be bulk billed. The letter the Liberal and National parties sent me seeking funds said that they will cut down the cost of Medicare. If that is introduced, it will hurt the families, because the families of this nation have benefited from Medicare. Medicare was the great reform of the first term of the Labor Government. We introduced a system, which is available to Australians, of free medical and hospital treatment. If those opposite stop families being bulk billed by doctors they will hurt families. People with children should not be penalised. It is all very well for the Liberal Party and the National Party to say: `We will stop bulk billing except for pensioners'. It is very unfair to families. All the gobbledy-gook that we are hearing tonight about hurting families is rubbish.

Some of the compassionate parts of the Budget should be mentioned tonight while we have a few minutes. One concerns aid for diabetics. Many times I have made representations about people suffering from diabetes. The Government will supply free of charge insulin, syringes and all the accoutrements that people with diabetes need. The Government will also assist families in which somebody is chronically ill. When more than 25 prescriptions have been used in a year further preparations under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme will be supplied free of charge. I pay tribute to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) for bringing these matters forward.

The main benefit for families will be the tax cuts coming in later this year. By 1 July 1987 the 60c in the dollar rate of income tax which was left to us by the Opposition-it walked away from this House after the 1983 election leaving the tax rate at 60c in the dollar for the top income earners-will be cut to 49c. The 48c and 46c rates will go down to 40c. There will be other changes in the marginal rates. At the same time, there will be imputation of company tax. That will be the greatest shot in the arm for small companies and small business people. No one will pay tax at a rate of more than 49c in the dollar. This is the greatest reform that has ever been introduced in the Australian tax system. Other Labor governments said they would do it. They promised to tax all the areas of income that were untaxed and to close the loopholes, but they never had the ability to do it.

I pay tribute to the Treasurer. He will go down in history as the man who brought equity and fairness to the Australian tax system. (Quorum formed) It was my hope to speak about the allocation to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. My time is fast slipping away. I pay great tribute to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) for what he has done and what I observed last week when visiting the Gulf of Carpentaria.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Compensation Scheme-New Theatre-Natural Disaster Assistance Loans-Sri Lanka-Commission for the Future-Queensland Government-African Liberation Trust Fund-South West African People's Organisation

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the House to the Government's advanced plans for a national compensation scheme. Honourable members will recall the Whitlam Government's attempt to impose a national compensation scheme on Australia a decade ago. Nothing has changed but the means by which the Australian Labor Party intends to achieve its ultimate objective. The Party's national platform now clearly shows that Labor will develop, in co-operation with the States, a national compensation scheme on a no-fault basis.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposals are already being progressed with the co-operation of the Labor-governed States in Victoria, New South Wales and South Australia. They will have a profound effect on the Australian community. As with Medicare, Labor intends to blanket the whole population with its accident scheme. All injuries resulting from road accidents, industrial accidents, accidents in the home and elsewhere are to be covered on a 24-hour a day basis. Everyone is to be caught in the net-the self-employed, housewives, children, road users and employees.

A national compensation scheme will see the widespread introduction of taxed pensions for accident victims, instead of tax free lump sum payments received at common law. This tax grab is already happening without one word from the Federal Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Budget Speech being necessary. These tax changes are occurring because the Victorian Government nationalised workers compensation last September and created Workcare-a scheme which erodes the common law rights of employees and places the emphasis on weekly payments, which attract income tax rather than tax free, lump sum payments.

The Victorian Government is now proposing to introduce a pure no-fault road accident scheme in January 1987. This will, among other things, further advance the Federal Government's program and require a large number of road accident victims to pay substantial amounts in income tax which would not otherwise be payable. The Victorian ALP's platform, as one might expect, mirrors the Party's Federal platform. It states that a Victorian ALP Government will co-operate with the Australian Government and other States to establish a national compensation scheme.

It is noteworthy that a Bill requiring the nationalisation of workers' compensation in South Australia will be introduced in that State's Upper House within the next few weeks. Again, that legislation will provide for the erosion of common law rights and lead to injured employees paying large sums of tax not previously payable. The New South Wales Government is pointing in the same direction with its workers compensation and road accident systems.

At the appropriate time all of the State schemes will be integrated and expanded. Finally they will emerge as the Federal Government's national compensation scheme. There is another critical aspect of the Federal and State Labor governments' plans for national compensation which gives cause for grave concern. I refer to the propensity of socialist governments to mortgage Australia's future. The Workcare scheme in Victoria is semi-funded and a Melbourne actuary has determined that if the Government maintains premiums at their current level the scheme will be absolutely broke within a few years. The present Victorian road accident scheme is already broke, with accumulated losses at June 1985, according to the State's Auditor-General, of $1.5 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—It will be $1.5 billion. This led to the State's Treasurer announcing in his 1985-86 Budget speech that $30m from petroleum royalties was being pumped into the system to help alleviate the problem. Now the Government is stating in advertisements promoting its new road accident scheme that the program will be partly paid for by increased fines for serious traffic offences.

SPEECH.PARA: The New South Wales road accident scheme has a funding shortfall in excess of $1 billion. We now have evidence aplenty of the growing threats posed by unfunded and semi-unfunded schemes. The Federal Government's proposed national compensation scheme falls clearly in this category.

The Executive Director of the Institute for Contemporary Studies in the United States of America put the whole matter into perspective in his paper `Around The World Social Security Goes Broke'. He said that funding problems promise to become political crises early in the twenty-first century and that policy makers think the problem can be left for someone else to solve. But the longer they wait the more painful must be the cure. It should therefore be evident that the national compensation scheme proposed by the Federal Government will not provide a cure; rather it will perpetuate and extend a problem this nation's taxpayers can ill afford.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Parliament is often likened to the theatre-men and women strutting the stage delivering their well-learned lines and attempting to convey their views and philosophies on the great issues of the day. Tonight I wish to talk about an actual theatre which for over 50 years had dedicated itself to more political issues of the day than perhaps addressed by any particular member of this House. On 11 August, New Theatre at Melbourne completed half a century of political theatre, making it the longest continuously running theatre company in Victoria. During that time, while maintaining four or five plays each year over five decades, New Theatre remained constant, like the Northern Star, to its charter of presenting theatre with a purpose, designed to politicise its audiences on social injustices of the day. The philosophy behind New Theatre has always been left of centre, bonded to the causes of working men and women, the oppressed and the minorities. Its credo has always been that theatre can be a force for social change. Inevitably, right from the beginning the theatre has been at odds with the ruling parties and classes, whose rationale has been to preserve the status quo by ensuring that ordinary people remain powerless to bring about reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: New Theatre encountered the wrath of the establishment as early as its second production, Till the Day I Die, in late 1936, when the anti-nazi one-act play was banned following a protest from Hitler's Consul-General to the Federal Government. Incidentally, the play was performed but the ban was not lifted until well into the war. In 1948, the theatre presented the plight of the Aborigines with productions of Fountains Beyond, a story of Aboriginal communities struggling to survive on the fringes of white settlements, and Rocket Range, about the establishment of rocket testing grounds on Aboriginal lands. This second play, which indicated the white bosses' total ignorance of Aboriginal ways, was tossed out of a drama festival because of its strong criticism of white society. New Theatre's most outstanding success was probably Reedy River, which was first presented in 1953. It brought together about 10 traditional bush songs, which were linked by a story about the shearers' strike of 1891. Music was provided by a bush band and the whole show made theatrical and folk music history. The theatre has produced this all-Australian show on no fewer than six occasions over extensive seasons.

I joined New Theatre during the 1966 performance and stayed to tread the boards in The Wall, a play about an uprising in the Warsaw ghetto, MacBird, a Shakespearian satire on the Kennedy assassination, The Death of Bessie Smith, the tragic story of the famous American Negro jazz singer who died from loss of blood when she was refused admission to several white hospitals, and On Stage Vietnam, a living newspaper-style play which opposed Australia's involvement in that immoral and unwinnable war. In 1967, its performance of America Hurrah generated an incredible amount of debate in the media on censorship when it challenged Victoria's obscenity laws. The issue became a cause celebre, hastening the introduction of more sensible censorship laws. Last year it produced Sandinista, a dramatic history of the Nicaraguan revolution, and this year, Athol Fugard's Statements, a semi-documentary of a relationship between a white librarian and a coloured teacher in South Africa.

This list is hardly exhaustive but it illustrates the great contribution made by New Theatre to politics and the arts. The theatre has been closely associated with many of Australia's leading writers, including Vance and Nettie Palmer, Frank Dalby Davidson, Miles Franklin, Oriel Gray and Frank Hardy. It has provided opportunities for budding playwrights, directors and actors, especially those who would not have found a venue because of the political nature of the performances. New Theatre has, in fact, premiered 63 Australian plays and was first in Australia with Brecht, Miller, O'Casey, Milligan and Dario Fo. What has kept New Theatre going? It cannot be the money. It works from show to show, its members are working people, its productions are inexpensive and its publicity is noted for its absence of gaudy tinsel. It is the people and their message which has kept them going and I compliment them all, past present and future.

Nettie Palmer once said: `How do you assess a play? By what the play says and how it says it'. We might well ask: `How do you assess a parliament? By what the Parliament says and how it says it'. Many of New Theatre's issues which I have outlined this evening are still very much current. Parliament, too, must remain a force for social change, not simply a talkshop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this adjournment debate I want to refer to a question that was asked earlier today by the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) and the answer that was given by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). The question was asked by someone whom we regard as a rejected member of the Queensland State House and the answer was given by a Minister who wasted the time of the House with a fairly shoddy personal attack on a Queensland grazing family and a Queensland Minister of the Crown. It was shoddy because both the question and the answer came from this coward's castle where no opportunity of response is given to the person being attacked.
—It was a dorothy dixer.

—Yes, it was a dorothy dixer too. It was a wasted question because earlier in the day the Queensland Minister, Mr Neil Turner, responded in the Queensland Parliament to a question that had been asked by the State Opposition Leader on this subject last week. It was answered in such a way that the Labor Party and the Leader Opposition did not ask a supplementary question, to which they were entitled, and the whole thing fell rather flat because no further explanation was required.

SPEECH.PARA: For cheap political purposes the Minister for Primary Industry, for whom I have a fair regard, allowed himself to be used and reduced himself to gutter tactics against a person in Queensland who could not defend himself. This episode reveals two things. First, the Minister obviously has no understanding of or empathy with the man in question, who is trying to survive on the land. He does not understand the great problems that are occasioned after a four-year drought of forced sales and stock deaths, or the impact of the Government's-his Government's-interest rates of 20 per cent or better on those who live or try to live off the land. In fact, he had time to quip about the use of the term `national disaster'. I can assure him that those who live in the drought country find that it is no laughing matter to have this issue treated so lightly. Secondly, it brings to question the professionalism of a senior public servant in Queensland in making this information available, together with personal and financial details of a bank client, which a customer would consider should be confidential and secure. I understand that there are police investigations under way into the activities of the public servant who is believed to have leaked the information.

The facts of this case are very interesting. The Assistant General Manager of the Queensland Agricultural Bank twice recommended the loan to the Behan family to the Board. On the second occasion, he said that the one difference between the two applications, both of which he recommended, was that the possibility of actual viability was better documented and, in the case of natural disaster funds, the purpose for which funds were sought came within its general guidelines.

The Minister made great play of the fact that the bank, or the banker of the person in question and the pastoral house, had refused to fund the reconstruction. Perhaps the Minister does not know that under his own guidelines such refusal by the bank and the pastoral house is the first step in applying for natural disaster funds. In fact, after the case the bank has ceded $60,000 of its first security to the Agricultural Bank and the pastoral house has lent further funds in addition. The $160,000-as I understand it, the amount of the loan-was for $60,000 carry-on funds, which is quite normal, $40,000 to restock after the disaster of the drought and $60,000 for reconstruction. The loan was not a one-off operation by the Agricultural Bank. I understand that since March 1986 12 loans have been approved under normal lending procedures, ranging from $200,000 to $820,000. Seven loans have also been made available from natural disaster assistance, ranging from $170,000 to $500,000, all in excess of the amount lent to the Behan family.

I am concerned about the Minister's allegation of corruption based in this case on absolutely incorrect leaked material. I will reject that charge where the allegation is made on that flimsy type of material. It is based on the fact that the Minister had no real experience, knowledge, or feeling for the families, the men and women, on the land. I challenge the Minister to go out to some of these forgotten places, to the areas in the central and north-west Queensland where Mr Behan's property is and the local shire is still drought declared. This area has been drought stricken for the past four years with the exception of only 10 months. I challenge him to go out and see what it is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Friday, 12 September, most of Australia's major newspapers carried a report from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) that some one million rounds of ammunition were stolen from an Australian factory and shipped to Tamil terrorists in Sri Lanka. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in answer to a question from the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) today dealt with the absurdity of this claim. I suggest that there was another reason for the claim being made last Friday. On Thursday, a document was released by Amnesty International documenting the disappearance of 272 Tamil people from Sri Lanka. The report also documents the abuse of human rights, the use of torture and killings, by the forces of the Sri Lankan Government. It was just too convenient for the Leader of the National Party to release his story the morning after the Amnesty International report was released and thus deny this report the coverage it deserved.

SPEECH.PARA: The Sri Lankan High Commission received a copy of the report a few days before it was publicly released. There was also a meeting between the High Commission in Canberra and officials from Amnesty International about the report. The High Commission knew when the report was to be released and the publicity it would gain. I suggest that the reports about the missing ammunition were an attempt to divert attention from the contents of the Amnesty International report. I am most surprised that after the one-day wonder of the Leader of the National Party's report the Amnesty International report has received no publicity in the Australian media.

We know from the reply today by the Minister for Defence that after the Press conference last week by the Leader of the National Party to announce his startling revelation, the representative of a Canberra lobby group, Carney, Hocking and Associates, was telephoning journalists advising them to telephone the Sri Lankan High Commission for confirmation of the story. That group is headed by Mr Carney, formerly on the staff of the Leader of the National Party. So now we know who the reliable source was who supplied the information to him. The plot thickens when we learn that this group has a public relations account with Air Lanka, and obviously close connections with the Sri Lankan High Commission here in Canberra. Despite the best efforts of the Leader of the National Party to divert attention from this report, I urge all honourable members to obtain a copy of the Amnesty International report entitled `Sri Lanka-Disappearances'. It will enable them to better understand the plight of the Tamil people, which I raise in this House from time to time.

It is a very delicate time in Sri Lanka with negotiations for a peace settlement going on, a peace settlement that all who have an interest in that country hope will come to fruition. At this delicate time I have no intention or desire to criticise the Sri Lankan Government or its representatives here in Canberra, but I must say that this report from Amnesty International goes beyond the politics currently occurring in Sri Lanka. The report documents disappearances, torture and killings. I think it is incumbent upon the authorities from Sri Lanka to answer the very serious charges raised in this document. All members of the Parliament would do well to obtain a copy of the report from Amnesty International and study it carefully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst pensioners and the aged are asked to tighten their belts, the Government has in this most recent Budget increased expenditure on some of its pet projects. Although I will not be referring to very large amounts of money relative to a Budget of $60 or $70 billion, I can assure you, Madam Speaker, that to a pensioner who is out of pocket $80 or thereabouts as a result of the deferral of pension increases, the amounts of money I will talk about tonight are pretty significant.

SPEECH.PARA: As a preliminary I make two points. First, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has announced that we will abolish the Commission for the Future, and that is a commitment I am very pleased to support. Secondly, the comments I want to make tonight are no reflection on the two journalists whose names I will raise. I will give the House some figures. The Commission for the Future has had its funds increased this year by 50 per cent. It is no wonder that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), has been going around the country, three weeks after the Budget was brought down, saying it is not good enough because it did not cut hard enough on the expenditure side. The third most senior member of the Government has already crippled the Government's Budget. So there is a 50 per cent increase in funding for the Commission for the Future, and a 10 to 15 per cent increase in consultants' fees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they fortune tellers?

—Yes, fortune tellers, as they are properly described by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Some time ago I asked for a list of consultants who had received funding in the 1985-86 year. On the basis of the papers provided to me under the Freedom of Information Act, in 1985-86 the Commission engaged consultants to the value of $146,293. The projects included the production of an annotated bibliography partly entitled `A Select Bibliography', which cost $5,200 and which one would have to say was select in every sense of the word. Another journalist prepared a written report on education futures that was so good the Commission paid $2,500 for it. In fact, if he had written the same article in the Melbourne Age, for which he writes, we could all have had it for 40c, which would have been quite a bargain. I suppose one might ask what these people know about the future. Quite frankly, I do not really know what more these journalists know about the future than anybody in this chamber, although one of the journalists engaged was once a weather man with one of the television stations. I suppose he at least has had some experience in predicting the future. I thought the House would be interested in some of these contracts. After I got the list of consultants I lodged a further application under the Freedom of Information Act for details of the consultancies.
—Was the Government helpful?

—In fact, I had to lodge an appeal because I did not get the documents within the time prescribed by law, which gives the House an indication of the Government's real attitude to freedom of information. The documents were here when I arrived in Canberra today, so I have had a chance to have a quick look through them. The contract with Kenneth Davidson, who writes for the Age, is interesting. The contract is dated 6 August 1986 and states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Consultant shall provide to the Commonwealth a written report . . . covering the issues for the future and education that arose from the conference . . .

What does a consultant have to do for his $2,500? He has to attend three briefing sessions-I suppose that is something-and then he has to `synthesise the input'. If we could define what `synthesise the input' meant we would all be well advanced. The report was to be 6,000 words in length and Kenneth Davidson was to get about $350 per thousand words. If that is of some interest, Mr Charles Wright of Coldstream, to whom I have spoken and who I must say seems a very reasonable person, has done considerably better. He is getting $500 for every thousand words. That is 50c a word. His obligations are set out in an agreement of 13 August which I thought was pretty instructive. The first requirement was for him to attend the seminar. I would have thought that was the least he could do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
—I wish to speak to the House and to the people of Australia, particularly the people of Queensland, about the fraud and deceit of the National Party Government--
—Careful.

—I will be careful about it. I refer to the National Party Government of Queensland. Earlier this evening the honourable member for Dawson tried to sweep under the carpet the unfortunate loan of $145,000, most of which was Commonwealth money, to someone who we now understand is one of the directors of the National Party in north Queensland. —What about the Auditor-General?
—The Auditor-General-the honourable member would not even be able to spell it.
—On a point of order, Madam Speaker--
—Would you ask him to spell it, Madam Speaker?
—Madam Speaker, I find the comment by the honourable member for Leichhardt offensive and I ask for it to be withdrawn forthwith.
