—And he still is not able to spell it, Madam Speaker. But when one comes from the simpleton area of southern Queensland, it is an unfortunate fact-
—On a further point of order, Madam Speaker--
—Ask him to spell `simpleton', Madam Speaker.
—Order! Some time ago the House gave to the Chair the right to decide whether a matter was unparliamentary. The matter is not unparliamentary, and the honourable member will resume his seat.
—Madam Speaker, I ask that I be heard on the subsequent point of order. I find the later comments of the honourable member for Leichhardt offensive and I ask that they be withdrawn.
—The honourable member will withdraw the later comment.
—I withdraw, Madam Speaker. I suppose that `simpleton' is a word that we could spell amongst us-
—Order! The honourable member will continue with his speech.
—Have a go.
—The honourable member for Menzies--
—Order! Will the honourable member for Leichhardt stick to the point and ignore the interjections.

—Thank you, Madam Speaker. What is happening in Queensland is despicable and the people of Queensland will show that they despise it in their voting habits in the very near future. Those who have raised objection here this evening will have to go out and sell what is happening to the people in their electorate. The matter is quite simple. Nationals are chasing 36 per cent of the people. Unfortunately, they will not get 36 per cent of the people--
—We will get 50 per cent.
—Order! The honourable member will ignore the interjection.

—We need not worry about 50 per cent. In conclusion, I say that it behoves me to stand here to appeal to the people of Queensland not to accept what is being put forward in the form of space centres in far north Queensland--
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not dwell on the disgraceful and inaccurate comments of the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) other than to say that his comments were nothing compared with the deception perpetrated by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in respect of the national economy, which eventually led him to admit the error of his ways when he uttered those famous words about a banana republic. I too would like to refer to Queensland as it has been mentioned here tonight. I point out that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) weighed into Queensland and made an atrocious attack on the Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. It has backfired and it will be shown how much it has backfired on polling day. It follows the attack made by Prime Minister Whitlam in the early 1970s, when he referred to Sir Joh as a `bible bashing bastard'. That also backfired, and Hawke's attack falls into the same category. It all arose over allegations in respect of terrorism. I think it is time that we started to look at the facts in terms of the support of various honourable members and the Federal Government for certain organisations. In proof of certain aspects of this, I bring forward a letter dated 3 February 1984, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Colleague
We understand that you have recently received a request for assistance from the African Liberation Trust Fund.

We appreciate that you receive many such requests for aid because it is widely understood that the unions are key supporters of the struggle for human rights and liberation from oppression. But we would ask you to give a very full consideration to the appeal for financial support for the African Liberation Trust Fund. With the struggle in southern Africa moving towards a climax our support can help reduce the length and intensity of the conflict.

The Federal Government has given its blessing to the establishment of an Information Office for the African National Congress and SWAPO. It remains for us to provide the support that will sustain this office and make it effective.

It is signed, `Yours sincerely, Dr Neal Blewett, Minister for Health; Greg Crafter, Minister for Community Welfare and Aboriginal Affairs of South Australia; and John Scott, MP, member for Hindmarsh'. They are the three signatories to this letter, which shows clearly that these members of parliament and a Minister of the Federal Government, then and now, appealed for support for the African National Congress, the South West African People's Organisation and the African Liberation Trust Fund.

Furthermore, I submit to the House that involved in this is a very nasty conspiracy, because it is clear from the first paragraph of this letter that it was designed to be a nicely timed follow-up to the original letter seeking donations. Therefore, it was done on a highly organised basis involving the complicity of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott), and the Minister of the South Australian Parliament. They ought to be ashamed of their action in relation to this matter. This communication completely vindicates the comments made last week by the Premier of Queensland in respect of this issue.

The support of the Federal Minister for Health in this matter is disappointing. He has signed the letter particularly as Minister for Health, and the letter refers to the Federal Government and the need to sustain support for the ANC and SWAPO. Of course, we all know the sort of terrorist action in which SWAPO is involved in South Africa. Obviously the Prime Minister was trying to camouflage the real position in respect of the economy-what the Government is doing in relation to the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the cutbacks being perpetrated on war widows-by his action in Queensland last week. The attack of the Prime Minister on the Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, will clearly backfire.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), who has just sat down, for advising me that he was going to raise this garbage in the House tonight. I raised this matter in the House on 25 March 1985. It is recorded at page 858 of Hansard. I am quite happy to repeat what I said because I think it is very telling on the difference between the two groups here-the Government and the Opposition. I said at that time:

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to advise this House of the fine work being carried out in Australia by such organisations as the Campaign Against Racial Exploitation. The driving force is Jim and Irene Gale, two wonderfully dedicated people.

I interpose that, unfortunately, Australia is the sadder because of the passing of Jim Gale. But I am glad to say that the Government, in its sponsorship of peace awards, saw fit to find that Jim Gale in his dedication to the peoples of Africa in particular was a person worthy of being awarded posthumously a peace award. His work continues. I am extremely proud to have been associated with him and his wife at that time. I will continue to work with my colleague the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) in trying to do something for the oppressed people of South Africa. I went on to say at that time:
There is also the work of Eddie Funde, the representative of the African National Congress. I try to assist as a trustee of the African Liberation Trust Fund.
I point out that that is shown in my personal details that were tabled in the House not so long ago; so there is nothing sinister or mysterious about my involvement. I went on:

I commend the Minister for Foreign Affairs on his statement. I congratulate the Opposition shadow Minister for his support. I would be delighted to see more of my colleagues support the Campaign Against Racial Exploitation and the African Liberation Trust Fund.
The reason I mentioned the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and the shadow Minister at the time was that earlier in the speech I had said:

In the period available to me I would like to address some specific matters of great concern to Australia's standing as a nation in today's world. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) has recently in this House condemned the outrageous killing of black people in South Africa on 21 March this year. Similar killings at Sharpeville were carried out by the South African Government 25 years to the day before these recent killings. The Minister, speaking on behalf of this Labor Government, reaffirmed the Government's total opposition to the injustice and inhumanity of apartheid. The shadow Minister, the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), wholeheartedly endorsed this Government's statement. I applaud the shadow Minister for his stand. I hope he can hold that line.

I want briefly to say that the letter referred to did have wide circulation. I think there must have been a bit of a mix-up in the mail because one of the recipients was a fellow by the name of Bruce Ruxton of the Returned Services League of Australia. Something must have happened with the mail because the letter to Mr Ruxton somehow got lost and it was only in the last six weeks that he received the letter. I presume he received it only then. He had the kindness to reply to me and express his views about organisations such as the South West Africa People's Organisation and the African National Congress. I responded and said that I was pleased to receive his reply. I reminded him of his recent tour of the Soviet Union and his very complimentary remarks about the Soviet system. Those remarks appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald. I would be more than delighted at the right time to table that letter to Bruce Ruxton and his subsequent reply, because I think it is with that kind of dialogue, without the hysteria that one gets from Queensland Premiers who are senile, that one gets a proper appreciation of the issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do intend to speak on a matter relating to my electorate. However, I have just been advised of a letter dated 12 September 1986 from the South West Africa People's Organisation to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) seeking assistance from the Government. The letter, referring to support required, states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The first concerns our need for help in training Namibians in preparation for their role in a future independent Namibia.

This dispels any suggestion that SWAPO is not a terrorist organisation. The honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott), who spoke a moment ago, stands condemned as a person who supports terrorism, along with other members of the Australian Labor Party. I fully support what the Queensland Premier has said and the people of Australia will no doubt condemn the ALP for its weak-kneed approach to terrorism in this country. We have the Palestine Liberation Organisation, SWAPO and other organisations which are operating under the auspices of this Government.

I now wish to refer to a problem experienced by a bus company in my electorate, Kangaroo Bus Lines, which in February 1985 received a letter of demand, a log of claims and working conditions, from the Transport Workers Union of Australia, the leadership of which in many cases comprises industrial thugs. The conditions that were asked of the company were ridiculous to say the least. Among other things the unions demanded a minimum of $1,500 a week for all employees, a minimum of $100 a week in addition to all other payments as extra payment, and a rest pause of 30 minutes for each hour worked. The reply from Kangaroo Bus Lines stated:

Having read the enclosed claim, I find it hard to believe that any organisation could expect a privately owned bus operation to remain in business if it had to meet the conditions as stated in your letter of demand.
If these conditions were forced upon us, we would have no alternative but to close down our operations and stand down all employees.

The letter concluded in effectly informing the TWU that the bus company was not interested in being covered under a Federal award, and the company mistakenly assumed that this was the end of the matter. In May of this year a staff member of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations approached the company to inspect its business operations. Since it was established the business has operated on the understanding that it was covered by a State award; but, unfortunately, according to the inspector the business somehow had become subject to a Federal award. How could this happen in a democratic society? Quite simply, the union concerned managed to include the business in a Federal award through a tactic known as setting up a roping in dispute. The Department of Employment and Industrial Relations explained in its letter to me of 25 June:

Federal awards apply only to actual parties to the dispute in settlement of which the award concerned was made. Federal industrial tribunals ordinarily have no power to add new respondents to an award by variation.

Where it is desired to extend the scope of an existing award to new respondents, it is necessary first to create a new dispute or disputes with such employers on the subject matters involved in the existing award. Such a dispute is known as a roping in dispute and the award made in settlement is known as a roping in award.

This ridiculous log of claims that no company could hope to implement effectively placed Kangaroo Bus Lines in dispute with the TWU. Kangaroo Bus Lines did not hear again from any industrial tribunal. It did not hear again from the union and it thought that was the end of the matter. But an inspector came from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. I was advised that Kangaroo Bus Lines had been roped into a Federal award and that come hell or high water there was nothing that Kangaroo Bus Lines could do about it except to apply for a variation of the award to exclude it from the award.

I am certain that the people of Australia would agree with me that it is criminal that a union could drag in a business in this way without previously advising it that the matter was coming before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, resulting in the company being bound by a Federal award. That is a ridiculous example of excessive union power. Not only did the employees of Kangaroo Bus Lines not wish to be included in the Federal award, but it also was in their best interest not to be so included. They now face the prospect of losing their jobs because of the onerous conditions of the Federal award which Kangaroo Bus Lines is not able to afford.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
—I require the debate to be extended.
—The debate may continue until 11.10 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few remarks in response to the remarks made earlier this evening by the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). I say first of all that I am particularly disappointed that the honourable member, for whom I have had considerable respect, should join the Premier of Queensland in idiocies and simplifications concerning the very difficult issue in South Africa. I have for a long time been sympathetic to the black majority in South Africa and their struggle for rights which all of us in this society claim and have. I have followed their struggle. Indeed, I suggest that the honourable member for Farrer should examine much more deeply the problem in southern Africa before he makes the kinds of comments to which he lent himself tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: Having long had this attitude, I must say that, when I was in South Africa in 1980 and visited Soweto and saw the contrast between the living conditions in Soweto and those in much of white Johannesburg, I found it understandable that that society has enormous internal tensions and problems. It is no good simply talking about terrorism without understanding the deep problems of that society. But honourable members do not have to believe me on this issue. I refer to the following quotation:

There is no peaceful legal means in which black people in South Africa can seek to exercise political pressure on the Government because all the legal means of exercising political pressure that we know in a country like Australia, have been successively denied to black South Africans. So, they can't do anything legally to try and make their point known.

If I was living without any political rights of any kind, and if over forty years I and my parents had not been able to achieve any political rights, and if I was living in the state in which people were in South Africa, then I would say if people would not respond to normal political pressure then ultimately you can't blame them if they pick up arms.

Those remarks, of course, were made by the ex-Liberal Prime Minister of this country. Again, he is someone who has been prepared to study and understand the problems in southern Africa. So when a group of Australians whom I very much respect, including my colleague the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott), Cliff Dolan, Professor Manning Clark, Don Dunstan, and the Bishop of Newcastle asked me to join in a trust fund to raise money simply in order to fund the personnel in an information office in this country for the African National Congress and the South West Africa People's Organisation, I was happy and honoured to take part. I point out that the whole purpose of this fund has simply been to fund and provide support for the personnel of that office so that their point of view-the point of view of the black majority in South Africa-can be presented in that country. They do not have the resources that the Government of South Africa has.

It is important to consider this when one listens to the honourable member for Farrer-an honourable member for whom, as I say, I have considerable respect-make his simplistic statements. One expects nothing better from the Premier of Queensland, but one does expect better from the honourable member for Farrer. One would hope that he would make the effort to listen to the arguments that the people are presenting through the information office of the ANC and SWAPO. I welcome this debate, because one of the chief benefits of Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen's utterances has been to arouse interest in this trust fund. I hope that this debate will do the same.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his predecessor's answer to question No. 4701 (Hansard, 10 and 11 November 1982, page 3052), can he say what was the outcome of discussions between the former Treasurer and the Commissioner of Taxation in relation to the need for additional Boards of Review.
(2) Does the Government intend to increase the number of Boards of Review.

(3) What consideration has been given to the matters raised in parts (12) and (13) of the question, that (a) lawyers with experience in tax matters be appointed to preside as appeal officers or one-person tribunals to hear tax matters involving disputes of lesser sums (e.g. under $5000) as operated in the United Kingdom, (b) there be no automatic right of appeal from these tribunals, with appeals only arising with the leave of either a review Board or the Court and (c) the fee for an appeal to this tribunal be low (e.g. $10), but the fee for appeals to the Boards of Review be increased markedly from the present sum of $2.
(4) Will the Government take action on these proposals; if so, what action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)-(4) The Government's policy regarding the administrative review of decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation on objections against taxation assessments and other decisions of the Commissioner is reflected in the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Act 1986 which was passed by the Parliament during the 1986 Autumn Sittings. That Act transferred the jurisdiction of the Taxation Boards of Review to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal with effect from 1 July 1986.

As announced in the 1986-87 Budget a filing fee of $200 for taxation and other applications to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is to be introduced. The fee will be reimbursed where the application is successful.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Do limitations on the Australian Taxation Office's (ATO) powers to investigate and obtain documentary evidence result in a lack of efficiency in the ATO's response to the challenges of organised and sophisticated tax fraud; if so, will he take steps to enact legislation strengthening the ATO's powers by bringing it into line with the provisions of section 545 of the Companies code.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commissioner of Taxation advises that the information gathering powers contained in taxation legislation are used extensively by taxation investigators. Instances do occur, of course, where an investigation is protracted because the Commissioner's powers are contested. Generally, however, these powers are effective in achieving their purpose.
Fraudulent matters of the type that the honourable member mentions are often referred to the Australian Federal Police who may obtain a search warrant issued under the provisions of the Crimes Act.

The existing power of access to books, etc. that is provided by taxation legislation is similar to that provided by section 545 of the Companies Act. In terms of increased efficiency in investigating tax fraud, little could be gained from bringing the taxation provisions into line with the company law provisions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the ease with which international money movements can be effected cause considerable difficulties for law enforcement and tax authorities.

(2) Is it a fact that to avoid detection and prosecution, criminals regularly put an `overseas loop' into the financing of their operations or the division of the proceeds of their crimes into their banking transactions.

(3) Is it a fact that one of the foreign banks granted a licence to operate in Australia obtained a court order preventing the Australian authorities gaining access to banking records in Vanuatu; if so, did he or his Department have any discussions with the foreign banks with a view to obtaining the co-operation of foreign banks licensed in Australia in providing information to Australian authorities when required.

(4) Does he propose to make it a condition for the conduct of business in Australia by both overseas and Australian-based banks that those banks direct their overseas operations to co-operate with Australian enforcement authorities investigating criminal conduct.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Several Royal Commissioners and Special Prosecutors have uncovered instances of criminals using domestic and international financial arrangements for the purposes of financing their operations, or transmitting the proceeds of their criminal activities, in ways designed to frustrate law enforcement and taxation authorities. I am aware that an `overseas loop' may be introduced in order to increase the difficulty of tracing a transaction.

Insofar as the protection of taxation revenue is concerned, the Government has in place, under the current foreign exchange arrangements, a system for screening a broad range of transactions involving the outward remittance of funds from Australia. These taxation screening requirements form part of the conditions under which the foreign exchange dealers and the public have been authorised by the Reserve Bank to enter into specified foreign currency transactions.

I would also mention that a factor bearing on the broader issue to which the honourable member alludes is the availability of, and access to, adequate documentation underlying international monetary transactions originating in Australia. These are matters that the Government is currently considering in various contexts, including in terms of formulating its response to the recommendations in this area of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union.

(3) As indicated in the 1983-84 Annual Report of Special Prosecuter Redlich, one of 16 foreign banks invited to establish operations in Australia did obtain a court order in Vanuatu preventing his office gaining access to banking records in that country. The legal proceedings to which the honourable member has referred took place in the Vanuatuan Supreme Court.

The ability of Australian authorities to access banking records in another country is, of course, dependent on the law in that country. The question of improving the access of Australian enforcement agencies investigating criminal conduct to overseas banking records is a matter that is most appropriately pursued through improving mutual assistance arrangements for criminal investigation between Australia and other countries (see (4)). This issue has not, therefore, been raised with the foreign banks that have established or are in the process of establishing operations in Australia. The new bank entrants have, however, been placed on the same operational footing as existing domestically owned banks as regards their obligations and responsibilities under relevant Commonwealth and State laws, including in regard to the provision of information.

(4) As I mentioned in respect of (1), the Government has under consideration a range of matters bearing on the issues raised by the honourable member. I would also note that the Government is currently engaged in consultations with foreign governments and other overseas bodies with a view to facilitating access for law enforcement purposes to financial records held outside Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does electronic funds transfer technology cause problems for the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) in the investigation of financial transactions evidencing major fraud on the ATO (a) currently or (b) in the foreseeable future; if so, what are the details.
(2) What proposals does (a) the ATO or (b) his Department have to deal with the transitory and far-flung nature of the records of financial dealings handled by electronic funds transfer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The ATO is not currently experiencing problems caused by electronic fund transfer technology, nor does it envisage problems in the foreseeable future. The ATO has to date found adequate audit trails in cases involving electronic fund transfers.

(2) In view of the above, neither the Australian Taxation Office nor my Department have under consideration any proposals specific to the matter the honourable member has raised. The Government does, however, have under consideration a range of measures which would assist taxation and other investigators in uncovering money transfers through the financial system, irrespective of whether those transfers are effected by electronic or other means. These include the Australia Card proposal (and the associated requirement that it be used to identify owners and operators within the financial system).

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Mr Ray Lord: Fringe Benefits Tax

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report on page 22 of the Financial Review of 12 November 1985, stating that the Managing Director of Smith and Lane Holdings, Mr Ray Lord, has received a $488,264 home loan at a 2% interest rate from Direct Acceptance Corporation, a subsidiary of Smith and Lane Holdings.
(2) Is such a benefit taxable or will it be taxable under proposed taxation changes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The question concerns the personal affairs of a particular taxpayer and is one that ultimately has to be determined by the Commissioner of Taxation. For that reason and because of the secrecy provisions of the relevant tax law, the matter is not one on which I am able to specifically comment.

In general terms, however, under the fringe benefits tax legislation which applies from 1 July 1986, a separate tax is imposed on employers in respect of the taxable value of non-cash fringe benefits including free or low interest loans provided to employees (or associates). The taxable value of a free or low interest loan will generally be equal to the difference between the interest accruing at a benchmark interest rate and interest accruing at the actual interest rate, if any, charged on the loan. The benchmark rate will generally be the lowest rate charged for arm's-length housing loans by the Commonwealth Bank immediately prior to the commencement of the relevant tax year. A maximum benchmark rate of 13.5% applies, however, for housing loans made to employees before 3 April 1986.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to my question No. 1860 relating to the limitations on the Australian Taxation Office's (ATO) powers to investigate and obtain documentary evidence, will he take steps to introduce legislation strengthening the ATO's powers by bringing it into line with the provisions of section 203 of the Customs Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: As I said in answer to question No. 1860, the Commissioner of Taxation has advised that generally the information gathering powers contained in taxation legislation are effective in achieving their purpose.

I note that section 203 of the Customs Act mentioned in the honourable member's question permits certain authorised persons to seize certain goods in respect of which breaches of the Customs Act have occurred. I would not see it as necessary that a similar provision be included in taxation legislation. Where questions of search or seizure arise, the Commissioner will ordinarily have recourse to special provisions found in the Crimes Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Tritium (3H) present in stormwater drainage at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission (AAEC) establishment at Lucas Heights, NSW.

(2) If so, (a) what is the approximate location of the stormwater drains in which the Tritium is found in relation to building 57, (b) is the dispersal of the Tritium controlled, (c) does the contaminated water pass into the Woronora River and through residential areas, (d) what measures have been taken to locate the source of the leaked Tritium, (e) is any nuclear waste stored or buried near to the leak, (f) what activities have taken place in building 57, (g) could the Tritium present in any stormwater drains be caused by water passing through buried or storm waste, (h) has the source of the Tritium been traced, (i) what action has the AAEC taken to make public the existence of the leak, (j) what action has been taken to make State authorities aware of the problem, (k) is the Tritium from this leak taken into account when assessing overall discharges of Tritium from the site, in the Authorisation Agreement with the NSW Government.

(3) Does the AAEC Safety Review Committee Report 31, 1983 state that Tritium was present in stormwater drainage below building 57 at the AAEC establishment at Lucas Heights and that this fact had been known for a decade.
(4) Does the Safety Review Committee recognise expressly in its Report No. 31 the adverse political and public reaction to the knowledge of such an uncontrolled dispersal of radionuclide.
(5) Was this concern about political and public reaction a contributing, if not determining factor, in the existence of the leak not being made public.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Small amounts of tritium have been detected in stormwater drainage from the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories (LHRL) from time to time, coming from several different sources which have been progressively eliminated as they have been identified. Measurable amounts of tritium were last detected in stormwater samples taken in June and between August and October 1985. Since then the level of tritium has decreased to near the limit of detection which is about one three-hundredth of the permissible level in drinking water, as derived from the recommendations of the International Commission on Radiological Protection.

(2) (a) The tritium detected in stormwater last year was in drainage associated with the HIFAR complex, at some distance from Building 57, and from the stormwater drainage system which includes drainage from Building 57.

(b) At the time that measurable amounts of tritium were detected in stormwater samples, the dispersal of tritium was not controlled. However these discharges have now been controlled by diverting them to the AAEC effluent treatment plant.

(c) Stormwater containing small amounts of tritium has flowed into the Woronora River but the level of dilution is so great that tritium has not been detected in water samples taken from the Woronora River where it passes through residential areas. Where minute amounts of tritium associated with the HIFAR complex have been detected in stormwater drainage, this has mostly been in stormwater flowing to Barden Creek.

(d) The tritium detected in stormwater drainage associated with the HIFAR complex was initially thought to come from authorised airborne discharges precipitated by rainfall. It has subsequently been established that condensate from a large airconditioning unit in the HIFAR area was contributing tritium to the stormwater drainage system, and this has now been diverted to the active effluent system.

Water seeping through sandstone under Building 57, which contains small amounts of tritium, is being collected and pumped to the AAEC effluent treatment plant. Material is being excavated from below Building 57 to identify the tritium source.

(e) Radioactive waste is stored in Building 57. No radioactive waste is buried on the LHRL site; the only buried radioactive wastes in the Lucas Heights area are at Little Forest, 1.6 km to the north.

(f) Storage and treatment of liquid radioactive waste; storage of more highly radioactive liquid wastes prior to treatment; draining of heavy water containing tritium from HIFAR ion exchange columns and storage of the degraded heavy water; drying of ion exchange resin; storage of beryllium oxide; storage of asbestos prior to disposal; storage of waste uranium metal turnings prior to treatment; storage of uranium oxide.

(g) The precise source is not yet known but it is unlikely to have come from buried or stored waste, since none is buried on the LHRL site and wastes stored on site are contained within weatherproof buildings.

(i) The presence of tritium in stormwater discharges has been made known by the AAEC in its annual environmental survey reports from 1970. Such discharges were also reported in the AAEC Annual Report for 1981-82. These reports are publicly available.

(j) The AAEC annual environmental survey reports are routinely made available to NSW authorities. In addition an officer of the NSW Department of Health, who is also Chairman of the NSW Radiological Advisory Council, is a member of the AAEC's Safety Review Committee. It is well known by these bodies that the presence of tritium in stormwater has never been of any significance from the point of view of public health or the environment.
(k) No. The amount of tritium is negligible in relation to the authorisation.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Endangered Species: Critical Areas of Habitat

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there any land in Australia which is privately owned and which forms a critical area of habitat for endangered species.
(2) What financial assistance has been provided by the Commonwealth to State or Territory Governments for the acquisition of critical areas of habitat for endangered species since March 1983.
(3) Has he established a program to provide such financial assistance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Some privately owned land in Australia does form the habitat of some of Australia's endangered species. Information about such land is developed from a number of sources. The Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM) co-ordinates lists of endangered species which provides some information of their distribution. As well, information on particular species has been the subject of special study by Commonwealth agencies such as the ANPWS, The Bureau of Flora and Fauna, the Australian National Botanic Gardens and the CSIRO. The States and Territory nature conservation agencies also maintain information on the distribution of endangered species. Through these processes certain areas of private land in Australia have been identified as important for the survival of certain species. For example an area of private land near Geraldton, Western Australia may be important for the survival of a native plant Drummondita ericoides. Also former private properties fell into such a category, for instance, the property ``Red Hill'' in Queensland is part of the remnant habitat of the Bridled Nailtail Wallaby which is an endangered species. The adjacent property ``Tauntyon'' also provides some habitat for the species. Former privately owned land adjacent to Yellingbo State Fauna Reserve in the Dandenongs, Victoria, as well as the Reserve itself provides the habitat of the Helmeted Honeyeater.

(2) In 1983-84 $200,000 was made available to the Queensland Government to assist in the purchase of the ``Red Hill'' property. The earlier acquisition with Commonwealth assistance of the adjacent property ``Taunton'' did not provide an area of land large enough to ensure the long term survival of the Bridled Nailtail Wallaby. In 1984-85 $12,000 was provided to the Victorian Government for the purchase of the land which was added to the Yellingbo State Fauna Reserve to secure part of the Helmeted Honeyeater's habitat. These funds were part of a total of $472,000 provided by the Federal Government to Victoria for the purchase of privately owned land under a 1976-77 agreement.
(3) Financial assistance is provided to the States and Territories for land acquisition through the Environment (Financial Assistance) Act 1977 and the States Assistance Program.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Year of Peace: Australia Council Grants

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 12 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Will Australia Council grants to artists under the auspices of the International Year of Peace be restricted to artistic projects that are in basic concord with the Government's foreign and defence policies; if so, who will make the decisions on each application for funding.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australia Council had advised me that applications to the Council for International Year of Peace (IYP) projects were assessed by a Working Party appointed by the Council and comprising-Professor Donald Horne, AO, Ms Betty Churcher and Ms Robin Nevin.

The Working Party considered applications in terms of quality, artform and geographical location. Account was taken of the need for projects to focus attention and encourage reflection on the basic requirements of peace in the contemporary world which is one of the objectives of the International Year of Peace as laid down by the Secretary-General of the United Nations.

Applications were assessed in accordance with the Government's general guidelines for applications for assistance under the International Year of Peace program. These guidelines state that projects which are in direct conflict with established Government policy on peace, disarmament and arms control issues will not be considered.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 19 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reports alleging that systematic efforts are being made by Turkish authorities to discourage the maintenance of the Syrian Orthodox Christian community as a separate religious and linguistic community.

(2) Does the Government have any recent information on alleged persecution of this group by such means as (a) discrimination in public sector employment and (b) suppression of religious teaching within the community.

(3) Are there any steps the Australian Government can take to encourage the recognition of this community as a non-Moslem minority under the Treaty of Lausanne which may remove much of this discrimination; if so, what are the steps.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (a) The Australian Ambassador to Ankara has recently been informed by the Syrian Orthodox Metropolitan that there is no direct persecution of Syrian Orthodox Christians by the Turkish authorities, although considerable migration of Syrian Orthodox Christians from Turkey has taken place.

(b) The Syrian Orthodox Christians have about 30 churches and two monasteries in the area between Midyat and Mardin in south-eastern Turkey, although only 30 per cent of the area is Christian. However, Syrian Orthodox Christian leaders have expressed some concern that the new education law, which requires all children to take exams in the Islamic faith, could result in some drift away from the community amongst younger people.

(3) There are no steps which the Government can take to encourage the recognition of this community as a ``non-Moslem minority''. In legal terms the categorisation of Syrian Orthodox Christians as a ``non-Moslem minority'' is a matter of fact.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the N.S.W. Building Society require Reserve Bank approval to operate as the Advance Bank after 1 June 1985; if so, what conditions did the Reserve Bank place on the operations of the Advance Bank.
(2) Were the conditions different to those placed on other (a) existing or (b) new banks; if so, in what way were they different.
(3) What additional services or benefits could the Advance Bank offer which were unavailable from the N.S.W. Building Society.
(4) Could the Advance Bank offer these improved services to (a) existing and (b) new customers.
(5) Was the Advance Bank bound by the 13.5% ceiling on housing loan interest rates on loans negotiated (a) before and (b) after 1 June 1985.
(6) Are all other banks required to keep housing loan interest rates at or below 13.5%.

(7) If the Advance Bank (a) could offer improved services to all customers as a result of obtaining a bank licence and (b) is not required to satisfy the 13.5% ceiling on home loan interest rates for all customers, why is the ceiling not imposed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The application by the N.S.W. Building Society for a banking authority was lodged and dealt with under normal banking policy. The Governor-General granted Advance Bank Australia Limited (formerly N.S.W. Building Society) such an authority to operate from 1 June 1985. The authority contains conditions requiring Advance Bank to conform with arrangements for prudential supervision as notified by the Reserve Bank. The conditions are as follows:

(a) the body corporate shall, upon request made at any time by the Reserve Bank of Australia, consult with the Reserve Bank in relation to the making or variation of arrangements for the prudential supervision by the Reserve Bank of the banking business carried on in Australia by the body corporate;

(b) the body corporate shall conform with such arrangements for the prudential supervision by the Reserve Bank of the banking business carried on in Australia by the body corporate as are notified to the body corporate by the Reserve Bank, whether following such consultation or otherwise.

(2) I indicated in September 1984 that all new banking authorities issued under the Banking Act would be subject to conditions requiring banks to comply with the prudential standards as set from time to time by the Reserve Bank. Prior to September 1984 authorities were generally issued without conditions. Since that time all new authorities have been issued subject to the same conditions as those placed on Advance Bank; the Bank of China's authority is an exception in that it includes an additional condition relating to the facilitation of financial relationships with the People's Republic of China. Those banks which do not have formal conditions to their banking authorities nevertheless consult with the Reserve Bank on prudential matters and conform with arrangements established by the Reserve Bank.

(3) Authorisation under the Banking Act enables an institution to engage in the general business of banking. That includes the provision of chequing account facilities. It also permits the institution to operate nationally under uniform banking policies, and gives it the status of a bank in its dealings in domestic and overseas financial markets. That status reflects the high prudential standards required of banks, and the prudential supervision of them by the Reserve Bank, for the purpose of protection of depositors.

(5) In the case of loans of less than $100,000 for owner-occupied housing which were approved or drawn down for the first time between 1 June 1985 and the taking effect of the Government's decisions of 2 April 1986 on the housing assistance package, Advance Bank is bound by the 13.5 per cent ceiling on interest rates in the same way as other savings banks. In the case of loans outstanding prior to 1 June 1985, I have agreed that, for a period of two years, the 13.5 per cent ceiling need not apply: at the end of that period the situation is to be reviewed in the expectation that those loans would then comply with the ceiling.

(6) National Mutual Royal Savings Bank has a similar arrangement to that applying to Advance Bank, operating from 26 February 1986. All other savings banks subject to the Banking Act are required to observe the 13.5 per cent ceiling on loans of less than $100,000 for owner-occupied housing approved before 3 April 1986.

(7) The transitional arrangements applying to Advance Bank and National Mutual Royal Savings Bank recognise that before their conversion to savings bank those institutions as building societies generally paid higher interest rates to attract deposits than did savings banks. For that reason they also charged higher interest rates on their housing loans. It takes some time before the structure of deposits and the average interest rate cost faced by a converted institution can be brought into line with those applying to established savings banks.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Trustees and Executors Agency: National Companies Code

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 11 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether Trustees and Executors Agency Co. Ltd (TEA) announced in March 1983 a loss of $1.1 million for the 6 months ended 31 December 1982.
(2) Is he able to say whether the directors of the company (a) declared a dividend of 10 cents per share on 20 April 1983 and (b) announced a decision to go into receivership on 13 May 1983.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to what Mr Justice Beach of the Supreme Court of Victoria said in response to the circumstances surrounding this company's collapse, that one could not imagine more shameful behaviour on the part of a trustee company and its directors.

(4) Does Sub-section 229 (2) of the National Companies Code require that an officer of a corporation shall at all times exercise a reasonable degree of care and diligence in the exercise of his powers and the discharge of his duties and that the penalty upon conviction for breach of the provision is a fine of $5,000.
(5) Are directors civilly liable (a) if a company contracts unpayable debts or (b) if they make a material omission from statements or reports relating to their company's affairs.
(6) Under the `good faith' provision of the National Companies Code, are directors required to act in the interests of the company and to avoid conflicts of interests.

(7) Is he able to say whether (a) TEA made a loan to Kelly Power Pty Ltd; if so, was a TEA director associated with Kelly Power Pty Ltd and (b) was the TEA Board Chairman, Mr Alexander Ogilvy, formerly associated with Arthur Young and Co.
(8) Why was the company's vulnerable position not revealed in its last regular audit.
(9) Why have criminal charges been brought against only one person and why has the case yet to be determined.
(10) Are other directors, officers, and auditors to be prosecuted; if not, why not.
(11) If other prosecutions are to take place, when will they occur.

(12) Will he, at the next meeting of the Ministerial Council, seek approval for uniform legislation to increase the level of protection for investors in trustee companies and set out clearly and more effectively the codes of conduct required of directors, officers and auditors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (5) (a) The Companies Code provides that, if a company incurs a debt when there are reasonable grounds to expect that the company will not be able to pay its debts as and when they become due, any director or other person involved in the company's management at that time is guilty of an offence (subject to a penalty of $5,000 or imprisonment for one year, or both) and the company and the above person or persons are jointly and severally liable for the payment of the debt.

(5) (b) In addition to questions of possible liability under the Trade Practices Act for misleading or deceptive conduct or under general law for misrepresentation, the Companies Code specifically makes it an offence for a person to omit or to authorise the omission from a document, required under the Act or lodged with the National Companies and Securities Commission, of any matter or thing with the effect that the document is to that person's knowledge misleading in a material respect. The Act imposes a penalty of $10,000 or imprisonment for two years, or both. A person is also liable if a material omission is made or authorised without taking reasonable steps to prevent it occurring (penalty $5,000 or imprisonment for one year, or both). In addition any person whose interests are affected by such omissions may seek an injunction under the Act.

(6) The Companies Code requires a company officer at all times to act honestly in the exercise of his powers and the discharge of his duties (penalty $5,000, or $20,000 and/or 5 years imprisonment if fraudulent). Substantial penalties ($20,000 or imprisonment for 5 years, or both) are imposed for improper use of information acquired by a company officer or employee by virtue of his position and for improper use of such position to gain, directly or indirectly, an advantage for himself or another person or to cause detriment to the company. The Court is able to order compensation to the company against convicted offenders. The company may also recover compensation against persons who have contravened the above provision even if they have not been convicted of the offence.
(7) (a) No; I am advised that Mr Peter Bunning has been a director of both TEA and Kelly Power Pty Ltd.
(7) (b) I am advised that Mr Ogilvy was formerly associated with Messrs Arthur Young & Co.

(8) This matter is dealt with in the Fourth Interim Report of the National Companies and Securities Commission in respect of which a certificate has been issued by the Attorney-General of Victoria stating that the publication of that report would be prejudicial to the administration of justice in Victoria. In accordance with provisions in the Companies Code, that report cannot now be published in whole or in part unless a further certificate is issued by the Attorney-General indicating that publication of the report would no longer be prejudicial to the administration of justice in Victoria.

(9), (10) and (11) These parts of the question relate to matters that are subject to decision by the Director of Public Prosecutions in Victoria after completion of the examination of all available and legally admissible evidence.

(12) The Companies Code already provides an appropriate level of investor protection and imposes proper standards of conduct on directors, officers and auditors. I am confident that the special investigation into the affairs of the Trustees Executors and Agency Company Limited will result in legal action being taken where contraventions of the Companies Codes provisions are supported by probative evidence. The courts have the present capacity to impose stringent penalties in cases of proven misconduct. I believe that the current provisions represent an effective way of dealing with misconduct by corporate officers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 11 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many persons invited by the Government to be members of the Constitution Consultative Commission and its advisory committees were (a) men and (b) women and what was the reason for their selection.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 11 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to indicate how many individuals have died whilst in police custody in each of the States and Territories in each of the last 5 years.
(2) Is he able to say whether the rights of persons in police custody are protected sufficiently under existing Territory and State law.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.

(2) It is considered that internal directives, promulgated by the Commissioner in accordance with section 14 of the AFP Act 1979, adequately protect the rights of persons held in AFP custody. These directives provide for, inter alia, access to legal advice and medical attention.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 13 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to the answer to questions Nos 3216 and 3243 what:
(a) was the stated purpose of each overseas trip made by employees of the Minister's Department and of all Statutory Authorities that report to the Minister in 1984-85;
(b) was the classification or job description of each officer making each trip;
(c) was the duration of each trip;
(d) were the countries visited during each trip; and
(e) was the estimated cost of each trip, with the air fare component identified separately.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The reply includes details of expenditure from the International Conference Vote for the cost of fares, travelling allowances, accommodation, conference expenses, car hire and incidentals for Australian representatives from Government Departments and Instrumentalities, and approved observers attending the many major conferences held overseas under the auspices of various international organisations.

On occasions only partial funding is provided from this vote. The Department administers this item as a common service, both because of its coordinating role in relation to the International Organisations involved and to ensure that the needs of all authorities and departments are met and in the most economical manner. Travel by Members of Parliament and personnel of all Government departments and authorities, when attending meetings as official Australian representatives, are funded from this item.

The reply does not detail costs associated with posting the Department's officers to established positions overseas, the Department's Diplomatic Courier program or travel to undertake property and equipment maintenance. It does include operational travel by officers of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau, but not aid experts or contract employees.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 19 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What sum did the Government spend on treatment of and research into (a) heart disease, (b) strokes, (c) cancer, (d) alcohol related illnesses and (e) AIDS in (i) 1983-84 (ii) 1984-85 and (iii) 1985-86 to date, in each State and Territory.
(2) How many persons received Government funded treatment for each complaint in each State and Territory in each of those years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Commonwealth Government does not collect diagnostic information regarding services that attract Medicare benefits. It is therefore, not possible to provide the requested information on either numbers of persons receiving treatment or amounts spent by the Commonwealth, classified by type of illness.
The Government, through the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC), spent the following amounts on research for the years 1983-1986.
* NHMRC does not record figures for various areas of heart disease and so amounts for heart disease and strokes are included under `Cardiovascular'.
+ NHMRC funding figures are available only on a calendar year basis.
* Figure includes $0.750m allocated by AIDS Task Force.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: During his last visit to the Soviet Union, did the Minister raise the matter of Ukrainian political prisoners with the relevant Soviet officials; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: My last visit to the Soviet Union was a short stopover at Moscow airport on 15 June 1985. Although the Government regularly makes representations to the Soviet authorities on human rights abuses in the Soviet Union, time restraints did not permit me to raise the specific matter of Ukrainian political prisoners on this occasion.
Australia has also been involved in complicated negotiations with Soviet authorities aimed at the possible release of the leading Ukrainian political detainee, Yuri Shukhevych.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Women's Centre Incorporated, Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 8 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answer by the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services to a question without notice (Hansard, 13 March 1986, page 1309) concerning a Community Employment Program grant to the Women's Centre Incorporated, A.C.T., who were the applicants for the grant.
(2) Who sponsored the project.
(3) What sum did the sponsor contribute.
(4) Did the applicant own Tilley Devine's bar when the $140 000 grant was allocated; if not, (a) who owned the bar and (b) how was the money controlled.
(5) If the applicant for the grant was not the controller of the project, what was the applicant's role in the venture.
(6) Where is the final audited statement on the venture.
(7) Will he table all the papers relating to the grant.
(8) When is the police report to be (a) finalised (b) tabled.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)-(8) All aspects covered in these questions are currently the subject of an investigation by the Australian Federal Police. It would be inappropriate to comment further on those aspects before that investigation has been completed and the report examined.

(2) How many were (a) full-time, (b) permanent part-time and (c) other part-time in the (i) public and (ii) private sector.
(3) How many were Community Employment Program created jobs.
(4) What criteria are used to define a job.
(5) Which Departments or instrumentalities have created positions and how many have been created in each Department and instrumentality in each category.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Total employment, seasonally adjusted, rose by 634,200 or 10.1 per cent between April 1983 and July 1986.
(2) (a) Full-time employment has increased by 433,000 or 8.4 per cent since April 1983, representing 68.3 per cent of total employment growth.
(b) and (c) Part-time employment rose 201,200 or 17.9 per cent over the period.

Details as to the permanency or otherise of part-time jobs are not obtained by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) in its monthly labour force survey. The most recent study of the nature of part-time working arrangements was that conducted by the ABS and recorded in Alternative Working Arrangements, Australia, March to May 1982, Catalogue no: 6340.0. That survey found that some 90 per cent of part-time employment at that time was on a permanent basis. (A person employed in permanent part-time work was defined as an employee who was entitled to paid holidays or sick pay. A casual part-time worker was one who was not entitled to paid leave).

(i) and (ii) Information on the distribution of employment growth between the private and public sectors is available from the monthly labour force survey for the period to May 1986 (latest available data).

In the three years to May 1986, total jobs in industries operating predominantly in the private sector increased by 435,900 (9.7 per cent) representing 67.6 per cent of the overall increase in employment (671,700) over the period. Of these jobs 283,200 were full-time, representing 65.5 per cent of the 432,400 full-time jobs created overall.

Employment in public sector dominated industries grew by 217,800 (13.5 per cent) in the three years to May 1986 representing 32.4 per cent of overall job growth. Of the net employment growth in the public sector 149,200 were full-time jobs, accounting for 34.5 per cent of the increase in total full-time employment over the three years to May 1986.

Data in the Employed Wage and Salary Earners series (ABS Catalogue No 6248.0), an alternative source of employment data based on an employer survey, indicate that in the two years to March 1986 growth in private sector wage and salary employment accounted for 85.5 per cent (420,700 jobs out of a total of 491,800 jobs) of the total increase in wage and salary earners. Data from this survey are not available as early as March 1983, and the survey excludes employers, self employed persons and all private sector agricultural employment.
(3) Under the Community Employment Program (CEP) 106,635 jobs had been formally approved for funding from the time of the Program's inception in 1983 up to 14 July 1986.
While current CEP guidelines do allow for part-time work to be undertaken, this has occurred only rarely, for example in certain child-care areas. Most CEP jobs are full-time.

(4) The ABS definition of employment, in conformity with that of the International Labour Organisation (ILO), includes persons aged 15 years and over who, in the week during which the survey was conducted:
(a) worked for one hour or more for pay, profit, commission or payment in kind in a job or business, or on a farm (including employees, employers and self-employed persons); or
(b) worked for one hour or more without pay in a family business or on a farm (i.e. unpaid family helpers); or

(c) were employees who had a job but were not at work and were: on paid leave; on leave without pay for less than four weeks up to the end of the survey week; stood down without pay because of bad weather or plant breakdown at their place of employment for less than four weeks up to the end of the survey week; on strike or locked out; on worker's compensation and expected to be returning to their job; or receiving wages or salary while undertaking full-time study; or
(d) were employers or self-employed persons who had a job, business or farm, but were not at work.
Source: (ABS, The Labour Force, Australia: Explanatory Notes).

(5) Establishment statistics on Government Departments and instrumentalities have not been recorded by the Public Service Board since June 1984. However some information on staffing numbers is available.

The following tables show movements in full-time and non-permanent part-time Public Service Act staffing numbers by Department and instrumentality between March 1983 and December 1985 (the most recent date for which figures are available). As at December 1985 there were no permanent part-time officers employed in the Australian Public Service. The figures have not been adjusted to take account of administrative re-arrangements over the period concerned since the detailed information needed is not readily available and would result in a very complex tabulation with large numbers of explanatory footnotes.

In the period March 1983 to December 1985 the number of persons employed under the Public Service Act increased by 12,158 or 7.6 per cent. This increase included growth in full-time staff of 11,727 or 7.4 per cent and growth in part-time staff of 431 persons or 14.6 per cent.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Human Rights and Self-determination: Baltic States

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What steps have been taken by the Government over the last 3 years to press for the observance of human rights and self determination for the Baltic States of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: This Government over the last three years has strongly and consistently deplored the Soviet Union's unsatisfactory human rights record, including in relation to the Baltic States, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. We have expressed our views publicly as well as conveying them privately to the Soviet authorities.
Australia has also joined in international efforts calling upon the Soviet Union to abide by the important principles of human rights embodied in United Nations instruments.

In response to the concern over the human rights situation in the Baltic States this Government raised the question of violation of human rights in the Baltic States at the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in March 1985 and March 1986.

On the question of self determination, as you will already be aware, Australia does not recognise de jure the incorporation of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania into the Soviet Union, but recognises de facto the Soviet Government's control over the Baltic States.

This Government will continue to support an end to the violation of human rights in the Baltic States and make efforts towards this end which can be assessed as constructive and not counter-productive.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 17 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answer to my question No. 2588 (Hansard, 12 March 1986, page 1256) relating to accounting standards, is the ``fast track'' to which he refers the 20 standards already prepared by the Australian profession.

(2) What is the nature of the standards (a) which have been approved, (b) which are likely to be approved and (c) which have been issued by the profession but not yet considered by the Accounting Standards Review Board.
(3) Will there be a comprehensive group of standards when the proposed standards are approved.
(4) Is there any opposition or hostility from the business community to the standards already issued.
(5) Will he consider, as a matter of urgency, granting financial assistance to the Australian Accountants Standards Foundation to enable it to increase production of the standards.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The ``fast track'' procedure involves the Accounting Standards Review Board identifying those existing professional standards for which it would be appropriate to expedite the ASRB's normal review and approval procedures. I understand that factors taken into consideration by the ASRB include the length of time the standard has been on issue; the degree of controversy associated with it; and the level of compliance with the standard. I am advised that in the light of those criteria, the ASRB considers that not all the profession's standards are suitable for immediate approval as approved accounting standards.
2 (a) The ASRB has approved eight accounting standards (on the dates shown) covering the following matters:
Events Occurring after Balance Date (18 September 1985)
Accounting for Interests in Joint Ventures (30 April 1986)
Financial Reporting of Sources and Applications of Funds (30 June 1986)

2 (b) I am informed that the ASRB expects to approve another 3 accounting standards in the next few months dealing with, respectively, the revaluation of non-current assets, accounting for research and development, and accounting for construction contracts. A further proposed standard on measurement requirements for foreign currency translation was released for public comment earlier this year and is now being considered in the light of the submissions received before being approved. Proposed standards on equity accounting and accounting for goodwill have been submitted by the Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Australian Society of Accountants (`the joint accounting bodies') and have yet to be publicly exposed. It should also be noted that at its meeting at Yulara on 23rd July 1986, the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities decided in principle that the disclosure requirements of Schedule 7 should be progressively replaced, as soon as practicable, by approved accounting standards.

2 (c) I am advised that there are a number of accounting standards which have been issued by the joint accounting bodies but which have yet to be formally submitted to the ASRB. These standards cover the following topics:
Valuation and Presentation of Inventories in the Context of the Historical Cost System
Accounting for Company Income Tax (Tax-Effect Accounting)
Expenditure carried forward to subsequent Accounting Periods
Accounting for the Acquisition of Assets (including Business Entities).

(3) When all the professional standards so far issued by the joint accounting bodies have been approved by the ASRB as approved accounting standards, significant aspects of accounting will still remain to be covered by further approved standards. While the standards already issued by the profession cover the fundamental issues of historical cost accounting and their approval would bring the Australian position closer to that of the more advanced Western countries, I understand that they do not deal with a number of issues, such as consolidated financial statements, accounting for costs of employee benefits, statements of financial position and accounting for investment in entities other than subsidiaries, which, for example, are the subject of standards in the United States. In addition, the ASRB will need to monitor, and take appropriate measures to deal with new developments in accounting concepts and practices, including the emerging overseas movement to replace historical cost accounting with the concept of current cost accounting.

(4) I am advised that the ASRB has received no formal complaints regarding standards subsequent to their approval. Indeed, the ASRB has introduced a number of formal procedures specifically intended to identify and resolve contentious issues before standards are approved. These procedures include the public exposure of proposed standards to provide the public, including the business community, with an opportunity to bring issues of concern to the attention of the ASRB. The ASRB is also required to evaluate the practicality and efficiency of a proposed standard having regard to its commercial and economic consequences. This assessment takes into account, among other things, the impact of compliance with, and the corresponding costs and benefits of, a proposed accounting standard on small as well as medium and large companies and on companies in particular industries.

(5) The organisation to which the honourable member has referred is the Australian Accounting Research Foundation (AARF). It is a private organisation involved in the research and development of professional accounting standards which is funded by the members of the joint accounting bodies. I understand that AARF also receives the proceeds of licensing arrangements with commercial publishers for the printing of the professional standards and will continue to receive such funds in respect of the commercial publication of approved standards which are based on proposed standards submitted by them. At a time when there is a need for restraint in Government expenditure in all areas I do not propose that we should, at this stage, be taking on additional areas of funding responsibility.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 2 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the campaign in Queensland promoted by the National Party of Australia and some aspects of the medical profession claiming that the State has been significantly disadvantaged under the Medicare arrangements because of the State's so called free hospital system.
(2) If so, will he detail the facts on this issue.

(3) Is it a fact that Queensland received (a) special financial assistance to compensate it because of its hospital system and (b) additional moneys which were untied and which have gone into consolidated revenue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. My attention has been drawn to the campaign in Queensland prompted by the National Party claiming that the State has been significantly disadvantaged under the Medicare arrangements because of the State's so called free hospital system. It would appear that the Queensland National Party resurrects the question of Medicare funding from time to time in a bid to distort the level of compensation that the Commonwealth is making to Queensland under Medicare.

(2) and (3) The facts of the issue are that all States and Territories were treated equally in relation to compensation for the loss of revenue or increased costs associated with the introduction of Medicare. However, to ensure that Queenslanders received a greater return through Medicare benefits and hospital payments than Queenslanders paid under the levy, a special grant was included in the Medicare payments. The amount paid for the first 5 months of Medicare was $18m; $35m was paid in 1984-85 and in 1985-86 that $35m was increased by 7.2% to $37.5m. This amount will be maintained in real terms in 1986-87. Further, at the time the Medicare Hospital Agreements were signed, the Commonwealth agreed that to dispel any concern that the people of Queensland had regarding the level of funding to Queensland under Medicare, the Grants Commission was requested to assess whether or not the Medicare arrangements altered the health relativities in relation to Commonwealth payments. The 1985 Grants Commission Report identified an amount of $10m as necessary to restore Queensland's position in relation to health relativities for 1983-84 and 1984-85. The additional $10m was paid in 1985-86. The new funding arrangements agreed at the Premiers' Conference in June 1985 maintained the equity of health relativities.

The Medicare grants are untied grants and are paid into the State's consolidated revenue. Queensland is free to allocate those funds in accordance with its own priorities. I am unaware if the additional grant funds have been directed to improving the Queensland public hospital system. However, I understand from an examination of the Queensland State Budget papers over recent years, that there has not been significant real increases in expenditure on public hospitals which would indicate that the extra $100 million paid to Queensland since the introduction of Medicare has not been directed at improving the State public hospital system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What control do the (a) Federal Government and (b) State Governments have over (i) the wholesale and (ii) the retail price of petrol and other petroleum products.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) maintains surveillance over wholesale prices charged by the oil companies for petrol, automotive distillate, aviation gasoline and aviation turbine fuel, and over the ex-refinery gate prices for liquefied petroleum gas. In accordance with the provisions of the Prices Surveillance Act 1983, the PSA sets maximum prices to be charged by oil companies for these products. The companies are free to charge lower prices if they wish.

In addition to its surveillance of these products, the PSA also monitors the wholesale prices of other petroleum products under a voluntary arrangement with the oil industry. The PSA does not undertake surveillance of the retail prices of petroleum products.

Western Australia is the only State which currently exercises control over petrol prices. It controls both wholesale and retail prices, although wholesale prices are set in line with decisions of the PSA. There are no State controls over the prices of other petroleum products.
