QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What progress was made at the IMF and World Bank meetings in April 1986 towards (a) reform of the international financial system and (b) coping with the massive overseas debts of some third world countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Information on these matters is contained in the Communique of the Interim Committee of the Board of Governors of the International Monetary Fund (the Interim Committee), released on 10 April 1986 and the Communique of the Joint Ministerial Committee of the Board of Governors of the Bank and the Fund on the Transfer of Real Resources to Developing Countries (the Development Committee), issued on 11 April 1986. A copy of these two communiques has been provided to the honourable member.
Paragraphs 4 to 7 inclusive of the Interim Committee Communique report on the Committee's consideration of a number of issues related to the international monetary system.

Paragraphs 12 to 17 inclusive of the Development Committee Communique and paragraph 8 of the Interim Committee Communique comment on the situation of low income countries with protracted balance of payments difficulties. The problems of the most heavily indebted middle-income countries are addressed in paragraphs 3 to 10 inclusive of the Development Committee Communique and paragraph 3 of the Interim Committee Communique.
Joint Ministerial Committee of the Boards of Governors of the Bank and the Fund on the Transfer of Real Resources to Developing Countries

1. The Development Committee held its twenty-eighth meeting in Washington, D.C. on April 10-11, 1986, under the chairmanship of His Excellency Ghulam Ishaq Khan. Mr A. W. Clausen, President of the World Bank, Mr J. de Larosiere, Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund, and Mr Fritz Fischer, Executive Secretary of the Development Committee, participated in the meeting. Observers from a number of international and regional organizations and Switzerland also attended.

2. The Committee heard a report from the IMF Managing Director on the Interim Committee discussions on the world economic outlook and on the debt situation and stategy and endorsed the Interim Committee's conclusion.

3. The Committee reviewed the progress that had been made in addressing the problems of the most heavily indebted middle-income countries in the period since its Seoul meeting and the announcement of U.S. Treasury Secretary Baker's initiative. In this context, the Committee reviewed the background paper on this subject prepared at its request by the world bank, and endorsed the general approach set out for achieving sustained growth in the heavily indebted countries. The Committee heard with great interest reports of progress made in recent months by a number of countries in designing such programs and urged all major parties-indebted countries, industrial countries, commercial banks, and international financial and development institutions-to redouble their efforts so that medium-term growth-oriented adjustment programs can be designed and implemented as soon as possible.

4. The Committee recognized that the problems of these countries were deep-seated and would not be resolved quickly as the outstanding debt burden on government finance and balance of payment hampers growth prospects and a return to creditworthiness. The Committee emphasized the need for a roll-back in protectionism. It agreed that a lasting solution for the debt problem requires not only sustained adjustment and growth in developing countries, but also industrial country policies which will promote a further decline in real interest rates, expansion in international trade, improvements in commodity prices, greater stability in exchange markets, and increased external capital flows. In this context the Committee urged industrial countries to redouble their efforts in removing these obstacles to a lasting solution to the debt problem.

5. The Committee stressed that even with substantial policy reforms in developing countries and satisfactory rates of non-inflationary growth in industrial countries, restoration of growth in developing countries requires large amounts of net flows of capital, including repatriation of flight capital. Success will depend essentially upon the creation of an environment which would help promote timely action by the commercial banks and by all sources of finance providing adequate amounts of resources.

6. In this context, the Committee emphasized the importance of export credit agencies (ECAs) as a major source of financing and endorsed the Interim Committee's conclusions on this topic. Members welcomed the World Bank's intention to work more closely with all parties concerned to encourage timely and adequate support by ECAs in countries undertaking adjustment for growth programs to help ensure their success.

7. The Committee also urged creditor governments to ensure that regulations and guidelines imposed by their bank supervisors do not impede financing arrangements that can provide increased commercial bank flows, consistent with prudential considerations, to countries implementing significant medium-term programs of adjustment and growth. The Committee agreed that new flows of international bank credit in such circumstances can help to improve the quality of outstanding credits.

8. The Committee also recognized the role of the private sector in development and the need for greater flows of foreign investment to developing countries. In this context, members noted that the Convention establishing the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA) has now been signed by 19 governments, including four industralized countries. The Committee encouraged other interested governments to sign and ratify the Convention so that it may enter into force as soon as possible.

9. The Committee re-emphasized the consensus reached in Seoul on the need for the enhanced participation of the World Bank and the IMF in the design, financing and monitoring of growth-oriented adjustment programs. The Committee agreed that this would help inspire greater confidence that the heavily indebted countries are taking appropriate steps to restore growth and creditworthiness. The Committee stressed that in furthering their collaboration, the Bank and the Fund should maintain their respective areas of competence and avoid cross-conditionality.

10. Consistent with the Bank's global commitment to development, growth and poverty alleviation, the Committee reaffirmed its strong support for a substantial expansion of the Bank's lending program. It noted that since the Committee's meeting in Seoul, Bank Management had increased projections of lending in FY1986-1988 to a range of $40-50 billion, and was now contemplating a lending level of up to $21.5 billion in FY1990. The Committee expressed its strong support for the steps taken by the Bank to assist the heavily indebted countries to develop credible growth-oriented programs. The increase in Bank net disbursements to these countries was welcomed as was the prospect that in 1986 adjustment-related lending to them will increase substantially. The Committee urged the Bank to take further steps to strengthen its ability to play a leading role in support of programs aimed at adjustment and growth as well as of investment projects throughout the world.

11. Ministers reiterated the understanding reached in Seoul that the Bank should be provided with the capacity to increase its quality lending and that the Bank should not be constrained by lack of capital or borrowing authority in meeting future demand. The Committee welcomed the additional efforts of the Bank in promoting growth-oriented adjustment and the associated increase in financial commitments it has undertaken in support of such programs. The Committee emphasized the essential role of the World Bank, together with the IMF and commercial banks, in supporting comprehensive adjustment programs. It noted that provided other participants continue to fulfill their obligations in the adjustment programs, Bank lending for FY1987 may possibly exceed the level of lending that could be sustained with the capital at present available to it. The Committee welcomed the forthcoming discussion in the Bank Board of several matters bearing on the calculation of future capital requirements, including the valuation of IBRD capital. Ministers agreed that the Bank's Executive Board should seek an early resolution of these issues so that an agreement on a General Capital Increase can be arrived at promptly. In this context, and in light of these encouraging developments, the Committee stressed the importance of continuing to monitor closely progress in meeting the Bank's capital requirements and the need to ensure adequate capital. The Ministers requested that the World Bank prepare a progress report for discussion at the next meeting on the Bank's lending program and on the continued adequacy of its capital.

12. Members reviewed the World Bank's most recent report, prepared at the Committee's request, on the continuing severe difficulties of Sub-Saharan Africa and agreed that concerted action is urgently needed to address the region's problems. The Committee reiterated its strong support for the Joint Program of Action endorsed at its September 1984 meeting. The Committee also requested that a study on the market prospects of raw materials be prepared for a future meeting of the Committee.

13. The Committee noted with satisfaction the growing commitment of African governments to policy reform, as illustrated by examples in the Bank's report of adjustment measures now being implemented. Some promising results are already evident. The Committee stressed that success of medium-term growth-oriented adjustment programs require increased external capital flows, particularly in view of continued weakness in commodity prices and heavy debt service obligations. Members noted the Bank's estimate of $2.5 billion in additional concessional flows that are needed annually, over the next five years, to help meet low-income Sub-Saharan Africa's financial needs. Members called upon industrial countries to exert their best efforts to close this gap by providing additional official development assistance, through both bilateral and multilateral channels, to countries in the region undertaking significant reform programs. Furthermore, most Ministers agreed that donor countries should not be net recipients of official capital flows from African countries undertaking adjustment programs.

14. Ministers also agreed on the need to enhance further the effectiveness of aid flows to Sub-Saharan Africa and noted the World Bank's suggestions for strengthening donor aid coordination. The Committee reaffirmed that the central responsibility for aid coordination lies with each recipient government. In this context, the Committee urged the Bank to take the leadership role in improving aid coordination, working closely with interested governments as well as with the UNDP, the OECD/DAC, the European Community and other concerned parties. The Committee asked the Bank to report back at the next meeting on progress achieved in all aspects of coordination, including progress in the establishment of improved monitoring mechanisms.

15. The Committee heard a progress report on current negotiations for the replenishment of IDA. Ministers emphasized the special importance of IDA to the success of development programs in poor countries throughout the world. Virtually all Ministers expressed the strong hope that an IDA-8 replenishment of $12 billion will be achieved. This would maintain in real terms the concessionary resources now available throughout IDA-7 and the Special Facility for Sub-Saharan Africa and enable IDA to continue its role in poverty alleviation and economic development and also to provide necessary support, in conjunction with the IMF, to IDA-eligible countries undertaking growth- oriented adjustment programs. Ministers urged donors to exert maximum efforts in the coming months to reach a consensus on outstanding issues related to the next replenishment, including fair burden-sharing and an equitable allocation of resources, and expressed the wish that negotiations be concluded before the next meeting of the Committee in September.

16. The Committee welcomed the recent decision taken by the IMF Executive Board that established the Structural Adjustment Facility (SAF) in the Fund which will provide assistance on concessional terms to low-income countries with protracted balance of payments problems in support of medium-term macroeconomic and structural adjustment programs. The Committee noted that the new Facility will require close coordination between the Fund and the World Bank to assist eligible members in the formulation of a comprehensive medium-term policy framework. The Committee expressed the hope that the SAF resources would be complemented by additional bilateral and multilateral concessional assistance in support of agreed programs. Ministers reaffirmed that such arrangements would not adversely affect the availability of concessional development finance for low-income countries not utilizing Trust Fund reflows.

17. The Committee recognized that concessional flows are of critical importance to the success of adjustment and growth programs in the poorest developing countries. In this context, the Committee welcomed further Bank reports following up on the conclusions of the Task Force on Concessional Flows. As part of the effort to encourage implementation of the Task Force Report's conclusions, including an increased flow of official development assistance, the Committee requested the World Bank to prepare a report for its next meeting on the volume of ODA flows forecast for the period 1986-90.

18. The Ministers took note of the discussion in the Interim Committee on the issues raised in the recent G-10 and G-24 Reports. The Ministers also recalled the commitment made by the Chairmen of the Interim and Development Committees at the Seoul meetings to communicate with each other with a view to seeing to what extent arrangements could be made for cooperation on matters pertaining to development. Taking note of the Chairman's intervention in the meeting of the Interim Committee, the Ministers requested him, after holding further consultations with the Chairman of the Interim Committee, to report to the next meeting of the Development Committee his views on the modalities of cooperative arrangements for improvements in the financial and monetary system's impact on growth and development.

19. The Committee was informed by the GATT Director General of the latest developments on international trade issues and the progress made by GATT's Preparatory Committee in defining the agenda for the proposed new round of trade negotiations. The Committee reiterated its call for all governments to resist protectionism and encouraged governments to launch the new round under GATT auspices at an early date with a view to further opening markets and strengthening the trading system. Ministers expressed the hope that Contracting Parties would take into account trade liberalization measures adopted in developing country adjustment and growth policies in the context of trade negotiations within the GATT framework. It invited the GATT Director General to continue to keep it informed about further developments.

20. The Committee expressed its profound appreciation to the retiring President of the World Bank, Mr A. W. Clausen, for his energetic support and encouragement of the work of the Committee, and for the highly significant contributions he has made during his five years in office to the cause of economic and social progress in the developing world. His imaginative and dedicated leadership of the Bank during a period of considerable stress in the global economy has, the Committee noted, positioned the institution well to build on the expanded role which has rightly been assigned to it. The Committee wished him well for the future.
21. The Committee agreed to meet again in Washington, D.C. on September 29, 1986.
Communique of the Interim Committee of the Board of Governors of the International Monetary Fund

1. The Interim Committee of the Board of Governors of the International Monetary Fund held its twenty-sixth meeting in Washington, D.C., on April 9-10, 1986, under the chairmanship of Mr H. Onno Ruding, Minister of Finance of the Netherlands. Mr Jacques de Larosiere, Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund, participated in the meeting. The Chairman of the Development Committee, Mr Ghulam Ishaq Khan, took part in certain of the deliberations. The meeting was also attended by observers from a number of international and regional organizations and from Switzerland.

2. The Committee reviewed the World Economic Outlook. Attention was drawn to a number of the major developments in the economic setting since the Committee's last meeting, including the strengthened committment to reducing budgetary deficits in the United States, the further adjustment in the pattern of exchange rates among major currencies, the continued downward movement in international interest rates, continued progress in reducing inflation, and the sharp decline in oil prices. The decline in oil prices from 1985 to 1986 represents a transfer of income from oil exporting developing countries to the industrial world of the order of $60 billion. Committee members felt that these developments had generally improved the outlook for sustainable growth. However, it was noted that the financial position of oil exporting countries had been weakened, with consequences for many other developing countries. It was important that the opportunities offered by these price developments be fully seized in order to promote non inflationary growth.

The current and prospective reduction in the U.S. fiscal deficit was welcomed. In respect of those countries where the economy is operating below capacity, and the balance of payments is in strong surplus and inflation is largely eliminated, it was noted that there might be room for more growth-oriented policies in the short term, while preserving the credibility of the authorities' medium-term policy stance. Committee members welcomed the decline in interest rates and hoped that further progress in reducing fiscal pressures and inflation would allow this process to continue, thereby helping capital formation and the growth of output and employment and alleviating the debt burden of developing countries. In the view of the Committee, structural policies aimed at improving the efficiency of resource allocation remained of central importance.

The Committee took particular note of the fact that developing countries continue to face a number of serious problems. The exceptionally difficult economic conditions in low-income countries, especially in Africa, continue to be a matter of special concern. In 1985, world trade had been sluggish, commodity prices fell considerably, imports declined in real terms in many countries, and the growth of output slackened. Nevertheless, some progress was made by developing countries in coping with their economic problems. On the whole, and although there remain notable exceptions, the rate of inflation has been contained and a number of countries have adopted particularly bold anti-inflationary policies; current account deficits remain well below their peak figures of the earlier 1980s. Much remains to be accomplished, however, and the Committee considered it particularly important that effective domestic policies for promoting non-inflationary growth should be pursued.

3. The Committee welcomed the progress that is being achieved in strengthening the current debt strategy along the lines proposed by the United States at the last Annual Meetings. The strategy must continue to be tailored to individual cases and aim at promoting durable growth in debtor countries and restoring normal relations with creditors in the context of a growing world economy.

While the Committee recognized that substantial progress had been made by a number of debtor countries despite difficult external circumstances, it noted that the basic debt ratios remained at difficult levels. It stressed the need for all debtor countries to follow sound macroeconomic and structural policies which are so important in rebuilding financial confidence and for creating a climate more conducive to encouraging domestic savings and productive investment as well as the repatriation of flight capital and direct investment flows.

The Committee also emphasized the importance of sound policies in industrial countries for the successful implementation of the debt strategy. It was important for these countries to maintain open markets, liberalize trade, and pursue policies aimed at increasing growth, reducing exchange rate instability and, in particular, further lowering interest rates.

It was essential to continue co-ordinated financial support, involving both official and private creditors, for debtors implementing sound economic policies, including those most affected by the recent substantial decline in world oil prices. In some cases, further concerted lending by commercial banks in support of economic adjustment efforts was needed in amounts and on terms appropriate to the circumstances and prospects of individual countries. This would, over time, improve the quality of banks' existing assets. Flexibility in rescheduling official debt was considered essential in support of sound adjustment programs. In addition, the Committee welcomed the move by official export credit agencies in industrial countries toward resuming or increasing cover, on a case-by-case basis, for countries whose debts have been rescheduled and which are undertaking the policy adjustments necessary to restore their creditworthiness. The Committee stressed the importance of this trend being carried further, but it noted that the resumption of export credit cover must not become a substitute for new funds from commercial banks where these are appropriate.

The Committee reaffirmed the central role of the Fund in providing its members assistance and financing to develop growth-oriented adjustment programs and in serving as a financial catalyst, and noted the increased need for flexibility in the case-by-case application of the policy on enlarged access to Fund resources. The Committee also welcomed the increasingly valuable role being played by the World Bank in the strengthened debt strategy by fostering efficient resource use as well as by providing long-term financial assistance and underlined the importance of close collaboration between the Bank and the Fund in applying this strategy.

4. The Committee had a substantive exchange of views on a number of issues related to the international monetary system. These issues were examined in the reports put before the Committee by the Group of Ten and the Group of Twenty-Four at it last meeting in Seoul, as well as in a report by the Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund on the discussions of these issues in the Executive Board since that time. The Committee's views on the exchange rate system, surveillance, and the role of the SDR are contained in paragraphs 5, 6 and 7.

5. Concerning the exchange rate system, the Committee agreed that the flexibility with which the system had operated had enabled the world economy to adapt to a number of major disturbances; however, the variability of exchange rates and the longer-term misalignments that had emerged remained a source of concern. It was agreed that, if better exchange rate performance were to be achieved on a durable basis, it would be of the essence that economic policies be conducted in a sound and mutually consistent way and that exchange rate considerations should play their part in those policies. The Committee asked the Executive Board to consider further whether there are any modifications in the exchange rate system which would contribute to enhancing exchange rate stability and the mutual consistency of economic policies without sacrificing the essential flexibility of the system.

6. The Committee reconfirmed the key role that Fund surveillance needs to play in the functioning of the international monetary system. The Committee noted that several proposals presented by the Group of Ten and the Group of Twenty-Four to strengthen surveillance are being implemented. To improve the multilateral setting for surveillance, the Committee asked the Executive Board to consider ways in which its regular reviews of the world economic situation could be further adapted to improve the scope for discussing external imbalances, exchange rate developments, and policy interactions among members. An approach worth exploring further was the formulation of a set of objective indicators related to policy actions and economic performance, having regard to a medium-term framework. Such indicators might help to identify a need for discussion of countries' policies. The Committee noted that increased emphasis would be given in the World Economic Outlook to policy interactions among industrial countries in order to strengthen the basis for assessing the international repercussions of the policies and objectives of the major industrial countries, and also to help promote the further development of recent initiatives to enhance policy co-ordination among these countries. The Committee stressed the importance of taking into account the views of the whole Fund membership in this multilateral discussion. In addition, the Committee asked the Fund to consider further the ideas in the Group of Ten and the Group of Twenty-Four reports regarding the strengthening of the consultation process.

7. The Committee noted the progress made by the Executive Board in studying the functioning of the international reserve system and the role of the SDR in a system in which borrowed reserves play so prominent a part, but are not now readily available to a number of countries with limited access to financial markets. It considered that the SDR, which is an owned reserve asset, can play a useful role as a component of international reserves and as a unit of account. It also recognized the potential use of the SDR as a ``saftey net'' against unexpected contingencies. The Committee stressed the monetary character of the SDR which should not be a means of transferring resources and recommended that the Executive Board study possible improvements in the monetary characteristics of the SDR that would increase its attraction and usefulness as a component of monetary reserves.
The Committee again discussed the question of SDR allocations and determined that, although most members favoured an allocation, the broad support needed for an allocation was lacking at this time.

The Committee urged the Executive Board to continue its discussions on the role of the SDR in the present international monetary system and on SDR allocation in the light of proposals, aiming at the different possibilities of obtaining a more balanced and stable proportion of SDRs in members' reserves that have been put forward in that Board, and to report to the Committee at its next meeting on the progress in these discussions.

8. The Committee reiterated the key role of the Fund in assisting countries in designing adjustment policies and in providing balance of payments financing. In this context, the Committee welcomed the decisions taken by the Executive Board establishing the Structural Adjustment Facility (SAF) for providing assistance on concessional terms to low-income countries with protracted balance of payments problems in support of medium-term programs of macroeconomic and structural adjustment in order to foster growth and balance of payments viability. The new facility calls for close collaboration between the Fund and the World Bank with a view to assisting members in developing their own comprehensive medium-term policy frameworks as a basis for using SAF resources as well as to ensure the flow of additional external resources to these countries from the World Bank, other lending agencies, and donor countries. In furthering their collaboration, the Fund and the Bank should maintain their respective areas of responsibility, avoid cross-conditionality, and ensure that the policy advice given by the two institutions is consistent.

9. The Committee intends to give further consideration at its next meeting to the issues raised in the reports of the Group of Ten and the Group of Twenty-Four. That consideration will will be based on the work the Executive Board will carry out in the coming months on these issues, taking into account the guidance it has been given by the Committee.
10. The Committee agreed to hold its next meeting in Washington, D.C. on September 28, 1986.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: How many jobs were created in each year from and including 1944-45 and in each of those years, what percentages did those jobs represent of the (a) total Australian population and (b) Australian workforce.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There are no official statistics on the number of jobs created in Australia, as such.

The closest approximation available from official sources would be figures obtained from a comparison, over time, of the total number of employed persons as estimated by the Australian Bureau of Statistics from the labour force survey which it has conducted since 1966. A series of annual averages of these figures, including year-to-year changes, expressed as a percentage of (a) total Australian population and (b) estimated total labour force, is shown in Table 1.

There are no comparable figures available for years prior to 1966. However, it is possible to derive an indication of trend from data available from the Censuses of Population and Housing conducted in 1947, 1954, 1961 and 1966. Relevant figures are shown in Table 2. To bring the census figures into closer relationship with the later (1966 onwards) survey figures, defence personnel have been excluded from the labour force figures in Table 2. A measure of the disparity still existing in the statistics (due largely to definitional differences between the two collections in respect of `employed persons', and in the collection methodologies used) can be gauged from the variation between the figures for 1966 in Tables 1 and 2.
ESTIMATED NUMBER OF EMPLOYED PERSONS (ANNUAL AVERAGE); ANNUAL CHANGE; ANNUAL CHANGE AS PERCENTAGE OF TOTAL MEAN AUSTRALIAN POPULATION; AND ANNUAL CHANGE AS PERCENTAGE OF TOTAL LABOUR FORCE, 1966-1985
(a) Discontinuity in series. Prior to 1978, estimates are based on 1976 Population Census benchmarks. From 1978 onwards, they are based on 1981 Population Census benchmarks.

(b) Definition of employed persons extended to include persons who worked without pay between one and 14 hours per week in a family business or on a farm (i.e. unpaid family helpers). Revised estimates not yet available for earlier periods.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 20 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the procedure to claim refunds on departmental rail travel require (a) up to 6 signatures and (b) take up to 4 days; if so, does this encourage his departmental officers to travel by air at greater expense.
(2) What is the annual (a) cost and (b) number of departmental (i) air fares and (ii) rail and car expenses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 27 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to recent allegations of malpractice by the Ciba-Geigy company involving hazardous chemicals.
(2) What action has been taken to establish a system of effective national control over the use of hazardous chemicals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) I provided my views on these issues during Question Time in the House on 17 April 1986. A system of evaluation and regulation of pesticides exists through the National Health and Medical Research Council, Australian Agricultural Council and State health and agriculture authorities. This system has ensured that a single and uniform clearance mechanism has operated for some 20 years. Australia, because of its Commonwealth-State legislative arrangements, relies to a large extent on such voluntary arrangements between the Commonwealth and States. In this particular case an undertaking by Ciba-Geigy to reformulate a pesticide was not carried out and this was not picked up by the State regulatory authorities. As indicated in my response to the House on 17 April, I have initiated moves, with my colleague the Minister for Primary Industry, to develop uniform national pesticide legislation to strengthen this system. The matter has been referred to the Australian Agricultural Council and the National Health and Medical Research Council in the first instance.

Regarding other hazardous chemicals, the Government is currently giving consideration to legislative proposals for a chemicals notification and assessment scheme for industrial chemicals which would introduce controls over those chemicals not subject to existing notification and assessment procedures.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has his attention been drawn to the comments of members of the Advisory Committees of the Constitutional Commission that the experience of the past shows immense difficulties in the way of achieving constitutional reform and the record of constitutional change in Australia has been dismal. If so, is the expenditure of more than $4.5m on the Constitutional Commission justified.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I assume that the comments to which the honourable member refers were those he quoted out of context in the House of Representatives on 27 May 1986-Hansard page 4092. To put the comments in context, in responding to my invitation to accept appointment to Advisory Committees both members expressed enthusiasm for the work in which they are now participating. Professor Coper said, ``I am delighted to accept, and look forward to assisting in this way in the review of the Constitution . . .''

``Both the Commission and the Advisory Committees appear to me to be particularly strong, and although the record of constitutional change in Australia has been pretty dismal to date, perhaps this time we have more reason to be optimistic.''

Mr Lindell said, ``May I indicate that I share your belief regarding the importance of the project and also the need to inform and educate the Australian people as to any proposals for change put forward by the Commission. The experience of the past shows the immense difficulties in the way of achieving constitutional reform. It is to be hoped that the Commission will be able to draw on the lessons of the past and utilise the opportunity presented by the celebration of the 1988 Bicentennial Year as the means by which it may help to achieve the necessary changes to Australia's Constitution''.

It was because I shared the view that the record of constitutional change in Australia had been dismal and that experience of the past had demonstrated the difficulties of achieving reform via Constitutional Conventions that I recommend, and the Government approved, the establishment of the Constitutional Commission as a new initiative to improve that record.

Attacks on the Commission's expenditure have given a distorted picture of the remuneration paid to Commission members. Sir Maurice Byers is probably Australia's most eminent constitutional counsel who would expect to command a daily fee substantially in excess of $2000. The fee negotiated with him was $750 per day. This compares very favourably with fees paid by the previous Government to senior counsel employed on a full-time basis of $1250 a day or higher. Sir Maurice is engaged on a part-time basis, i.e. he is paid only for the days he works for the Commission.

Mr Gough Whitlam is not receiving any remuneration for his work on the Constitutional Commission at the moment. As Ambassador to UNESCO his Parliamentary Pension is only ``topped up'' to the salary of other Ambassadors. The position of National Art Gallery Chairman which Mr Whitlam will take up on return to Australia is, like the position on the Constitutional Commission, part-time only.

The other Commissioners are Sir Rupert Hamer, former Liberal Premier of Victoria; Mr Justice Toohey of the Federal Court, who does not receive any additional remuneration for his work on the Commission; Professor Enid Campbell, who received no remuneration from the Constitutional Commission in 1985-86; and Professor Leslie Zines. All hold part-time positions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Government give a commitment to release all proposals for constitutional reform proposed by the Constitutional Commission prior to the next election.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The date by which the terms of reference of the Constitutional Commision require it to report, namely, 30 June 1988, is later than the latest date by which the next federal election must be held. Consequently, no such commitment can be given in relation to the Commission's final report. However the Commission intends to publicise its provisional proposals, and its terms of reference require it to consult the public, in the course of its inquiry. A series of issues papers and discussion papers containing proposals will be published. The first of those have already been published.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do nuclear-powered ships and submarines visiting Australian ports have containment facilities to prevent the escape of radioactive materials in the event of a power malfunction; if so, what.
(2) Are nuclear-powered sources on vessels visiting Australian ports as safe as those at nuclear-powered stations; if not, why not.

(3) In view of the recent disaster at Chernobyl, is he satisfied that the containment facilities on nuclear-powered vessels visiting Australian ports are adequate to prevent the release of radioactive materials during a power malfunction.
(4) Will he take steps to ensure that nuclear-powered ships and submarines visiting Australian ports have adequate containment facilities; if not, why not.

(5) What section of his Department is directly responsible for the monitoring of safety requirements laid down in the guidelines covering the visits of nuclear-powered vessels announced by the Attorney-General on 15 December 1983.
(6) Are other Departments involved in ensuring that these safety requirements are complied with; if so, (a) which Departments and (b) what are their particular areas of responsibility.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. While specific design features of the reactors on US warships are classified, it can be stated that there are multiple barriers for containing the release of fission products. The safe containment of fission products, including in combat situations, is accorded the highest priority in the construction of these warships, as it is necessary for the crew to live next to the reactor at all times and to continue to function even if the ship sustains battle damage.

(2) (3) and (4) The Australian Government believes that the particular operational and safety features of visiting nuclear powered warships (NPWs) make them much safer than nuclear power stations of the Chernobyl type. US naval reactors are different in design, power output, fuel integrity and standards of construction from the Soviet reactor in Chernobyl.

All US naval reactors which are now in operation are of the pressurized water design, wherein the nuclear core is maintained in a total water environment. This design uses no graphite and therefore the reported problem at Chernobyl involving a graphite fire is physically impossible in a US naval reactor. The US naval reactors are also typically one tenth the size of the Chernobyl reactor, and unlike Chernobyl, do not normally operate at high rates of output.

NPWs visit Australian ports only in accordance with strict environmental and safety regulations designed to protect the public in the unlikely event of a reactor accident. One of the conditions of entry for NPWs is that there must be a capability to remove the vessel to a remote safe location within 24 hours. The conditions also require the activation of an Australian radiation monitoring program during a NPW visit. This program has never revealed a radiation leak or a rise in the natural background radiation levels.

(5) and (6) Responsibility for assessing and monitoring safety requirements associated with NPW visits rests with the Visiting Ship Panel (Nuclear). This panel is chaired by Defence and includes representatives from the Australian Atomic Energy Commission (AAEC), Natural Disasters Organisation, Royal Australian Navy, Department of Foreign Affairs, Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment and the Australian Radiation Laboratory, all of which contribute expert advice and opinion. The AAEC is specifically responsible for radiation monitoring arrangements. The precise responsibilities of the other bodies during visits vary according to individual port safety arrangements, which are the responsibility of State or Territory Governments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 28 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What amount of money will be spent on the new phase of the ``Priority One'' program which began on 25 May 1986.
(2) What is the estimated expenditure in this phase on radio advertising including (a) production and (b) on-air costs.

(3) In respect each radio advertisement (a) how many times was it aired (b) what was its duration and (c) (i) on which stations, (ii) in which States and Territories and (iii) at what times was it shown.
(4) What (a) is the cost of producing the pamphlet ``Priority One in Action'' and (b) the number of copies printed.
(5) What new information is included in this latest publication, when compared with earlier published material on the program, that will benefit young people.

(6) Did he state on 23 May 1986 that radio is the most effective medium for reaching young people; if so, why was the first phase of the ``Priority One'' program advertised extensively on television and in newspapers.
(7) Is this the final phase of the program.
(8) What funds (a) were spent on the first phase of the program (b) will be spent on the program in (i) 1985-86 and (ii) subsequent financial years.
(9) What evidence does the Government have of the percentage of youth who are, or who are not, aware of the opportunities available to them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) $400,000 has been allocated for the new phase of the Priority One program which began on 25 May 1986.

(3) The following list details the number of times the advertisement was aired by each radio station, by State/Territory. The radio advertisements are of a 30 second duration. The scheduling of advertisements is the responsibility of the program manager.
(4) 500,000 copies of the pamphlet were printed at a cost of $75,451.08 (including agency head hours and production costs and printing).

(5) Priority One in action is designed to provide up to date information on Priority One and in particular to provide the information young people need to take advantage of the range of opportunities available to them under the Priority One initiatives. Earlier publications announced the initiation of the Priority One Young Australia Strategy and the National Youth Phone-in, and reported its outcomes.
(6) I stated on 23 May 1986 that radio is the most effective medium for reaching young people. This is why we have used radio when addressing young people.

There has been no paid advertising of Priority One on television. Television coverage of Priority One has been provided by the television stations as a community service. Of the newspaper advertising of Priority One, some was directed at the public at large rather than young people specifically and the remainder was an added effort to ensure that young people would know the telephone number to enable them to participate in the Priority One National Youth Phone-In.
(7) This is the final phase of the ``Priority One'' program in 1985/86.

(8) In 1985-86, including the $529,754 spent by the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism in marketing the Government's Strategy for Young People, a total of $2,529,754 was spent on the promotion of Priority One. The extension of the program is a matter for Budget consideration and will be announced as part of the 1986-87 Budget.

(9) A range of reports have highlighted the need to better inform young people of opportunities available to them. The reports include: ``Youth and Work in Australia-A Comprehensive Policy Agenda'' (OECD); The Report of the Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs reports commissioned by State and local Governments and Youth Affairs Council of Australia's nationwide consultation report ``Creating Tomorrow Today''.

Additionally, the National Youth Phone-In provided evidence to suggest that young people are aware in general of the opportunities available to them but are not aware of the details of such opportunities. The new phase of the campaign is intended to address this situation and provide information as to where young people can obtain details of opportunities they may wish to pursue.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the Minister for Finance expressing Government policy when in answer to a question without notice (Senate Hansard, 2 June 1986, page 3144), he stated that if a farmer wants to gain exemption from fringe benefits tax he can do so by charging the market rental and increasing wages to cover the rental, and that there was no problem.
(2) If the Minister's statement is not Government policy, what is the aim of the fringe benefits tax as applied to farmers.
(3) If the Minister is expressing Government policy is it a fact that it is no problem for farmers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minister for Finance was quite correct in stating that a farmer would not be liable for fringe benefits tax for employer-provided accommodation if he charged employees the full market rental for that accommodation. It is also open to the farmer to increase employees' wages to cover the rental charged.

(2) There is no conflict between the Minister's statement on the fringe benefits tax as it relates to farmers and Government policy. The Government set out to achieve an equitable and efficient tax system. This entails taxing the total remuneration packages of employees, including non-cash fringe benefits which had substantially escaped the tax net. The virtual non-taxation of this non-cash income had benefited some employees since lower level of total remuneration gave the same after-tax income to the farm employee as could be obtained from a higher remuneration package fully subject to tax. This system was clearly inequitable between employees with different levels of non-cash benefits, both within the rural sector and across a wider range of industries. After careful consideration the Government concluded that taxing non-cash fringe benefits at the employer level would be the most effective method of correcting this. In order to ensure that the non-cash remuneration of all employees is effectively taxed it is necessary to levy the tax on all employers, including those in the rural sector.

While it is administratively much simpler to levy the tax on employers the Government does not necessarily intend that they should bear the total burden of the tax. With the introduction of this tax it is expected that some employers and employees may see advantage in replacing fringe benefits with cash payments. As such payments would bear income tax, this development would be consistent with the Government's objectives.

Where necessary, the Government will consult with employers and the ACTU about possible adjustments to the wage fixing principles to provide for such `cashing-out' of benefits under appropriate conditions. In particular, it may be desirable to amend some rural awards which specifically address the provision of fringe benefits and the level of employee contributions.

(3) The basic point is that the fringe benefits tax will effectively impose tax on forms of income which were previously not subject to taxation and so it is reasonable to expect that some adjustments will be made in practices which have benefited from this deficiency in the tax system. However, it must be remembered that in total the tax reform package will deliver substantial cuts in marginal income tax rates. The fringe benefits tax will have only a modest effect on the farming community while they will benefit from a number of other tax reform measures including the proposed income tax rate cuts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to British students travelling around Australia on unemployment benefits; if so, when.

(2) Does the situation referred to in part (1) amount to fraud of the Australian social security system; if so, (a) what action has he taken to limit this fraud and (b) how much has this fraud cost for each year 1982 to 1986 to date.
(3) Will he speak to his British counterpart about this abuse of the social security system.
(4) Has he discussed the position with the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs; if not, why not; if he has had such discussions, what form did the discussion take and what was resolved.
(5) Has he directed his Department to inform the editors of ``STOP PRESS'' of his, and his Department's attitude to the position; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that British students admitted to Australia under the Working Holidaymakers Scheme may qualify for unemployment benefit, if they are available for and actively seeking employment while they are here. This situation has existed for some years.

(2) The situation does not amount to fraud, provided of course that applicants are honest in their statements about their availability and search for work. These people have a legal entitlement to unemployment benefit because of the operation of the provisions of the Social Security Act and the reciprocal social security agreement between Australia and the United Kingdom, and because of the terms of the entry permits issued under the Working Holidaymakers Scheme which enable them to seek employment in Australia. It is, however, a matter of some concern that British working holidaymakers in taking unemployment benefits are acting outside the spirit and intentions of the Scheme.

(3) I have written to the UK Minister of State for Social Security, the Hon. A. Newton, advising him that the Government intends to seek re-negotiation of the Australia/United Kingdom reciprocal social security agreement to remedy this situation. This matter will be discussed with officials from the UK Department of Health and Social Security in September this year.

(4) I have been discussing this matter with my colleague the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs for some time. Following discussions, the Government has decided to exclude UK holidaymakers from the payment of employment benefit. The proposed action outlined in my answer to (3) was a result of this decision.

(5) The editor of the British students' newspaper ``STOP PRESS'' has been in contact with the Director of the Department's London office, and was advised of the conditions for payment of unemployment benefit in the context of the Working Holidaymakers' Scheme.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to state which countries are host to US military bases or joint facilities.
(2) Is he able to say what amount the US Government pays to each of the governments of these countries as rent for the continued presence of those bases or facilities.
(3) What does the US pay to Australia as rent for the US joint facilities in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) This information is readily available in the publications ``The Military Balance 1985-86'' and ``NATO's Sixteen Nations'' of August 1985.

(3) The Australian Government receives no rent from the US in respect of the joint Defence facilities. The facilities are operated and managed by the two Governments as joint facilities under international agreements and the payment of rent by one of the parties would be inconsistent with these arrangements. While the arrangements for the use and occupation by the United States Navy of Commonwealth Land at North West Cape signed in 1967 included a provision for an annual rental of one peppercorn, this provision was removed when the Naval Station became a joint facility in 1974.

To revert to the then Coalition Government's policy of charging rent for any of the joint facilities might undermine this Government's policy of maintaining Australia's full and equal participation in all aspects of the operation of the Joint Facilities, which is fundamental to protecting Australia's sovereignty and interests.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the construction of a child care centre at Mt Druitt Hospital a Community Employment Project (CEP); if so, what was its total cost.
(2) What was the (a) Commonwealth, (b) State and (c) Mt Druitt Hospital contribution towards the funding of this project in (a) dollar and (b) percentage terms.
(3) When was the building completed.
(4) When was a management committee appointed for the centre.
(5) When did the centre become operational.
(6) Was a sign erected adjacent to the centre indicating that it was a CEP project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The centre was built under the Wage Pause Program and the total cost is not known. There was, however, a CEP project approved to provide drainage, landscaping and fencing around the centre at a total cost of $87,864.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Mitchell Royal Commission into the Greek conspiracy social security fraud case recommended that compensation be paid; if so, how much did it recommend for each person involved.
(2) Will the total compensation recommended be paid; if not, why not.
(3) How much did the Royal Commission cost.
(4) Will the Government release the Commission's report before a decision is made concerning the level of compensation payments; if not, why not.
(5) What measures has he taken to prevent this compensation payment setting a precedence for other unsuccessful social security fraud cases.

(6) Has this Commission and its associated press contributed to the scaling down of extensive and comprehensive measures to prevent and sanction fraud prevalent in the social security system; if so, to what extent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, although it was not a Commission of Inquiry into any ``Greek conspiracy social security fraud case'', but into compensation arising from Social Security conspiracy prosecutions. The amount recommended for each person is detailed in Volume 2 of the Report of the Royal Commission. The Commission recommended that volume 2 not be published, at least until all claimants have decidced whether or not to accept the compensation offered. This recommendation has been accepted by the Government.

(3) My colleague, the Special Minister of State, informs me that, to date, the Commission of Inquiry has cost $1,628,112. It is expected that the cost will ultimately be only slightly higher than this figure.
(4) Volume 1 of the Report was released on 10 June 1986.
(5) The Government considers that no generally applicable precedent has been established by its commitment to pay compensation in the circumstances of this case.

The need for the payment of compensation arose out of the way in which the case was conducted and the fact that there was no conspiracy involving the Greek Community. The present government, while maintaining its efforts to prevent and control fraud, will ensure that it launches prosecutions only where these are justified and where there is the necessary evidence to support them.
(6) On the contrary, the Government is committed to ensuring that the incidence of successful fraudulent claims for social security benefits is reduced.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say whether the US Army will be tasking upgraded M113 armoured personnel carriers to perform the same role as the Bradley M2 infantry fighting vehicle.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that the United States Army will continue to use the upgraded M-113 armoured personnel carrier in mechanized infantry divisions until the Bradley Infantry Fighting Vehicle is made available to those units. The Bradley will replace the M-113 in infantry and scout roles in active component units. At the same time the M-113 will continue to perform a variety of functions. It will remain in the force as an engineer squad carrier, medical evacuation vehicle, command vehicle, ground surveillance radar team carrier, and maintenace contact team vehicle. For affordability reasons the M-113 will remain the infanty squad carrier and scout vehicle in most reserve component mechanised and armour battalions and cavalry squadrons.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development Nations

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say which OECD nations are in the process of reducing either their armoured corps or mechanized infantry forces.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Although there have been some organizational changes and variations in equipment tables of armoured and mechanized infantry forces of some of the OECD countries, I am advised that none of these countries is in the process of reducing these forces.

(2) The force structure judgments of many OECD countries reflect, of course, quite different strategic circumstances to those of Australia. The NATO members, for instance, maintain armoured and mechanized forces to counter the superior numbers available to the Warsaw Pact countries. Japan's Self-Defence Force similarly takes account of Soviet Forces in Asia. Australia, on the other hand, faces no comparable armoured or mechanized threat.

QUESTION.PARA: Will he strengthen the provisions of section 263 and 264 of the Income Tax Assessment Act to place the obligation on the taxpayer, his accountant, bank and/or broker to assist in the location of required documents to ensure that tax investigation officers have powers similar to those provided under section 545 of the Companies Code and section 203 of the Customs Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government amended the Sales Tax Procedure Act 1934 with effect from 30 May 1985 to make it clear that the occupier of land or premises entered by an authorised taxation officer for the purposes of the sales tax law is required to provide that officer with all reasonable facilities and assistance to enable the officer to effectively perform his or her official duties.
Consideration will be given to providing a similar requirement for the purposes of other laws administered by the Commissioner of Taxation, including the Income Tax Assessment Act.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Trade: Forward Budget Estimates

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 13 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What assumptions and considerations underlie the estimated reductions in outlays for this portfolio for (a) 1986-87 and (b) 1987-88 as shown in the November 1985 Department of Finance report on the forward estimates of budget outlays and staffing.
(2) Does his Department as reorganised in 1985 have a (a) corporate and (b) annual operation plan as at 9 March 1986.
(3) What seminars, symposiums and courses have been run to improve the skills of those people remaining in the Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The forward budget estimates contained in the November 1985 Department of Finance report reflected the portfolio's expected funding requirements at that stage. The estimated reductions included
downward adjustments with respect to anticipated expenditure under the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974 and under the Export Expansion Grants Act 1978
a gradual wind-down of activity in the 1986-87 financial year associated with the America's Cup Defence to be held in February 1987 and
a termination of arrangements concerning payment in relation to the liquidation of the Stock Financing Fund of the International Sugar Organisation.

(2) The Department has adopted a corporate planning process which focuses on the dynamic nature of the trade environment with goals and objectives appropriate to that environment. The Department is also preparing to move into program budgeting in 1987-88.
Activity to develop an operational plan commenced in 1984-85 but was deferred pending the outcome of the restructuring of the portfolio.

(3) A program of seminars, symposiums and courses conducted in the period January to June 1986 to meet the development and training needs of staff remaining in the Department covered the following subject areas: Induction/Orientation, Occupational Health and Safety, Professional and Management Development. In addition a number of officers attended courses on Professional and Management Development run by external institutions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 14 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many research projects specifically related to literacy development and/or failure have been funded by the Government in each of the last 5 years.
(2) What were the (a) names of recipients, (b) projects and (c) amounts of each grant.
(3) Is literacy research grossly underfunded in view of its importance to the Australian community and economy.
(4) Will funding be boosted in the 1986 research awards.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Five research projects which relate to literacy have been funded by the Commonwealth in the past 5 years.
Literacy and numeracy demands on school leavers
Spatial information processing and specific reading disability
Literacy and educational perceptions of three Aboriginal communities
* Funded through the Education Research and Development Committee.
In addition much of the Commonwealth funding for curriculum development can be viewed as applied research on literacy:
identification of the needs faced by education systems in relation to literacy;
developing effective strategies for improving teaching practices in the field of literacy;
assisting parents to become effective partners with teachers in developing their children's reading abilities.
Several programs have been funded in curriculum development in 1984-85 and 1985-86. These are:

The national Early Literacy Inservice Course was developed by the South Australian Education Department from a New Zealand original. The Commonwealth has actively supported the national dissemination and co-ordination of the ELIC Program through the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Curriculum Development Council. Expenditure in 1984-85 was $276,700 and in 1985-86, $86,000.

In addition, the Commonwealth has funded State use of the Early Literacy Inservice Course through the Basic Learning in Primary Schools Program. Funding was $2,167,527 for the 1985 calendar year and approximately $800,000 has been approved in first quarter 1986.

A substantial range of projects in the general area of literacy and language have been funded by the Commonwealth through the BLIPS Program. Information provided by the States in 1985 indicates that approximately $1,300,000 was allocated to a range of programs. Interim figures for 1986 indicate that approximately $300,000 has already been requested for literacy-related programs.
The Commonwealth has funded three further projects through the Centre in recent years:
The Reading and Learning Program with A.C.T. Schools Authority and Canberra College of Advanced Education, received $35,000 in each of 1984-85 and 1985-86;
Evaluation of the Reading Recovery Program, with Victorian Education Department received $35,720 in 1985-86.

(3) No. Total Commonwealth expenditure on literacy related programs over the period 1984 to date exceeds $5 million. A considerable amount of Commonwealth funding has been administered through various programs under the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Acts towards applied research in literacy, within State programs. A great deal of research continues in State Education Departments on the assessment and improvement of literacy. Commonwealth funds are also provided under the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act to the States for the operation of universities and colleges of advanced education and for specific programs in TAFE. From within the total funds available to universities, colleges of advanced education and TAFE authorities they are able to undertake projects associated with literacy research. Priorities are established at the State and institutional level.

(4) There are no current plans to increase the high priority the Government gives to literacy research; however the prime responsibility remains with the States which have been assisted by Commonwealth funding.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether (a) there exists widespread community concern and dissent in the legal system about apparent disparities in punishment of convicted offenders, (b) the Reagan administration has recently secured passage of the US Comprehensive Crime Control Act 1984 and the establishment of the US Sentencing Commission in October 1985 and (c) sentencing commissions have been operating successfully in a number of US States for many years and have earned the support of the judiciary and the community.
(2) Does Australia's federal system impose special needs for machinery to secure consistency in sentencing.
(3) Is it a fact that the reluctance of appeal courts to intervene in discretionary decisions gives rise to a risk of necessary levels of sentencing disparity.
(4) Is he able to say whether the Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Harry Gibbs, intimated at a recent Criminal Law Congress that a sentencing commission was prima facie, a good idea.
(5) Is it a fact that federal/State jealousies over criminal justice are the main obstacle to the introduction of rational sentencing reform.
(6) Does he support in principle an Australian Sentencing Commission.
(7) Will he raise with the State Attorneys-General the need to establish an Australian Sentencing Commission whose composition and functions take into account State concerns.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a), (2), (3), and (5). The Australian Law Reform Commission has under consideration a Reference on sentencing relating to Commonwealth offenders. An earlier interim report of the Commission initially canvassed the idea of a Sentencing Council. The Law Reform Commission is in the process of reviewing the Interim Report including, the establishment of a Sentencing Council.
(1) (b) Yes, although I understand that the Sentencing Guidelines are yet to come into force.
(1) (c) I understand that some States in the United States of America have adopted Sentencing Commissions.

(4) I have been advised that at the Criminal Law Congress on 7 October 1985 the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia in response to a question put to him indicated the desirability of achieving greater uniformity in sentencing procedures in Australia and would support measures taken towards this end. I am also advised that the Chief Justice expressed no views as to the role any sentencing commission may play in the actual sentencing process.
(6) In principle I consider that the establishment of a Sentencing Commission or Council would be desirable.

(7) No; not at this stage. If, however, the Australian Law Reform Commission recommends that a Sentencing Commission (or Council) be established I will raise this matter again with the State and Northern Territory Attorneys-General.
