QUESTION.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 17 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any genetically altered organisms been released or escaped into the environment in Australia; if so, (a) where and (b) when have these occurred.
(2) What was the nature of the releases and escapes.
(3) What measures were necessary in each case to prevent the release being environmentally hazardous.
(4) Is he able to say what safeguards exist in each State and Territory to prevent the escape of potentially hazardous genetically altered material.
(5) Are institutions involved in genetic engineering required to maintain effective emergency plans for releases and escapes.
(6) Are the institutions required to notify (a) the Commonwealth and (b) State authorities in these cases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Strictly speaking, genetically altered organisms include all organisms whose genetic make-up has been changed either by purposeful manipulation and breeding, or by selection of a random change occurring in the natural environment. By this broad definition, most, if not all commercial crops, horticultural plants and livestock which are used in Australia today are examples of releases of genetically manipulated organisms.

In industries where microorganisms are used to make useful products like ethanol, baker's yeast, antibiotics, organic acids and enzymes, the process organism has nearly always been changed, often by man-induced mutations, and these organisms too have been widely released into the environment.

Only a few techniques for crossbreeding or genetic manipulation are explicitly regulated or monitored. For example, artificial insemination of farm animals is regulated in most Australian jurisdictions but plant breeding is not usually controlled.

Of the more recently developed techniques of genetic manipulation, the recombinant DNA technique has been monitored nationally since 1981 by the Recombinant DNA Monitoring Committee (RDMC), which reports to me.
With respect to recombinant DNA modified organisms, the RDMC has provided the following information in answer to the honourable member's question.

``This Committee sets out non-statutory safety guidelines and reviews work proposals submitted by organisations. As it is a non-statutory monitoring system the responsibility for ensuring that researchers and other employees maintain safety standards (including those specified in the RDMC's Guidelines) remains with the organisation performing the work. Each organisation establishes an institutional biosafety committee to provide this local supervision and to act as the point of contact for the RDMC.

The RDMC is not required to monitor all work involving the recombinant DNA technique; just that involving recombinant molecules unlikely to occur in nature. Certain groups of microorganisms are known to exchange genetic information in nature (so called self-exchangers). These exchanges involve the same types of reactions at the molecular level as are carried out by scientists in the laboratory when they manipulate organisms by recombinant DNA techniques. When genetic manipulations are conducted in the laboratory between organisms known to exchange DNA in nature, the work is exempt from the RDMC's Guidelines. The RDMC has exempted other experimental systems on a case-by-case basis, when the exchange involved is judged to be non-hazardous. In cases which are exempt, the work is expected to be conducted according to established safe microbiological practices.
(1) and (2) The RDMC is unaware of the accidental escape of any organism modified in the laboratory.

The RDMC has given advice on two vaccine trials involving live modified organisms, one for use on a species of farm animal, and the other for humans. The vaccine organisms concerned were disabled and extremely unlikely to survive long either in the test subjects or in the environment. In both cases the appropriate State department was closely involved in supervising the trials. The animal trial commenced during 1985 and the RDMC gave its advice on the human trial earlier this year. Both projects involve commercially sensitive information, and so details cannot be given. It should also be noted that several experiments involving animals and inserted genetic material are currently underway. In each of these cases the Committee or its Scientific Sub-committee has considered this work to be contained, as the facilities in which the animals are housed minimise the possibility of accidental release. In addition, the Scientific Sub-committee is presently considering the types of experiments involving recombinant DNA modified organisms (whether migroorganisms, insects, animals or plants) which are suitable for teaching purposes in tertiary institutions.

(3) To minimise hazard to the environment, the vaccine organisms were deliberately modified to ensure poor survival, and were tested to ensure that the modification was stably inherited and was not corrected after the administration to the test animals. The containment provided in the animal trials and the supervision by the appropriate State departments were also significant measures.

(4), (5) and (6) There appears to be no legislation applying specifically to products made with organisms genetically manipulated by recombinant DNA methods, but there is a good deal of legislation which regulates particular end uses or products. This applies regardless of the methods used in their development. Any biological pesticides, for example, must be registered through the same mechanisms as chemical-based pesticides. Thus the legally-based safeguards which exist vary from field to field, but within any one field are generally the same irrespective of whether the use or product involves genetically altered organisms. The arrangements vary from State to State depending upon the nature of the legislation in each jurisdiction. Requirements to notify government authorities in the event of an escape would similarly vary between fields and jurisdictions.

The RDMC has published Guidelines for recombinant DNA work of both small and large scale. Both sets of Guidelines seek to minimise the risk to escape, and the stringency of containment measures varies according to the potential hazard of the organism to be altered, as assessed by the RDMC. The Small Scale Guidelines specify several emergency measures which should be used following an accident or spill of culture. The Large Scale Guidelines explicitly require that emergency procedures be specified to handle safely any losses of culture material.

The RDMC has also established an interim assessment procedure for experiments involving the planned release of modified organisms. In providing information to the RDMC, organisations are asked to specify the methods which will be used to monitor, control, or eliminate the organism from the site and the surrounding environment, should this become necessary. Organisations are also asked to advise of the regulatory agency which will authorise the release.

For all work which falls within the scope of the RDMC's Guidelines, all organisations, whether research institutions, firms, or government agencies, are asked to submit proposals for review by the RDMC. It is a requirement of the Guidelines that accidents be reported to the RDMC. Only a couple of minor laboratory accidents have been reported since the RDMC was established in 1981.''

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 30 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to state why Dr Ramsey, Chairman of the Advanced Education Council, requested that submissions from Queensland's colleges of advanced education on ``proposals and priorities for the 1988-90 triennium'' be sent directly and separately to the Advanced Education Council.
(2) Is established procedure that a single Queensland submission, approved by the Queensland State Cabinet, be sent.
(3) Is it a fact that Dr Ramsey's request is in direct conflict with an Australian Education Council resolution made at its meeting in Broome, W.A., in 1985.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Following consideration of the report by the Chairman of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission on the structure of the Commission and arrangements for co-ordination and consultation with States and institutions, the Government decided to implement arrangements to improve the formal consultation process between the Commission and States and institutions. This included the requirement that in the triennial planning process both the States and individual institutions should present submissions to the Commission. Accordingly the Commission sought institutional submissions from colleges of advanced education and universities throughout Australia as part of the planning process for the 1988-90 triennium. This arrangement was discussed between the Commission and State representatives at their regular Consultative Meetings and was confirmed in letters to State authorities prior to the individual approaches to institutions.

(2) and (3) Following a request from me, States will provide a single statement for the 1988-90 triennium conveying the State priorities for all three sectors in tertiary education. The Queensland Minister for Education, the Hon. Lin Powell, mla, advised me on 17 April 1986 that he would be responsible for transmitting the States's submission to the Commonwealth. Dr Ramsey's request on behalf of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, for institutional submissions is not in conflict with the arrangements agreed between Mr Powell and me.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 30 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the Minister's Department and the proposed Australian Nuclear Sciences and Technology Organisation to be involved in food irradiation issues; if so, at what level.

(2) Does the Government intend that the proposed Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation will have responsibility over State, corporate and individual users of radio isotopes, the use of isotopic techniques and nuclear radiation for medicine, science, industry, commerce and agriculture.

(3) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the differences between the States with respect to the implementation of the Code of Practice for the Safe Transport of Radioactive Substances 1982; if so, will the Government be legislating to overcome these differences and when.
(4) If not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Atomic Energy Commission (AAEC) is currently involved in studies into food irradiation techniques and the suitability of various food items for irradiation, and the AAEC's successor the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) is expected to continue research and development work in this area. ANSTO is also expected to continue the AAEC's contribution to Phase II of the Regional Project on Food Irradiation organised jointly by the International Atomic Energy Agency and the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation and sponsored by the Australian Government under the IAEA's Regional Co-operative Agreement. The Department of Resources and Energy is not involved in food irradiation issues.
(2) No. This is a responsibility of State Governments.

(3) and (4) The transport of radioactive substances by road and rail is the responsibility of the States and Territories within their areas of jurisdiction, accordingly, implementation of the Code of Practice for the Safe Transport of Radioactive Substances in respect of these forms of transport is a State matter. The differences to which the honourable member refers relate to definitional matters and are a consequence of the fact that the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) Regulations for the Safe Transport of Radioactive Materials on which the Transport Code is based were formulated by the IAEA on the basis of a single administering body and do not take account of a federal system of government. Hence, implementation by the States/Territories requires certain matters in the IAEA regulations to be defined. For example, the term ``competent authority'' as used in the IAEA Regulations needs to be defined in the case of each State or Territory. Another example is that while the IAEA Regulations limit exposure of transport and storage personnel to that permitted for members of the public but in special cases allow for arrangements to be made for such personnel to be classified as radiation workers, which would effectively raise their limit, the South Australian regulations do not allow for any such classification. I understand such differences do not affect the substance of the Code itself.

It should be noted that following publication by the IAEA in 1985 of revised Regulations for the Safe Transport of Radioactive Material, a Committee of Commonwealth/State officials is currently considering the Australian Code with a view to its early revision.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the cost to revenue of tax deductibility of child care been estimated; if so, what is it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The cost to revenue of allowing full tax deductibility for child care expenses incurred by taxpayers whose children are cared for to enable them to go out to work is estimated to be of the order of $150m in a full year. For the purposes of this estimate it has been assumed that all such expenditure in respect of children aged 12 years and under would qualify for deduction. If tax deductibility were to be limited to payments to registered child care centres, or allowed only in respect of children of pre-school age, the cost to revenue would be less.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 20 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Mr P. J. Bewley, a public servant, been denied his entitlement to superannuation on the basis of a medical condition which has not recurred for at least 5 years; if so, why?

(2) Can the Superannuation Commissioner's appeal against the Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision in favour of Mr Bewley be overriden by the fact that Mr Bewley has fulfilled the medical requirements?
(3) How does the Government's decision to amend the Superannuation Act affect Mr Bewley's case?
(4) Will the Government compensate Mr Bewley for any delay or failure to provide him with his superannuation entitlement.
(5) Will the Government improve procedures for issuing of superannuation medical certificates.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Mr Bewley is an officer of the Australian Public Service and a member of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. Benefits become payable under the Scheme on cessation of employment to which the Scheme relates. Where the member is retired on invalidity grounds or dies in service, the benefit otherwise payable is reduced where the retirement or death was caused by or related to a physical or mental condition or conditions specified in a benefit classification certificate; thus benefits are not affected if the occasion for their payment is unrelated to the specified conditions. The benefit classification certificate previously issued in relation to Mr Bewley was set aside by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
(2) The Commissioner's appeal against the Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision has been withdrawn following the passage of the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Act 1986.
(3) The effect of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision in Mr Bewley's favour is protected by sub-section 6 (2) of the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Act 1986.
(4) This question does not arise as a member of the Scheme is not entitled to a benefit payment until cessation of employment.
(5) Further directions have been issued concerning pre-appointment medical examination of prospective employees.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 21 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the importation of refined petroleum products contributed to Australia's adverse terms of trade; if so
(a) to what extent and
(b) at what cost.
(2) Has Australia the facilities and capacity to refine the petroleum products it requires; if so, why are these products being imported.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On the basis of the most recently available data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (March quarter 1986) the importation of refined petroleum products has not contributed to Australia's adverse terms of trade; in that quarter the level of import prices of refined petroleum products was less, in relative terms, than the average price level of all exported goods. Indeed in only three of the previous fourteen quarters did the level of import prices for refined petroleum products exceed that for the export of all goods.

(2) In volume terms alone, Australia has sufficient refining capacity to satisfy its demand for petroleum products. Nominal refining capacity in Australia is approximately 720,000 barrels a day while petroleum product consumption in Australia is presently around 580,000 barrels a day.

Australia imports refined petroleum product primarily to supply the northern regions of Australia which are remote from Australia's major fuels refineries. The high cost of Australian coastal shipping, as well as logistical problems, makes it more economical to supply these regions through imports, sourced mainly from Singapore.

Product is also imported into the southern States from time to time, to make up for refinery production lost during periods of scheduled and unscheduled maintenance and to alleviate shortages caused by industrial or other problems.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 21 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which companies and federal departments, other than Local Government and Administrative Services, are involved in the transport of radioactive material from Lucas Heights, N.S.W.
(2) What (a) types of radioactive material are involved and (b) what are the (i) destinations of these consignments and (ii) mode of transport used.
(3) What are the public health and environmental effects of technetium if it is released into the atmosphere.
(4) What warning notices are required to be attached to containers of radioactive materials.
(5) In view of the recent theft of radioactive material from Upper Ferntree Gully railway station, will he require improvements to the warning notices on containers of this material; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In addition to the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, the following organisations are involved in the routine transport of radioactive materials from Lucas Heights:
Apart from the Department of Administrative Services, relevant federal authorities are the Departments of Transport and Aviation.

(2) (a) Radioisotopes distributed by the AAEC are either in liquid or solid form. The bulk of the 600-odd consignments made each week are mainly for use in nuclear medicine and most products are based on the radionuclide technetium-99m. Another significant product line in terms of consignments is iodine-131.

(b) The destinations of radioisotopes supplied by the AAEC range throughout Australia, including to over 50 hospitals and medical centres. Shipments are also made to New Zealand, the Philippines, Malaysia, Thailand, Singapore and to a lesser extent other countries. They are transported primarily by road and air, with a limited number of consignments using rail transport at some stage. Very occasionally sea transport is used for large shipments of radioactive material.
(3) Negligible public health and environmental effects would result if a typical AAEC consignment of technetium was released into the environment.

(4) Labelling requirements for radioactive materials transported within Australia are consistent with those recommended in the Regulations for Safe Transport of Radioactive Materials issued by the International Atomic Energy Agency. These labels show the radioactive warning trefoil, the word ``radioactive'', the name of the radionuclide being transported, the activity of the contents, the external radiation level, the class number of dangerous goods applying to radioactive materials, and the type of package design. In the case of radioisotopes dispatched from the AAEC, the packages also carry labels showing the name, address and telephone number of the consignor (the AAEC); the name and address of the consignee; and the action to be taken in the event of an accident.

(5) In view of the existing labelling requirements detailed in (4), it is unlikely that additional warning notices would reduce the risk of theft. Security arrangements for transporting packages of radioactive materials by rail in Victoria are currently being re-examined.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 27 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How long does it take for material to be dispatched after an inquiry on the drug information line.
(2) What will happen to the lists of inquirer names and addresses collected on the drug information line.
(3) What security measures have been taken to protect the names and addresses of people who call the drug information line.

(4) Have tests on the drug information line been undertaken to determine (a) waiting time for the operator to answer, (b) skill of the operator and (c) delivery time of information requested; if so; what were the results.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Information kits are dispatched by our agents in Melbourne generally within 24 hours of calls being received through the National Drug Information Line.
(2) The names and addresses of all callers to the National Drug Information Line are destroyed immediately after dispatch of information to callers in accordance with contractual obligations.

(4) (a, b, c) Random tests have been made each week since the commencement of the National Drug Information Line. The results of the operation of the telephone line have been satisfactory. Delivery times for information kits cannot be monitored due to the destruction of names and addresses after dispatch of kits. The feedback we have received, however, indicates that delivery times are generally satisfactory.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Exports to Sri Lanka: Australian Military Armaments

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Have Australian military armaments products been exported to Sri Lanka in 1985 and 1986; if so (a) what products were exported and (b) is he able to state that these exports have not been used for the suppression of the Tamil people.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honour- able member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Australian military armament products to the value of $2445 have been exported to Sri Lanka in 1985 and 1986. The products were rifle attachments for firing blank ammunition.

The products were of a non-offensive nature used for rifle training purposes and while they contribute in a small degree to the proficiency of the Sri Lankan armed forces they could not be used against the Tamil people.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Annual Reports: Departments and Government Agencies

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 3 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Will he consider the feasibility of requiring all Departments and government agencies to include, in their annual reports, a progress report on their responses to unfavourable Auditor-General's reports or reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Requirements relating to the annual reports of departments and government agencies are incorporated in guidelines tabled in the Parliament from time to time. These guidelines supplement any requirements contained in legislation.

New guidelines on departmental annual reports have been prepared, following amendments to the Public Service Act passed in 1985, and they address the issue raised by the honourable member of responses to comments or criticisms of the Auditor-General or Parliamentary Committees.
In accordance with requirements of the Public Service Act 1922, the revised guidelines have been submitted to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for approval before being tabled.

The current guidelines on annual reports of statutory authorities were tabled in 1982 and contain no requirement in relation to reports of the Auditor-General or Parliamentary Committees. Consideration will be given to the inclusion of such a requirement when the guidelines are next revised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why was a sound advertising campaign initiated for Priority One.
(2) Was the first campaign successful and cost effective; if so, how was this determined.
(3) What will be the cost of the second campaign.
(4) What advertising agency will prepare the advertisements.
(5) Was the advertising contract put to tender; if so, which agencies were invited to tender and which agencies submitted tenders.
(6) If the advertising contract was not tendered for, who was that course chosen.
(7) On what basis was the advertising contract awarded and who made the recommendations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There was only one campaign initiated for Priority One in 1985-86. This campaign provided for the dissemination of information on the elements of Priority One including a process to consult young Australians to obtain their comments and ideas both on Priority One and on their particular needs and problems generally. The final phase of this campaign which I announced on 23 May 1986 was aimed at providing information as to where young people can obtain details of opportunities they may wish to pursue.

(2) Evaluation of the effectiveness of the campaign was not undertaken in 1985/86 as the campaign itself did not finish until late in June 1986. The extension of the program including evaluation is a matter for budget consideration and will be announced as part of the 1986-87 Budget.
(3) $400,000 was allocated for the phase of the campaign which began on 25 May 1986.

(5), (6) and (7) This phase of the campaign was part of the campaign previously contracted to Chandler Hambleton and Mier and was not subjected to separate tender. The decision to recommend Chandler Hambleton and Mier for the total campaign was based on the favourable evaluation of this agency's credentials and previous satisfactory performance in government advertising.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 4 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What research and development on solar power is underway in Australia.
(2) To what extent is solar power in use in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A list of energy R & D projects, including those on solar energy, is given in the ``Compendium of Australian Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Projects'', No. 7, June 1986.

The Commonwealth Government provides direct support for energy research, development and demonstration projects through the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Program. A list of solar energy research projects was provided as part of my answer to Question on Notice No. 4063. (See page 95, House of Representatives Hansard 19 August 1986).

(2) Solar energy is making a useful contribution to Australia's energy requirements through passive solar household design and domestic water heating. Solar water heaters are being used extensively throughout Australia, particularly in Western Australia where 21% of households have solar water heaters and the Northern Territory where the proportion is 37%.

Solar energy is also playing a useful, though smaller, role in the area of photovoltaic cells. These are finding increasing use in remote locations for telecommunications, water pumping, navigational aids and some remote households.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 5 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the satellite transmission of the Special Broadcasting Service be regarded as a Satellite Program Service and be encoded; if so, will this prevent thousands of Australians from enjoying, or continuing to enjoy, this channel for the least cost.
(2) Is the remote area ABC television service similarly encoded.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The SBS has leased a low power transponder for the distribution of its television programs to the SBS terrestrial transmitters for re-broadcasting to the public. This activity is similar to commercial Satellite Program Services. The policy on SPS is to protect regional stations from fortuitous reception of metropolitan commercial network signals. There is no similar requirement to protect regional stations from national ABC or SBS television signals.

The requirement to encode SBS signals stems from the desire to not allow satellite services to be wrongly regarded by the public as being of low quality. The SBS is using a low power transponder, for distribution, and while the signal can be received reasonably well by domestic earth stations during clear sky conditions, there is degradation in the picture quality and sound when it is very cloudy or raining. During heavy rain, the low power signal may be lost altogether. By comparison, the more powerful ABC Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service (HACBSS) signal is specifically designed for direct to home reception and is affected to a much lesser extent.

Another factor is that the SBS signal can only be received within the South East Zonal beam. To upgrade the signal to the standard for direct to home reception (ie HACBSS quality) and extend coverage throughout Australia would be a multi-million dollar undertaking. There are no proposals to upgrade the SBS signal in the present economic circumstances.

It is not the Government's intention, however, to deny communities access to the SBS signal. If they wish, communities in the South East beam may establish authorised facilities for re-broadcasting the signal locally under the Self-help Broadcasting Reception Scheme. In that way residents in the community would be able to receive SBS programs using a standard television set.
(2) No. The ABC's Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service (HACBSS) is intended for direct to home reception and is provided via four high power transponders into the four zones.
